question.q: 1) In a world characterized by scarcity
question.c: C) we are not limited by time.
question.d: D) individuals need not work to obtain goods.
question.e: E) people must make choices among alternatives.

question.q: 2) Which of the following is the best definition of economics?
question.a: A) the study of how a provincial government allocates tax dollars
question.b: B) the study of how consumers spend their income
question.c: C) the study of how producers decide what inputs to hire and what outputs to produce
question.d: D) the study of how individuals, businesses, governments, and entire societies make choices as they cope with scarcity and the incentives that influence and reconcile those choices
question.e: E) the study of how consumers and producers meet each other at the market

question.q: 3) Which of the following is a microeconomic topic?
question.a: A) the reasons why a consumer buys less honey
question.b: B) the reasons why the average price level in a country falls
question.c: C) the cause of increasing unemployment
question.d: D) the effect of the government budget deficit on inflation
question.e: E) the reasons why the labour force in a country decreases

question.q: 4) The study of how wages are set for New Brunswick teachers is classified as
question.c: C) economics of social interest.
question.d: D) economics of private interest.

question.q: 5) Which of the following newspaper headlines concerns a macroeconomic issue?
question.a: A) Why are people buying more SUVs and fewer minivans?
question.b: B) How would a tax on e-commerce affect chapters.indigo.ca?
question.c: C) How would an unexpected freeze in Oxford, Nova Scotia change the price of blueberries in the Maritimes?
question.d: D) Why is Japan's economy stagnant?
question.e: E) Why do grain producers purchase less pesticides?

question.q: 6) The branch of economics that studies the choices of individuals and businesses is
question.c: C) positive economics.
question.d: D) normative economics.

question.q: 7) Each of the following would be considered a macroeconomic topic except
question.a: A) the reasons for a decrease in the unemployment rate.
question.c: C) the effect of the government budget deficit on inflation.
question.d: D) the determination of aggregate income.
question.e: E) the selection of production techniques.

question.q: 8) Complete the following sentence. Macroeconomics
question.a: A) is primarily concerned with the operation of individual markets in the economy.
question.b: B) deals mainly with the economic behaviour of households.
question.c: C) is the only part of economics to deal with government decisions.
question.d: D) is primarily concerned with the behaviour of the stock market.
question.e: E) is the study of the national economy and the global economy.

question.q: 9) The determination of prices in individual markets is primarily a concern of
question.c: C) macroeconomics.
question.d: D) microeconomics.

question.q: 10) Which one of the following topics does macroeconomics study?
question.b: B) effects of government safety regulations on the price of cars
question.c: C) the performance of the global economy
question.d: D) prices of individual goods and services
question.e: E) effects of taxes on the price of gasoline

question.q: 11) Which one of the following topics does microeconomics study?
question.a: A) reasons for a fall in the price of orange juice
question.b: B) the effect of a rise in the Canadian dollar on Canada's exports
question.c: C) effect of interest rates on national economic growth
question.d: D) effect of the government budget deficit on employment
question.e: E) determination of total production in a country

question.q: 12) Complete the following sentence. Microeconomics is
question.a: A) not concerned with factors of production.
question.b: B) concerned with normative issues only.
question.c: C) concerned with the size of the total amount of income earned by all households in an economy.
question.d: D) the branch of economics that studies the choices of individuals and businesses.
question.e: E) concerned exclusively with the role of the government in the economy.

question.q: 13) Which of the following would be considered a microeconomic topic?
question.a: A) the severity of a recession
question.b: B) the cause of unemployment in the economy
question.c: C) the effect of the government budget deficit on inflation
question.d: D) the determination of aggregate income
question.e: E) the study of how wages are set for mine workers

question.q: 14) The branch of economics that studies the national economy and the global economy is
question.c: C) Keynesian economics.
question.d: D) positive economics.

question.q: 15) The fact that human wants cannot be fully satisfied with available resources is called the problem of
question.c: C) normative economics.
question.d: D) marginal cost.

question.q: 16) The problem of scarcity exists
question.a: A) only in economies that lack incentives.
question.b: B) only in economies that have incentives.
question.c: C) in all economies.
question.d: D) only when people are unemployed.
question.e: E) now but will be eliminated with economic growth.

question.q: 17) The inescapable economic fact is that
question.a: A) there are unlimited wants and limited resources.
question.b: B) there are unlimited resources, and we just have to figure out how to allocate them.
question.c: C) capitalists are always exploiting the workers.
question.d: D) unions are always exploiting firms.
question.e: E) capitalists and unions cannot work together.

question.q: 18) An incentive ________.
question.a: A) could be a reward but could not be a penalty
question.b: B) could be a penalty but could not be a reward
question.c: C) could be either a reward or a penalty
question.d: D) is the opposite of a tradeoff
question.e: E) occurs in the macroeconomy but not in the microeconomy

question.q: 19) Scarcity confronts ________.
question.a: A) neither the poor nor the rich
question.b: B) the rich but not the poor
question.c: C) the poor but not the rich
question.d: D) the rich and the poor
question.e: E) families with incomes less than $25,000 a year

question.q: 1) The two big economic questions
question.c: C) involve neither self-interest nor social interest.
question.d: D) do not arise from scarcity.
question.e: E) involve both self-interest and social interest.

question.q: 2) The two big economic questions
question.a: A) summarize the scope of economics.
question.b: B) are "what goods and services are produced?" and "how are goods and services produced?"
question.c: C) have nothing to do with goods and services.
question.d: D) do not consider for whom goods and services are produced.
question.e: E) have nothing to do with the way goods and services are produced.

question.q: 3) The two big economic questions include all of the following except
question.c: C) how to produce.
question.d: D) for whom to produce.
question.e: E) can choices made in the pursuit of self-interest also promote the social interest.

question.q: 4) When a firm decides to produce more hybrid cars and fewer gas guzzlers, it is answering the ________ question.
question.c: C) "who"
question.d: D) "where"

question.q: 5) When a textile firm decides to produce more silk fabric and less cotton fabric, it is answering the ________ question.
question.c: C) "what"
question.d: D) "where"

question.q: 6) When a farmer decides to harvest tomatoes using machines instead of migrant workers, the farmer is answering the ________ question.
question.c: C) "who"
question.d: D) "where"

question.q: 7) Complete the following sentence. Capital is
question.c: C) tools, instruments, machines, buildings, and other constructions that businesses use to produce goods and services.
question.d: D) land.

question.q: 8) When a firm decides to produce computers using robots instead of people, it is answering the ________ question.
question.c: C) "how"
question.d: D) "who"

question.q: 9) To meet increased demand for its good, a firm decides to hire a few high-skilled workers, rather than hire many low-skilled workers. The firm is answering the ________ question.
question.c: C) "who"
question.d: D) "where"

question.q: 10) An art museum decides to offer tours by having visitors listen to CDs rather than have tour guides. The museum is answering the ________ question.
question.c: C) "how"
question.d: D) "where"

question.q: 11) To earn income, people sell the services of the factors of production they own. Land earns ________; labour earns ________; capital earns ________ and entrepreneurship earns ________.
question.c: C) rent; wages; interest; profit
question.d: D) profit; interest; wages; rent

question.q: 12) The fact that some people can afford to live in beautiful homes while others are homeless is an example of an economy facing the ________ question.
question.c: C) "for whom"
question.d: D) "where"

question.q: 13) The fact that a hockey star earns $3 million a year while a teacher earns $50,000 annually is an example of an economy facing the ________ question.
question.c: C) "where"
question.d: D) "for whom"

question.q: 14) Complete the following sentence. Entrepreneurship is
question.b: B) traded on the stock market.
question.c: C) categorized as capital.
question.d: D) the human resource that organizes labour, land and capital.
question.e: E) categorized as the factor of production labour.

question.q: 15) Sue, who has a law degree, earns $200,000 a year, while Chris, a high-school dropout, earns $5.00 an hour. This is an example of an economy facing the ________ question.
question.c: C) "for whom"
question.d: D) "where"

question.q: 16) A star athlete can afford a garage full of exotic cars while other people can only afford to take a city bus for transportation. This is an example of an economy facing the ________ question.
question.c: C) "for whom"
question.d: D) "where"

question.q: 17) Complete the following sentence. Financial capital is
question.a: A) one of the "gifts of nature."
question.b: B) the tools and machines that are used to produce goods and services.
question.c: C) money, stocks, and bonds.
question.d: D) used in the production of goods and services.

question.q: 18) Which factor of production earns the most income?
question.c: C) labour
question.d: D) entrepreneurship

question.q: 19) What choices are best for the entire society?
question.c: C) social interest choices
question.d: D) ethnic group choices

question.q: 20) Self-interest choices are
question.a: A) those choices which are best for the person making them.
question.b: B) never in the social interest.
question.c: C) always in the social interest.
question.d: D) those choices that are best for all residents of a region.
question.e: E) choices that are agreed to by majority vote.

question.q: 21) The expansion of international trade, borrowing and lending, and investment is
question.c: C) corporate revolution.
question.d: D) globalization.

question.q: 22) Which of the following relates factors of production to the sources of income correctly?
question.c: C) Labour earns rent.
question.d: D) Capital earns profit.

question.q: 23) Which statement about incomes earned by factors of production is false?
question.c: C) Labour earns wages.
question.d: D) Capital earns profit.

question.q: 24) A tractor is an example of which of the following factors of production?
question.c: C) land
question.d: D) entrepreneurship

question.q: 25) Which one of the following is an example of capital as a factor of production?
question.a: A) money held by Tim Hortons
question.c: C) an automobile factory owned by Ford
question.d: D) a high school teacher

question.q: 26) Which of the following would an economist classify as capital?
question.c: C) entrepreneurship
question.d: D) a computer

question.q: 27) Which one of the following is labour?
question.c: C) a shoe factory
question.d: D) a bread-slicing machine

question.q: 28) Which one of the following would economists classify as land?
question.a: A) an automotive plant in British Columbia
question.b: B) rich agricultural soil in Saskatchewan
question.c: C) an oil rig in the Atlantic Ocean
question.d: D) an elementary school in Nova Scotia
question.e: E) automobiles parked in a parking lot in Manitoba

question.q: 29) Which one of the following is an example of land?
question.c: C) Lake Erie
question.d: D) a road

question.q: 30) Which one of the following is an example of a factor of production?
question.c: C) the skills of a welder
question.d: D) an IBM stock certificate

question.q: 31) Which one of the following is an example of capital?
question.c: C) pasture
question.d: D) a bread-slicing machine

question.q: 32) The creation of a successful movie illustrates choices made in self-interest that also achieve the social interest if ________.
question.a: A) the movie has a higher attendance than any other movie produced that year
question.b: B) the movie is produced at the lowest possible cost, and the movie gives the greatest possible benefit
question.c: C) the movie addresses a social issue
question.d: D) the movie is an Academy award winner because an Academy award winning movie is most popular with the movie-going public
question.e: E) the movie is produced in a country where workers typically earn less than workers in North America

question.q: 33) The creation of a successful movie can influence the main questions that economics seeks to answer. Choose the statement that is false.
question.a: A) The movie influences the how question because the movie can create new production techniques, which can be used in subsequent films.
question.b: B) The movie influences the for whom question because the people who earn higher incomes through the movie production buy more goods and services.
question.c: C) The movie influences the when question because movie crews work on many different films and must be available for the entire production.
question.d: D) The movie influences the what question because it can lead to spinoff goods or a new movie genre, which can result in the production of similar films.
question.e: E) The movie influences the how question because it can use unknown actors or Academy Award winners.

question.q: 34) Choose the correct statement.
question.a: A) Canada produces more services than goods.
question.b: B) Canada produces more goods than services.
question.c: C) Canada produces an equal quantity of goods and services.
question.d: D) China's production of services is a greater percentage of its total production than Canada's.
question.e: E) Canada's production of manufacturing is a greater percentage of its total production than China's.

question.q: 35) In Canada ________ percent of the adult population have completed high school and ________ percent have a university degree.
36) Which of the following is not a factor of production?
question.a: A) the water used to cool a nuclear power plant
question.b: B) the effort of farmers raising cattle
question.c: C) the wages paid to workers
question.d: D) the management skill of a small business owner
question.e: E) the land used by a farmer to grow wheat

question.q: 1) Opportunity cost is
question.a: A) the value of your favourite activity.
question.c: C) the money you spend on food, shelter, and clothing.
question.d: D) the marginal benefit from an activity.
question.e: E) the highest-valued alternative that we give up to get something.

question.q: 2) During the next hour John can choose one of the following three activities: playing basketball, watching television, or reading a book. The opportunity cost of reading a book
question.a: A) depends on how much the book cost when it was purchased.
question.b: B) is the value of playing basketball if John prefers that to watching television.
question.c: C) is the value of playing basketball and the value of watching television.
question.d: D) depends on how much John enjoys the book.
question.e: E) is the value of watching television if John prefers playing basketball to watching television.

question.q: 3) Sally has to decide whether to study for her economics test or her accounting test. If she chooses to study for accounting, her opportunity cost of studying accounting is
question.b: B) less than the value of studying economics.
question.c: C) not comparable to the value of studying economics.
question.d: D) equal to the value of studying economics.
question.e: E) the future lost wages that will occur if she fails her accounting exam.

question.q: 4) When the government of Alberta chooses to build more roads, the required resources are no longer available to provide better health care facilities. This situation illustrates the concept of
question.c: C) opportunity cost.
question.d: D) human capital.

question.q: 5) The concept of opportunity cost
question.a: A) is relevant only for European countries.
question.b: B) suggests that individuals can achieve all they want.
question.c: C) suggests a major increase in public education spending means a reduced expansion in the public healthcare system.
question.d: D) is relevant only for developed countries.
question.e: E) is relevant only for developing countries.

question.q: 6) Which one of the following is a necessary consequence of scarcity?
question.c: C) the requirement of making choices
question.d: D) all wants are satisfied

question.q: 7) To make choices, people must
question.a: A) be able to carry out complex mathematical calculations.
question.c: C) be free from government constraint.
question.d: D) have unlimited access to information at no cost.
question.e: E) evaluate the values of alternative actions.

question.q: 8) When the government chooses to use resources to build a dam, those resources are no longer available to build a highway. This illustrates the concept of
question.c: C) opportunity cost.
question.d: D) a "how" tradeoff.

question.q: 9) What is the definition of marginal benefit?
question.a: A) the cost of an increase in an activity
question.b: B) the sum of benefit and cost that arises from an increase in an activity
question.c: C) the cost of a decrease in an activity
question.d: D) the benefit that arises from an increase in an activity
question.e: E) the benefit that arises from a decrease in an activity

question.q: 10) When asked in an interview what she missed the most because of the time she spent training for the Olympics, a rower, who lived on her own, answered "a normal social life." She also revealed that she had given up a job that paid $30,000 per year to train fulltime. She received a grant of $8,000 per year from Sport Canada, but this failed to cover all her training expenses. Her food and rent were $5,000 per year and training expenses were $12,000 per year. Aside from the value of a normal social life, what is the annual opportunity cost, expressed in dollars, to this rower of "Going for Gold"?

11) Saskatchewan had more hospitals than Ontario, despite having one-tenth the population. The Saskatchewan government closed many of these hospitals in spite of widespread local protests. Which one of the following arguments is true?
question.a: A) Since hospitals have positive benefits, they should never be closed.
question.b: B) If Saskatchewan had more hospitals than Ontario, it must have had too many hospitals.
question.c: C) The Saskatchewan government must have thought the marginal benefit from one of these hospitals exceeded its marginal cost.
question.d: D) The Saskatchewan government must have thought the marginal benefit from one of these hospitals was less then its marginal cost.
question.e: E) The communities where these hospitals existed bore no costs from these decisions, because they did not pay for any of the hospital operating costs.

question.q: 12) "There can be too much of a good thing." This statement suggests that
question.a: A) choices made in self-interest cannot be applied to many economic decisions.
question.b: B) a good may be produced to the point where its marginal cost exceeds its marginal benefit.
question.c: C) certain goods and services such as education and health care are inherently desirable and should be produced regardless of costs and benefits.
question.d: D) a good may be produced to the point where its marginal benefit exceeds its marginal cost.
question.e: E) a good may be produced to the point where its marginal benefit is equal to its marginal cost.

question.q: 13) Which of the following sayings best describes opportunity cost?
question.a: A) "Make hay while the sun shines."
question.b: B) "Love of money is the root of all evil."
question.c: C) "Boldly go where no one has gone before."
question.d: D) "There's no such thing as a free lunch."
question.e: E) "Baseball has been very good to me."

question.q: 14) If you take an additional class this term, you can graduate earlier. This is an example of
question.c: C) the pursuit social interest.
question.d: D) marginal benefit.

question.q: 15) Marginal benefit is the
question.a: A) total benefit from an activity.
question.b: B) additional benefit from a decrease in an activity.
question.c: C) additional benefit from an increase in an activity.
question.d: D) opportunity cost of a decrease in an activity.
question.e: E) opportunity cost of an increase in an activity.

question.q: 16) Complete the following sentence. Marginal cost is
question.a: A) the total cost of an activity.
question.b: B) the cost of a decrease in an activity.
question.c: C) the cost of an increase in an activity.
question.d: D) the opportunity cost of a decrease in an activity.

question.q: 17) The big tradeoff is the tradeoff between
question.c: C) current consumption and a higher future standard of living.
question.d: D) guns and butter.
question.e: E) personal security and private property.

question.q: 18) Monika will choose to eat a seventh pizza slice if
question.a: A) the marginal benefit from the seventh slice is greater than its marginal cost.
question.b: B) the marginal benefit from the seventh slice is less than its marginal cost.
question.c: C) the total benefit from all seven slices is greater than their total cost.
question.d: D) the total benefit from all seven slices is less than their total cost.
question.e: E) she has enough money to pay for it.

question.q: 19) Before starring as Tony Stark in Iron Man, Robert Downey Jr. had played in 45 movies that had average first-weekend box office revenues of a bit less than $5 million. Iron Man grossed $102 million in its first weekend. The success of Iron Man ________ the opportunity cost of hiring Robert Downey Jr.
question.c: C) decreases; more
question.d: D) increases; more

question.q: 20) The night before a history test, you decide to go to the movies instead of reviewing your notes. You get 60 percent on your test compared with the 75 percent that you normally score. You ________ a tradeoff ________, and the opportunity cost of your evening at the movies was ________.
question.a: A) faced; between a higher test score and an evening at the movies; the 15 percent fall in your grade
question.b: B) did not face; because your roommates agreed you should go to the movies and not study; zero
question.c: C) did not face; because you made the best choice; zero
question.d: D) faced; between a higher test score and an evening at the movies; the mark of 60 percent on your test
question.e: E) did not face; most students get 60 percent on history tests; the mark of 60 percent on your test

question.q: 21) A university decides to change its late night bus service between the campus and student housing from a fare-based service to a free service. This statement means that the incentive to ride the bus ________ and the opportunity cost of a bus ride ________. The university's decision is a ________ decision.
question.c: C) remains the same; remains the same; macroeconomic
question.d: D) remains the same; remains the same; microeconomic

question.q: 22) Refer to Fact 1.1.1. The cost of regenerating East London ________ an opportunity cost of hosting the 2012 Olympic Games ________.
question.a: A) is not; because few people attending the 2012 Olympics will spend much time outside Olympic venues
question.b: B) is; if the costs of the East London regeneration is equal to a significant percentage of the total amount spent by London taxpayers to host the 2012 Olympics
question.c: C) is; if the regeneration of East London would not occur unless London hosted the 2012 Olympics
question.d: D) is not; because regenerating East London is an unnecessary expense
question.e: E) is; if the property taxes of people living in East London increase

question.q: 23) You have the choice of going on vacation to Florida for one week, staying at work for the week, or spending the week doing fix-up projects around your house. If you decide to go to Florida, the opportunity cost of the trip is ________.
question.a: A) working and doing fix-up projects
question.b: B) working or doing fix-up projects, depending on which you would have done otherwise
question.c: C) working, because you would be giving up dollars
question.d: D) nothing because you will enjoy the trip to Florida
question.e: E) variable depending on the weather you leave behind in Canada

question.q: 24) Laura is a manager for HP. When Laura must decide whether to produce a few additional printers, she is choosing at the margin when she compares ________.
question.a: A) the total revenue from sales of printers to the total cost of producing all the printers
question.b: B) the extra revenue from selling a few additional printers to the extra costs of producing the printers
question.c: C) the extra revenue from selling a few additional printers to the average cost of producing the additional printers
question.d: D) the revenue from selling HP's printers as compared to printers from competing companies, such as Lexmark
question.e: E) the cost of producing HP's printers as compared to printers from competing companies, such as Lexmark

question.q: 25) Which of the following creates an incentive to increase the amount of an activity?
question.a: A) an increase in the marginal cost of the activity and a decrease in the marginal benefit from the activity
question.b: B) a decrease in the marginal cost of the activity and an increase in the marginal benefit from the activity
question.c: C) constant marginal cost and constant marginal benefit from the activity
question.d: D) an increase in the marginal cost of the activity and an equal increase in the marginal benefit from the activity
question.e: E) a decrease in the marginal cost of the activity and an equal decrease in the marginal benefit from the activity

question.q: 1) Statements about "what ought to be" are called
question.c: C) economic statements.
question.d: D) scientific statements.

question.q: 2) Statements about "what is" are called
question.c: C) economic statements.
question.d: D) scientific statements.

question.q: 3) Which of the following statements is normative?
question.a: A) Scientists should not make normative statements.
question.b: B) Warts are caused by handling toads.
question.c: C) As e-book prices fall, people buy more of them.
question.d: D) If income increases, sales of luxury goods fall.
question.e: E) There is more caffeine in a cup of tea than in a cup of coffee.

question.q: 4) A positive statement is
question.a: A) about what ought to be.
question.c: C) always true.
question.d: D) capable of evaluation as true or false by observation and measurement.

question.q: 5) A positive statement is
question.c: C) about what ought to be.
question.d: D) what is currently believed about the way the world operates.
question.e: E) an opinion that cannot be verified.

question.q: 6) A normative statement is
question.c: C) always true.
question.d: D) always false.
question.e: E) capable of evaluation, as true or false, by observation and measurement.

question.q: 7) "The rich should face higher income tax rates than the poor." This is an example of
question.c: C) a negative statement.
question.d: D) economic reasoning.
question.e: E) neither a normative nor a positive statement.

question.q: 8) Which of the following is an example of a positive statement?
question.a: A) Canada should cut back on its use of carbon-based fuels such as coal and oil.
question.b: B) Increasing the minimum wage results in more unemployment.
question.c: C) Every Canadian should have equal access to health care.
question.d: D) The Bank of Canada ought to cut the interest rate.
question.e: E) Canada should have lower tax rates for wealthier Canadians.

question.q: 9) Complete the following sentence. Economic models
question.a: A) do not answer questions about the economic world.
question.b: B) include most of the details of the economic world.
question.c: C) describe some aspect of the economic world, but include only those features needed for the purpose at hand.
question.d: D) answer questions that arise from normative statements.
question.e: E) were first developed in the 1970s.

question.q: 10) The scientific purpose of simplifying assumptions in an economic model is to
question.b: B) eliminate the need for further testing of the implications of the model.
question.c: C) abstract from the complexities of the real world those issues that are not important for the issues under examination.
question.d: D) eliminate the possibility of personal bias in the model.
question.e: E) add necessary hypotheses to the problem.

question.q: 11) Model A is superior to model B if
question.a: A) it contains more real world detail than model B.
question.b: B) it contains fewer unrealistic assumptions than model B.
question.c: C) its predictions correspond more closely to the facts than the predictions of model B.
question.d: D) it is preferred by a majority of researchers in a public opinion poll.

question.q: 12) In choosing among alternative models, economists generally have the strongest preference for models that
question.a: A) have assumptions that are close to exact replicas of reality.
question.b: B) are detailed and complex, with every available fact and figure included.
question.c: C) have few assumptions and are as simple as possible, even if they cannot predict very well.
question.d: D) predict better than any other that is available.
question.e: E) have assumptions that are complicated.

question.q: 13) A normative statement is a statement regarding
question.a: A) what is usually the case.
question.b: B) the assumptions of an economic model.
question.c: C) what ought to be.
question.d: D) the predictions of an economic model.

question.q: 14) "The rich face higher income tax rates than the poor" is an example of a
question.c: C) a predictive statement.
question.d: D) a theoretical statement.

question.q: 15) An economic model is tested by
question.a: A) examining the realism of its assumptions.
question.b: B) comparing its predictions with the facts.
question.c: C) comparing its complexity to other models that deal with similar issues.
question.d: D) the Testing Committee of the Canadian Economic Association.
question.e: E) comparing its descriptions and examining the realism of its assumptions.

question.q: 16) Which of the following is a positive statement?
question.a: A) Low rents restrict the supply of housing.
question.b: B) Low rents are better for a city than high rents.
question.c: C) Housing costs too much.

question.q: 12) A situation in which resources are either unused or misallocated or both is represented in a production possibilities frontier diagram by
question.a: A) any point on either the horizontal or the vertical axis.
question.b: B) a point above or to the right of the production possibilities frontier.
question.c: C) a point outside the production possibilities frontier.
question.d: D) a point inside the production possibilities frontier.
question.e: E) a point on or inside the production possibilities frontier.

question.q: 13) A production possibilities frontier is negatively sloped because
question.a: A) more goods are purchased as price falls.
question.c: C) some resources are unused.
question.d: D) there is not enough capital in the economy.

question.q: 14) Ted chooses to study for his economics exam instead of going to the concert. The concert he will miss is Ted's ________ of studying for the exam.
question.c: C) opportunity cost
question.d: D) discretionary cost

question.q: 15) Opportunity cost of an action is
question.a: A) the best choice that can be made.
question.c: C) the money cost.
question.d: D) the comparative cost.

question.q: 16) The concept of opportunity cost
question.a: A) cannot be explained by using a production possibilites frontier.
question.b: B) explains that goods are swapped for other goods.
question.c: C) implies that when a person is more efficient in the production of one good, he should produce that good and exchange it for some good that he is relatively less efficient at producing.
question.d: D) implies that a double coincidence of wants must be present for exchange to take place.
question.e: E) implies that because productive resources are scarce, we must give up some of one good to acquire more of another.

question.q: 17) On a graph of a production possibilities frontier, opportunity cost is represented by
question.a: A) a point on the horizontal axis.
question.b: B) a point on the vertical axis.
question.c: C) a ray through the origin.
question.d: D) the slope of the production possibilities frontier.

question.q: 18) Production efficiency is achieved when
question.a: A) the production possibilities frontier shifts outward at an even pace.
question.b: B) there are no more tradeoffs.
question.c: C) all resources are equally productive in all activities.
question.d: D) resources are not equally productive in all activities.
question.e: E) we produce goods and services at the lowest possible cost.

question.q: 19) A tradeoff exists when
question.a: A) we move from a point within the production possibilities frontier (PPF) to a point on the PPF.
question.b: B) we move from a point on the PPF to a point within the PPF.
question.c: C) the PPF shifts outward.
question.d: D) we move along the PPF.
question.e: E) the PPF shifts towards the origin.

question.q: 20) Which of the following quotations best illustrates a tradeoff?
question.a: A) "If the firm reorganized its production process, it could produce more widgets and more gadgets."
question.b: B) "The firm should sell more gadgets, even if it means less widget sales."
question.c: C) "The more and more gadgets the firm produces, the bigger the fall in widget production."
question.d: D) "If the firm invests more in capital equipment, it can expand sales next year."
question.e: E) "The firm has been able to lower costs due to its extensive experience in building widgets."

question.q: 21) A medical clinic has 10 workers. Each worker can produce a maximum of either 2 units of medical services or 5 units of secretarial services a day. The production possibilities frontier of this firm would show
question.c: C) constant opportunity cost.
question.d: D) zero opportunity cost.

question.q: 22) A medical clinic has 10 workers. Each worker can produce a maximum of either 2 units of medical services or 5 units of secretarial services a day. The opportunity cost of one more unit of medical services is
question.c: C) 0.4 units of secretarial services.
question.d: D) 2.5 units of secretarial services
question.e: E) dependent on the level of services.

question.q: 23) A medical clinic has 10 workers. Each worker can produce a maximum of either 2 units of medical services or 5 units of secretarial services a day. One day, the firm decides it would like to produce 10 units of medical services and 30 units of secretarial services. This output level is
question.c: C) inefficient.
question.d: D) costless.
question.e: E) is attainable if the firm reduces the number of its workers.

question.q: 24) A medical clinic has 10 workers. Each worker can produce a maximum of either 2 units of medical services or 5 units of secretarial services a day. One day, the firm decides it would like to produce 16 units of medical services and 5 units of secretarial services. This output level is
question.c: C) inefficient.
question.d: D) costless.

question.q: 25) The bowed-out (concave) shape of a production possibilities frontier
question.a: A) is due to the equal usefulness of resources in all activities.
question.b: B) is due to capital accumulation.
question.c: C) is due to technological change.
question.d: D) reflects the existence of increasing opportunity cost.
question.e: E) reflects the existence of decreasing opportunity cost.

question.q: 26) If opportunity costs are increasing, then the production possibilities frontier
question.a: A) will be bowed out and have a positive slope.
question.c: C) will be linear and have a negative slope.
question.d: D) will be bowed out and have a negative slope.
question.e: E) reflects the fact that available resources are equally useful in all production activities.

question.q: 27) The fact that resources are not equally productive in all activities
question.a: A) implies that a production possibilities frontier will be bowed outward.
question.b: B) implies that gains from specialization and trade are unlikely.
question.c: C) follows from the law of demand.
question.d: D) implies a linear production possibilities frontier.
question.e: E) implies that an economy should not produce certain goods.

question.q: 28) If additional units of any good could be produced at a constant opportunity cost, the production possibilities frontier would be
question.c: C) positively sloped.
question.d: D) negatively sloped.

question.q: 29) The existence of increasing opportunity cost
question.a: A) explains why specialization is frequently useful.
question.b: B) explains why resources are scarce.
question.c: C) explains the bowed-out shape of the production possibilities frontier.
question.d: D) follows from the existence of property rights.
question.e: E) explains why some societies produce inside their production possibilities frontier.

question.q: 30) Refer to the production possibilities frontier in Figure 2.1.2. If 6 units of X are currently being produced, then
question.a: A) 40 units of Y cannot be produced unless production of X is decreased.
question.b: B) 40 units of Y cannot be produced unless production of X is increased.
question.c: C) 60 units of Y can be produced with some resources not fully used.
question.d: D) 50 units of Y must be produced, regardless of resource utilization.
question.e: E) 50 units of Y can be produced if all resources are used and assigned to the task for which they are the best match.

question.q: 31) Refer to the production possibilities frontier in Figure 2.1.2. Suppose that 50 units of Y are currently being produced. Then
question.a: A) 7 units of X are being produced.
question.b: B) 6 units of X can be produced if all resources are used and assigned to the task for which they are the best match.
question.c: C) 9 units of X can be produced if all resources are used and assigned to the task for which they are the best match.
question.d: D) resources are not being fully utilized.
question.e: E) 6 units of X are being produced.

question.q: 32) Refer to the production possibilities frontier in Figure 2.1.2. At point A, the opportunity cost of producing 3 more units of X
question.c: C) is 20 units of Y.
question.d: D) is 10 units of Y.
question.e: E) cannot be determined from the diagram.

question.q: 33) Refer to the production possibilities frontier in Figure 2.1.2. At point A, the opportunity cost of increasing production of Y to 80 units is
question.c: C) 2 units of X.
question.d: D) 3 units of X.

question.q: 34) Refer to the production possibilities frontier in Figure 2.1.2. At point C, the opportunity cost of producing one more unit of X is
question.c: C) 8 units of X.
question.d: D) 20 units of X.

question.q: 35) Refer to the production possibilities frontier in Figure 2.1.2. At point C, what is the opportunity cost of increasing the production of Y from 20 to 50 units?
question.c: C) 8 units of X
question.d: D) 20 units of Y

question.q: 36) Consider the production possibilities frontier in Figure 2.1.2, and assume that everything that is produced is also consumed. Which of the following statements is false?
question.a: A) Resources are not equally useful in all activities.
question.b: B) Points inside the frontier indicate unused or misallocated resources.
question.c: C) Starting at point A, an increase in the production of Y will shift the frontier outward.
question.d: D) The opportunity cost of producing Y increases as production of Y increases.
question.e: E) The opportunity cost of producing X increases as production of X increases.

question.q: 37) As we increase the production of X, we find we must give up larger and larger amounts of Y per unit of X. Select the best statement.
question.a: A) This illustrates increasing opportunity cost.
question.b: B) As a result, we should not specialize in the production of X.
question.c: C) The production possibilities frontier for X and Y is a straight line.
question.d: D) Good Y will be more highly regarded by consumers than good X.
question.e: E) We must be inside the production possibilities frontier.

question.q: 38) Figure 2.1.3 illustrates Mary's production possibilities frontier. If Mary wants to move from point B to point C,
question.a: A) it will be necessary to improve technology.
question.b: B) it will be necessary to increase the accumulation of capital.
question.c: C) it will be necessary to give up some of good X to obtain more of good Y.
question.d: D) it will be necessary to give up some of good Y to obtain more of good X.
question.e: E) she can accomplish this without any opportunity cost.

question.q: 39) Figure 2.1.3 illustrates Mary's production possibilities frontier. If Mary wants to move from point D to point C,
question.a: A) it will be necessary to improve technology.
question.b: B) it will be necessary to increase the accumulation of capital.
question.c: C) it will be necessary to give up some of good X to obtain more of good Y.
question.d: D) it will be necessary to give up some of good Y to obtain more of good X.
question.e: E) she can accomplish this without any opportunity cost.

question.q: 40) Refer to the production possibilities frontier in Figure 2.1.3. The opportunity cost of moving from C to B will be
question.a: A) greater than moving from D to C but less than moving from B to A.
question.b: B) less than moving from D to C but greater than moving from B to A.
question.c: C) the same as moving from D to C or moving from B to A.
question.d: D) greater than moving either from D to C or from B to A.
question.e: E) neither greater than moving from D to C nor moving from B to A.

question.q: 41) Refer to the production possibilities frontier in Figure 2.1.3. The fact that less of X must be given up when moving from D to C than when moving from B to A indicates
question.c: C) comparative advantage in the production of X.
question.d: D) the consequences of technological improvement.

question.q: 42) Refer to Table 2.1.1. What does point C mean?
question.a: A) If 8 units of X are produced, then at least 28 units of Y can be produced.
question.b: B) If 8 units of X are produced, then at most 28 units of Y can be produced.
question.c: C) If 28 units of Y are produced, then more than 8 units of X can be produced.
question.d: D) If 8 units of X are produced, then only 36 units of Y can be produced.
question.e: E) There is unemployment at this point.

question.q: 43) Refer to Table 2.1.1. The opportunity cost of increasing the production of X from 8 to 12 units is
question.c: C) 8 units of Y.
question.d: D) 12 units of Y.

question.q: 44) Refer to Table 2.1.1. The opportunity cost of increasing the production of Y from 16 to 36 units is
question.c: C) 12 units of X.
question.d: D) 16 units of X.

question.q: 45) The economy illustrated by the data in Table 2.1.1 exhibits
question.b: B) constant opportunity cost in the production of X.
question.c: C) constant opportunity cost in the production of Y.
question.d: D) increasing opportunity cost.
question.e: E) initially increasing, then decreasing opportunity cost.

question.q: 46) From the data in Table 2.1.1, the production of 7 units of X and 28 units of Y is
question.b: B) attainable but leaves some resources unused or misallocated or both.
question.c: C) on the PPF between points C and D.
question.d: D) on the PPF between points B and C.

question.q: 47) Refer to Table 2.1.1. As we increase the production of X,
question.a: A) the amount of Y that is given up for each additional unit of X decreases.
question.b: B) the output of Y increases.
question.c: C) the opportunity cost of each additional unit of X increases.
question.d: D) unemployment increases.
question.e: E) the amount of X increases at an increasing rate.

question.q: 48) From the data in Table 2.1.1 we can infer that
question.a: A) the economy illustrated has a comparative advantage in the production of Y.
question.b: B) the economy illustrated has a comparative advantage in the production of X.
question.c: C) the opportunity cost of producing an additional unit of Y increases as the production of Y increases.
question.d: D) the opportunity cost of producing an additional unit of Y decreases as the production of Y increases.

question.q: 49) The diagram of the production possibilities frontier corresponding to the data in Table 2.1.1 would be
question.b: B) negatively sloped and bowed inward.
question.c: C) negatively sloped and bowed outward.
question.d: D) positively sloped for X and negatively sloped for Y.

question.b: B) attainable but leaves some resources misallocated.
question.c: C) on the production possibilities frontier between points C and D.
question.d: D) inside the PPF.
question.e: E) possible if we reduce the amount of capital goods.

question.c: C) 6 kilograms of butter.
question.d: D) 1/6 kilogram of butter.

question.q: 52) Refer to Table 2.1.2. According to this production possibilities frontier,
question.a: A) a combination of 6 kilograms of butter and 1 gun leaves some resources unused.
question.b: B) a combination of 0 butter and 4 guns is attainable.
question.c: C) resources are equally useful in all activities.
question.d: D) the opportunity cost of producing guns increases as more guns are produced.
question.e: E) the opportunity cost of producing guns decreases as more guns are produced.

question.q: 53) Refer to Table 2.1.3. In moving from combination C to combination B, the opportunity cost of producing one additional hockey stick is
question.c: C) 6 maple leaves.
question.d: D) 1/6 maple leaves.

question.q: 54) Refer to Table 2.1.4. Complete the following sentence. The production possibilities frontier in the table shows
question.c: C) constant opportunity cost.
question.d: D) under-utilization of resources.

question.q: 55) The slope of the production possibilities frontier curve indicates
question.c: C) absolute advantage.
question.d: D) marginal benefit.

question.q: 56) As we move down the bowed-out production possibilities frontier, opportunity cost
question.c: C) remains constant.
question.d: D) initially decreases, then increases.
question.e: E) decreases but at an increasing rate.

question.c: C) C
question.d: D) D

question.c: C) a decreasing; an increasing
question.d: D) an increasing; an increasing

question.q: 59) Figure 2.1.6 shows the production possibilities frontier for a firm that produces pet food. Point A is ________ and point B is ________. This PPF ________ illustrate scarcity because ________.
question.a: A) unattainable; attainable; does; because the firm cannot attain the points outside the frontier
question.b: B) attainable; unattainable; does not; the firm can produce any quantity it wants if it is willing to pay a high enough price
question.c: C) unattainable; attainable; does not; the firm can produce any quantity it wants if it is willing to pay a high enough price
question.d: D) attainable; unattainable; does; the firm cannot produce points outside the frontier and as the firm moves along the PPF, it cannot produce more dog biscuits without producing less cat food
question.e: E) attainable; unattainable; does not; it is downward sloping

question.a: A) our choice of goods to produce can be either on or inside the production possibilities frontier
question.b: B) we can satisfy all our wants

question.d: D) we face a tradeoff and incur an opportunity cost
question.e: E) resources are either unused or misallocated

question.c: C) her PPF becomes straighter
question.d: D) the world PPF shifts outward
question.e: E) her PPF does not change

question.a: A) is the opportunity cost of producing one more unit of a good or service.
question.b: B) is unrelated to the production possibilities frontier.
question.c: C) always equals marginal benefit.
question.d: D) remains constant.
question.e: E) is always greater then marginal benefit.

question.a: A) a pair of shoes decreases.
question.b: B) a pair of shoes increases.
question.c: C) a shirt remains constant.
question.d: D) a shirt increases or decreases but we don't know for sure.
question.e: E) a pair of shoes and a shirt is equal at the midpoint between the x-axis and the y-axis.

question.q: 3) Which of the following is true regarding marginal benefit?
question.c: C) I and III
question.d: D) III only

question.q: 4) To describe preferences, economists use the concept of
question.c: C) marginal benefit.
question.d: D) marginal cost.

question.q: 5) Complete the following sentence. As you consume more and more of a good,
question.c: C) marginal benefit always equals marginal cost.
question.d: D) marginal benefit increases or decreases depending on where you are on the production possibilities frontier.
question.e: E) the price of the good falls.

question.q: 6) The marginal benefit curve for a good
question.a: A) shows the benefit a firm receives from producing one more unit of that good.
question.b: B) shows the most a consumer is willing to pay for one more unit of that good.
question.c: C) is upward-sloping.
question.d: D) is bowed outward.

question.a: A) the bottles of pop that people are willing to forgo to get another bicycle.
question.b: B) the bicycles that people are willing to forgo to get another bottle of pop.
question.c: C) the bottles of pop that people must forgo to get another bicycle.
question.d: D) that the benefits of producing more bicycles is greater than the benefits of producing more pop.
question.e: E) that the benefits of producing more pop is greater than the benefits of producing more bicycles.

question.q: 8) In Figure 2.2.1, when 2,000 bicycles are produced each month
question.a: A) the marginal benefit from another bicycle is greater than the marginal cost of another bicycle.
question.b: B) more bicycles must be produced to reach the efficient level of output.
question.c: C) fewer bicycles must be produced to reach the efficient level of output.
question.d: D) the economy is efficient at this level of production of bicycles.

question.q: 9) In Figure 2.2.1, the curve labelled A is the ________ curve and the curve labelled B is the ________ curve.
question.c: C) marginal benefit; trade
question.d: D) production possibilities; trade

question.q: 10) In Figure 2.2.1, when 4,000 bicycles are produced each month
question.a: A) the marginal benefit from another bicycle is greater than the marginal cost of another bicycle.
question.b: B) more bicycles must be produced to reach the efficient level of output.
question.c: C) fewer bicycles must be produced to reach the efficient level of output.
question.d: D) the economy is very efficient at this level of production of bicycles.

question.q: 11) A marginal benefit curve measures
question.c: C) absolute advantage.
question.d: D) opportunity cost.

question.q: 12) Allocative efficiency refers to a situation where
question.b: B) we cannot produce more of any one good without giving up some other good.
question.c: C) goods and services are produced at the lowest possible cost and in the quantities that provide the greatest possible benefit.
question.d: D) opportunity cost is zero.

question.q: 13) As production of food increases, marginal benefit from food
question.a: A) increases and marginal cost increases.
question.b: B) increases and marginal cost decreases.
question.c: C) decreases and marginal cost increases.
question.d: D) decreases and marginal cost decreases.
question.e: E) decreases and marginal cost is zero.

question.q: 14) Suppose the production possibilities frontier for skirts and pants is a straight line. As the production of skirts increases, the marginal benefit from skirts
question.a: A) increases and marginal cost is constant.
question.b: B) is constant and marginal cost decreases.
question.c: C) decreases and marginal cost increases.
question.d: D) decreases and marginal cost decreases.
question.e: E) decreases and marginal cost is constant.

question.q: 15) With allocative efficiency, for each good produced,
question.a: A) marginal benefit equals marginal cost.
question.b: B) marginal benefit is at its maximum.
question.c: C) marginal benefit exceeds marginal cost by as much as possible.
question.d: D) marginal cost exceeds marginal benefit by as much as possible.
question.e: E) marginal cost is at its minimum.

question.q: 16) Marginal benefit from a good or service is the benefit received from consuming ________. It is measured by the most that people are willing to pay for ________.
question.a: A) goods that you prefer; an additional unit of it
question.b: B) goods that you prefer; more of it
question.c: C) one more unit of it; an additional unit of it
question.d: D) one more unit of it; more of it
question.e: E) as much as is available; the total amount consumed

question.q: 17) Refer to Table 2.2.1. Marginal benefit from food crops
question.a: A) equals the marginal cost of food crops.
question.b: B) remains constant as the quantity of food crops increases from 1 tonne a day to 2 tonnes a day.
question.c: C) cannot be calculated from the table.
question.d: D) increases as the quantity of food crops increases from 1 tonne a day to 2 tonnes a day.

question.q: 18) The principle of decreasing marginal benefit implies that the ________.
question.a: A) additional benefit from obtaining one more unit of a good or service decreases as more of that good or service is consumed
question.b: B) additional benefit from obtaining one more unit of a good or service increases as more of that good or service is consumed
question.c: C) total benefit from obtaining more of a good or service decreases as more is consumed
question.d: D) total benefit from obtaining more of a good or service remains the same as more is consumed
question.e: E) additional benefit from producing one more unit of a good or service decreases as more of that good or service is produced

question.q: 19) The most anyone is willing to pay for another purse is $30. Currently the price of a purse is $40, and the cost of producing another purse is $50. The marginal benefit from a purse is ________.
1) A technological improvement is represented by
question.a: A) an outward shift of the production possibilities frontier.
question.b: B) a movement along the production possibilities frontier.
question.c: C) a point inside the production possibilities frontier.
question.d: D) a point outside the production possibilities frontier.
question.e: E) a movement from a point inside the production possibilities frontier to a point on the production possibilities frontier.

question.q: 2) In general, if country A is accumulating capital at a faster rate than country B, then country A
question.a: A) will soon have a comparative advantage in the production of most goods.
question.b: B) is using a larger proportion of resources to produce consumption goods.
question.c: C) will have a production possibilities frontier that is shifting out faster than country B's.
question.d: D) will have a higher rate of inflation than country B.
question.e: E) will have more unemployment than country B.

question.q: 3) The principal reason that production possibilities have grown more rapidly in Hong Kong than in Canada over the last 50 years is because
question.a: A) of cheap Hong Kong labour.
question.b: B) of foreign aid to Hong Kong.
question.c: C) Hong Kong has fewer workers.
question.d: D) Hong Kong has more natural resources.
question.e: E) Hong Kong has devoted a larger proportion of its resources to capital accumulation.

question.q: 4) Which one of the following would cause a production possibilities frontier to shift outward?
question.a: A) an increase in the stock of capital
question.b: B) an increase in the production of consumption goods
question.c: C) bad weather
question.d: D) a decision to fully utilize unemployed resources
question.e: E) a decrease in the population

question.q: 5) The development of new goods and better ways of producing goods and services is
question.c: C) the big tradeoff.
question.d: D) allocative efficiency.

question.q: 6) The growth of capital resources, including human capital is
question.c: C) depreciation.
question.d: D) opportunity cost.

question.q: 7) Which one of the following would likely shift a production possibilities frontier inward?
question.c: C) a decrease in the price of natural resources.
question.d: D) all of the above
question.e: E) None of the above, because production possibilities frontiers do not shift inward.

question.q: 8) Refer to the production possibilities frontier in Figure 2.3.1. The production possibilities frontier will shift rightward most rapidly if current production is at
question.c: C) C.
question.d: D) D.

question.q: 9) A production possibilities frontier will shift outward FOR ALL OF THE FOLLOWING REASONS EXCEPT
question.b: B) an increase in the stock of capital.
question.c: C) an increase in the labour force.
question.d: D) opportunity cost is increasing.

question.q: 10) A movement along the production possibilities frontier will result from
question.b: B) change in the stock of capital.
question.c: C) change in the labour force.
question.d: D) all of the above.

question.q: 11) The opportunity cost of pushing the production possibilities frontier outward is
question.c: C) reduced current consumption.
question.d: D) the gain in future consumption.

question.q: 12) In general, the higher the proportion of resources devoted to technological research in an economy, the
question.a: A) greater will be current consumption.
question.b: B) faster the production possibilities frontier will shift outward.
question.c: C) faster the production possibilities frontier will shift inward.
question.d: D) closer it will come to having a comparative advantage in the production of all goods.
question.e: E) more bowed out will be the shape of the production possibilities frontier.

question.q: 13) Consider a country that has two industries. In the north, they grow wild rice, which requires a lot of rainfall. In the south, they grow wheat, which requires just a moderate amount of rainfall (too much rainfall is bad for wheat production). One year, there is a record rainfall. This will result in
question.a: A) a parallel shift inward of the production possibilities frontier.
question.b: B) a parallel shift outward of the production possibilities frontier.
question.c: C) the production possibilities frontier swiveling, with the wild rice intercept increasing, and the wheat intercept decreasing.

question.d: D) There would be a movement along the existing production possibilities frontier towards a more capital-intensive point.
question.e: E) There would be a movement from the existing production possibilities frontier inwards towards a point with unused or misallocated resources.

question.a: A) movement from the existing production possibilities frontier to a point inside the production possibilities frontier.
question.b: B) shift inward of the existing production possibilities frontier and production at a point on the new PPF.
question.c: C) shift outward of the existing production possibilities frontier.
question.d: D) movement along the existing production possibilities frontier to a point of less fish production.
question.e: E) shift inward of the existing production possibilities frontier plus a movement to a point inside the new production possibilities frontier.

question.q: 16) Which of the following quotations illustrates economic growth?
question.a: A) "The firm should lower the price it charges for widgets and gadgets."
question.b: B) "The firm should sell more gadgets, even if it means less widget sales."
question.c: C) "The more and more gadgets the firm produces, the bigger the fall in widget production."
question.d: D) "If the firm invests more in capital equipment, it can expand production next year."
question.e: E) "The firm has been able to lower costs due to its extensive experience in building widgets."

question.q: 17) Economic growth ________ overcome scarcity because ________.
question.a: A) does; with economic growth the PPF rotates outward and eventually becomes a horizontal line
question.b: B) does; we will eventually reach the point where we have too much
question.c: C) does not; we can produce more goods and services but it is still impossible to satisfy all our wants
question.d: D) does not; economic growth requires capital accumulation and technological change
question.e: E) does; with economic growth the PPF rotates outward and eventually becomes a vertical line

question.q: 18) In 1960, the production possibilities per person in Canada were ________ than those in Hong Kong. Canada devoted ________ of its resources to accumulating capital and the remainder to consumption. Hong Kong devoted ________ of its resources to accumulating capital and the remainder to consumption. Because Hong Kong devoted a ________ fraction of its resources to accumulating capital, its production possibilities have ________.
question.a: A) smaller; one-fifth; one-third; greater; expanded more quickly
question.b: B) smaller; one-third; one-fifth; smaller; not expanded as quickly
question.c: C) greater; one-third; one-fifth; smaller; not expanded as quickly
question.d: D) greater; one-fifth; one-third; greater; expanded more quickly
question.e: E) greater; one-half; one-quarter; smaller; not expanded as quickly

question.q: 19) The production possibilities frontier shifts outward when ________.
question.b: B) the quantity of money in the economy grows
question.c: C) prices rise
question.d: D) human capital accumulates
question.e: E) the political party in power changes

question.q: 20) Consider a production possibilities frontier with corn production measured on the vertical axis and car production measured on the horizontal axis. Unusually good weather for growing corn shifts ________.
question.a: A) the horizontal intercept of the PPF rightward and the vertical intercept of the PPF upward
question.b: B) the horizontal intercept of the PPF rightward but does not shift the vertical intercept of the PPF
question.c: C) the vertical intercept of the PPF upward but does not shift the horizontal intercept of the PPF
question.d: D) neither the horizontal intercept nor the vertical intercept of the PPF
question.e: E) the vertical intercept of the PPF downward and the horizontal intercept of the PPF leftward

question.q: 1) Individuals A and B can both produce good X. We say that A has a comparative advantage in the production of good X if
question.a: A) A has a lower opportunity cost of producing X than B.
question.b: B) A has a higher opportunity cost of producing X than B.
question.c: C) A can produce more units of X in a given time period than B.
question.d: D) A can produce X using newer technology than B.
question.e: E) A can produce less units of X in a given time period than B.

question.q: 2) Individuals A and B can both produce goods X and Y. Individual A has a comparative advantage in the production of X if
question.a: A) A is faster than B at producing X.
question.b: B) the amount by which A must reduce production of Y is less than the amount by which B must reduce production of Y to produce an additional unit of X.
question.c: C) B has superior knowledge about how to produce X.
question.d: D) A has a preference to consume X.
question.e: E) the amount by which A must reduce production of Y is more than the amount by which B must reduce production of Y to produce an additional unit of X.

question.q: 3) Debra has an absolute advantage in producing a good when she
question.a: A) has a comparative advantage in producing that good.
question.b: B) can produce the good at lower opportunity cost than anyone else.
question.c: C) can produce more of that good than anyone else, using the same quantity of inputs.
question.d: D) has exclusive rights to sell that good.
question.e: E) has better technology than anyone else.

question.q: 4) A person who has an absolute advantage in the production of all goods will
question.a: A) also have a comparative advantage in the production of all goods.
question.b: B) not be able to gain from specialization and trade.
question.c: C) produce all goods at the lowest opportunity cost.
question.d: D) not have a comparative advantage in the production of any goods.
question.e: E) have a comparative advantage in the production of only some goods and not others.

question.q: 5) Given Fact 2.4.1, the opportunity cost of producing 1 loaf of bread is
question.a: A) 20 minutes (1/3 hour) for Andy and 1 hour for Rolfe.
question.b: B) 1/3 kilogram of butter for Andy and 1 kilogram of butter for Rolfe.
question.c: C) 3 kilograms of butter for Andy and 1 kilogram of butter for Rolfe.
question.d: D) 8 kilograms of butter for both Andy and Rolfe.
question.e: E) not calculable from the given information.

question.q: 6) From Fact 2.4.1, we know that
question.a: A) Andy has the lower opportunity cost of producing bread, while Andy and Rolfe have equal opportunity costs of producing butter.
question.b: B) Andy has the lower opportunity cost of producing both bread and butter.
question.c: C) Andy has the lower opportunity cost of producing bread, while Rolfe has the lower opportunity cost of producing butter.
question.d: D) Andy has the lower opportunity cost of producing butter, while Rolfe has the lower opportunity cost of producing bread.
question.e: E) Andy has the higher opportunity cost of producing both bread and butter.

question.q: 7) Refer to Fact 2.4.1. Which one of the following statements is true?
question.a: A) Andy has an absolute advantage in butter production.
question.b: B) Rolfe has an absolute advantage in butter production.
question.c: C) Andy has a comparative advantage in bread production.
question.d: D) Andy has a comparative advantage in butter production.
question.e: E) Rolfe has a comparative advantage in bread production.

question.q: 8) Refer to Fact 2.4.1. The opportunity cost of producing 1 kilogram of butter is
question.a: A) 20 minutes (1/3 hour) for Andy and 1 hour for Rolfe.
question.b: B) 1 hour for Andy and 1 hour for Rolfe.
question.c: C) 3 loaves of bread for Andy and 1/3 loaf of bread for Rolfe.
question.d: D) 3 loaves of bread for Andy and 1 loaf of bread for Rolfe.
question.e: E) 8 loaves of bread for Rolfe and 24 loaves of bread for Andy.

question.q: 9) Given Fact 2.4.1, Andy and Rolfe
question.a: A) can gain from trade if Andy specializes in butter production and Rolfe specializes in bread production.
question.b: B) can gain from trade if Andy specializes in bread production and Rolfe specializes in butter production.
question.c: C) cannot gain from trade.
question.d: D) can trade, but only Rolfe will gain.
question.e: E) can trade, but only Andy will gain.

question.q: 10) Consider Fact 2.4.1. After specialization, total consumption will
question.a: A) depend on the preferences of Andy and Rolfe.
question.b: B) be 8 loaves of bread and 24 kilograms of butter.
question.c: C) be 32 loaves of bread and 16 kilograms of butter.
question.d: D) be 8 loaves of bread and 8 kilograms of butter.
question.e: E) be 24 loaves of bread and 8 kilograms of butter.

question.q: 11) Refer to Fact 2.4.2. Which one of the following statements is true?
question.a: A) Brenda has an absolute advantage over Agnes in the production of both goods.
question.b: B) Agnes has a comparative advantage in the production of Y.
question.c: C) Brenda has a comparative advantage in the production of X.
question.d: D) Brenda will not gain from trade.
question.e: E) Agnes will not gain from trade.

question.q: 12) Given Fact 2.4.2, the opportunity cost of producing a unit of X is
question.a: A) 1 unit of Y for Agnes and 2 units of Y for Brenda.
question.b: B) 1 unit of Y for Agnes and 1/2 unit of Y for Brenda.
question.c: C) 1 hour for Agnes and 1/2 hour for Brenda.
question.d: D) 1 hour for Agnes and 2 hours for Brenda.
question.e: E) 1 hour for Agnes and 1/4 hour for Brenda.

question.q: 13) Given Fact 2.4.2, the opportunity cost of producing a unit of Y is
question.a: A) 1 unit of Y for Agnes and 2 units of Y for Brenda.
question.b: B) 1 unit of Y for Agnes and 1/2 unit of Y for Brenda.
question.c: C) 1 hour for Agnes and 1/2 hour for Brenda.
question.d: D) 1 hour for Agnes and 2 hours for Brenda.
question.e: E) 1 unit of X for Agnes and 1/2 unit of X for Brenda.

question.q: 14) Complete the following sentence. Given Fact 2.4.2,
question.a: A) there will be gains from trade, no matter what Brenda and Agnes specialize in, as long as they specialize.
question.b: B) there will be gains from trade only if Agnes specializes in the production of Y and Brenda in X.
question.c: C) there will be gains from trade only if Agnes becomes faster at producing X.
question.d: D) there will be no gains from trade because Agnes has an absolute advantage.
question.e: E) there will be gains from trade if Agnes specializes in the production of X and Brenda in Y.

question.q: 15) Given Fact 2.4.2, what would be the total output of X and Y in an eight-hour day if Agnes and Brenda each specialized in producing the good in which they have a comparative advantage?
question.a: A) 3 units of X and 5 units of Y
question.b: B) 8 units of X and 16 units of Y
question.c: C) 8 units of X and 32 units of Y
question.d: D) 24 units of X and 40 units of Y
question.e: E) 16 units of X and 8 units of Y

question.q: 16) Any two individuals will gain from exchange
question.a: A) unless one has an absolute advantage in producing all goods.
question.b: B) if each specializes in the production of the good for which he has the higher opportunity cost.
question.c: C) unless they have the same opportunity costs for producing all goods.
question.d: D) unless they have different opportunity costs for producing all goods.
question.e: E) unless they have the same absolute advantage in producing all goods.

question.q: 17) Refer to Table 2.4.1. Which one of the following is true?
question.a: A) Romulus has both an absolute advantage and a comparative advantage in the production of Y.
question.b: B) Romulus has both an absolute advantage and a comparative advantage in the production of X.
question.c: C) Vulcan has a comparative advantage in the production of X.
question.d: D) Romulus has a comparative advantage in the production of X.
question.e: E) Vulcan should specialize in the production of X.

question.q: 18) Refer to Table 2.4.1. Which one of the following is true?
question.a: A) The opportunity cost of producing more of good X is the same for both planets.
question.b: B) The opportunity cost of producing more of good Y is the same for both planets.
question.c: C) The opportunity cost of producing more of good X is lower in Vulcan.
question.d: D) The opportunity cost of producing more of good Y is lower in Vulcan.
question.e: E) Vulcans are smarter than Romulans.

question.q: 19) Refer to Table 2.4.1. For Vulcan, the opportunity cost of producing an additional unit of X is
question.c: C) 2/3 units of Y.
question.d: D) 1 unit of Y.
question.e: E) dependent upon how many units of X are already produced.

question.q: 20) Refer to Table 2.4.1. For Romulus, the opportunity cost of producing an additional unit of X is
question.c: C) 2/3 units of Y.
question.d: D) 1 unit of Y.

question.q: 21) Refer to Table 2.4.1. For Romulus, the opportunity cost of producing an additional unit of Y is
question.c: C) 2 units of X.
question.d: D) 3 units of X.

question.q: 22) Refer to Table 2.4.1. For Vulcan, the opportunity cost of producing an additional unit of Y is
question.c: C) 2 units of X.
question.d: D) 3 units of X.

question.q: 23) Refer to Table 2.4.1. Each country will gain from trade if
question.a: A) Romulus specializes in both goods.
question.b: B) Vulcan specializes in both goods.
question.c: C) they both continue to produce both goods.
question.d: D) Vulcan specializes in good X and Romulus specializes in good Y.
question.e: E) Romulus specializes in good X and Vulcan specializes in good Y.

question.q: 24) If individuals A and B can both produce only goods X and Y and A does not have a comparative advantage in the production of either X or Y, then we know
question.a: A) B has an absolute advantage in the production of X and Y.
question.b: B) A and B have the same opportunity costs for X and for Y.
question.c: C) B has a comparative advantage in the production of both X and Y.
question.d: D) the gains from trade will be large but only in one direction.
question.e: E) A must have lower opportunity costs of production for both goods.

question.q: 25) Consider the following household. In 5 hours, Bob can cook 5 meals or clean 6 rooms. In 5 hours, Mary can cook 30 meals or clean 10 rooms. Select the best statement.
question.a: A) Bob has an absolute advantage in the production of both goods.
question.b: B) Since Mary is better at producing both goods, she should produce both.
question.c: C) Bob has a comparative advantage in cooking.
question.d: D) Mary should specialize in cooking.

question.q: 26) Given the information in Table 2.4.2, can Sheila and Bruce gain by specialization?
question.a: A) Yes, but only if Bruce gets paid more than Sheila.
question.b: B) No, not under the given circumstances.
question.c: C) It depends on the wages each earns.
question.d: D) Only if they are married to each other.
question.e: E) Yes, if each specializes in the good in which he has a comparative advantage.

question.q: 27) Given the information in Table 2.4.2, which one of the following is true?
question.a: A) Sheila should specialize in good X.
question.b: B) Bruce should specialize in good X.
question.c: C) The opportunity cost to Bruce of an additional unit of X is 0.4 units of Y.
question.d: D) A and B.

question.q: 28) Suppose John and Joe each have different production possibility frontiers; John specializes in cloth and Joe specializes in corn. John's island unexpectedly has exceptionally good weather, and suddenly he is twice as productive in the production of both corn and cloth. Select the best statement.
question.a: A) This is an example of unemployed resources becoming employed.
question.b: B) As a result, John will have an absolute advantage in both corn and cloth.
question.c: C) As a result, it is possible that John and Joe will switch what they specialize in.
question.d: D) There will be no change in what John and Joe specialize in, because John's comparative advantage has not changed.
question.e: E) There will be a change in what John and Joe specialize in, because John's opportunity cost of production will have risen.

question.q: 29) It pays for people to specialize and trade with each other because
question.a: A) otherwise they would not survive.
question.b: B) they can take advantage of the fact they have an absolute advantage in the production of something.
question.c: C) this way they can consume outside their production possibilities frontier.
question.d: D) this way the strong can exploit the weak.

question.q: 30) There are two goods, X and Y. If the opportunity cost of producing good X is lower for Pam than for Gino, then
question.a: A) Pam has an absolute advantage in the production of X.
question.b: B) Gino has an absolute advantage in the production of Y.
question.c: C) Pam has a comparative advantage in the production of X.
question.d: D) Gino has a comparative advantage in the production of Y.

question.q: 31) Mexico and Canada produce both oil and apples using labour only. A barrel of oil is produced with 4 hours of labour in Mexico and 8 hours of labour in Canada. A bushel of apples is produced with 8 hours of labour in Mexico and 12 hours of labour in Canada. Canada has
question.a: A) an absolute advantage in oil production.
question.b: B) an absolute advantage in apple production.
question.c: C) a comparative advantage in oil production.
question.d: D) a comparative advantage in apple production.

question.q: 32) In Portugal, the opportunity cost of a bale of wool is 3 bottles of wine. In England, the opportunity cost of 1 bottle of wine is 3 bales of wool. Given this information,
question.a: A) England has an absolute advantage in wine production.
question.b: B) Portugal has an absolute advantage in wool production.
question.c: C) Portugal has a comparative advantage in wine production.
question.d: D) Portugal has a comparative advantage in wool production.

question.q: 33) To gain from comparative advantage, countries must not only trade, they must also
question.c: C) engage in research and development.
question.d: D) engage in capital accumulation.

question.q: 34) In one hour, Sue can produce 50 caps or 10 jackets and Tessa can produce 70 caps or 7 jackets. Sue's opportunity cost of producing a cap is ________ jackets and Tessa's opportunity cost of producing a cap is ________ jackets.
question.a: A) 0.2; 0.10; Sue; Tessa gains but Sue loses
question.b: B) 5.0; 10.0; Tessa; Sue loses but Tessa gains
question.c: C) 5.0; 10.0; Sue; both Sue and Tessa gain
question.d: D) 0.2; 0.10; Tessa; both Sue and Tessa gain
question.e: E) 0.2; 0.10; Sue; both Sue and Tessa gain

question.q: 35) Tom takes 20 minutes to cook an egg and 5 minutes to make a sandwich. Jerry takes 15 minutes to cook an egg and 3 minutes to make a sandwich. If Tom and Jerry specialize and trade eggs and sandwiches with each other ________.
question.a: A) Tom benefits but Jerry does not
question.b: B) Jerry benefits but Tom does not
question.c: C) neither Tom nor Jerry benefit
question.d: D) either Tom or Jerry benefit but we don't have enough information to know which one benefits

question.q: 36) Tom takes 20 minutes to cook an egg and 5 minutes to make a sandwich. Jerry takes 15 minutes to cook an egg and 3 minutes to make a sandwich. Both individuals gain if ________.
question.a: A) Jerry produces eggs and trades them to Tom for sandwiches
question.b: B) Jerry produces sandwiches and trades them to Tom for eggs
question.c: C) they trade with each other regardless of who produces sandwiches and who produces eggs
question.d: D) the opportunity cost of producing an egg is greater than the opportunity cost of producing a sandwich
question.e: E) the opportunity cost of producing a sandwich is greater than the opportunity cost of producing an egg

question.c: C) money.

question.q: 2) Markets
