question.q: 3) A property right is
question.a: A) any commodity or token that is generally acceptable as a means of payment.
question.b: B) an economic unit that hires factors of production and organizes those factors to produce and sell goods and services.
question.c: C) any arrangement that enables buyers and sellers to get information and to do business with each other.
question.d: D) a social arrangement that governs the ownership, use, and disposable of anything that people value.

question.q: 4) The flows in the market economy that go from firms to households are ________.
question.a: A) all flowing through goods markets; all flowing through factor markets
question.b: B) the real flows of goods and services and the income flows of wages, rent, interest and profits; the real flows of labour, land, capital and entrepreneurship and the flow of expenditure on goods and services
question.c: C) the income flows of wages, rent, interest, and profits and the flow of expenditure on goods and services; the real flows of goods and services and the real flows of labour, land, capital and entrepreneurship
question.d: D) the real flows of goods and services and the real flows of labour, land, capital and entrepreneurship; the income flows of wages, rent, interest, and profits and the flow of expenditure on goods and services
question.e: E) all flowing through factor markets; all flowing through goods markets

question.q: 5) The main functions of markets include
question.a: A) promoting the social interest, but not the self-interest.
question.b: B) selling goods but not factors of production.
question.c: C) enabling buyers and sellers to get information about each other.
question.d: D) establishing a physical location for business transactions.
question.e: E) promoting the self-interest but not the social interest.

question.q: 6) In an economy lacking property rights, it would be ________ to realize the gains from trade and there would be ________ specialization compared to an economy with property rights.
question.c: C) easier; less
question.d: D) easier; more

question.q: 7) Intellectual property ________.
question.b: B) includes stocks and bonds and money in the bank
question.c: C) is the intangible product of creative effort
question.d: D) is protected by copyrights and patents
question.e: E) both C and D are correct

question.q: 1) The relative price of a good is all of the following except
question.a: A) the ratio of one price to another.
question.c: C) the money price of the good divided by a price index.
question.d: D) the same as the money price of a good.

question.q: 2) How many sides does a market have?
question.c: C) two sides - buyers and sellers
question.d: D) three sides - buyers, sellers, and the government
question.e: E) two sides - domestic and foreign

question.q: 3) Which market is an example of a market for goods?
question.c: C) manufactured input market
question.d: D) apple market

question.q: 4) Which market is an example of a market for services?
question.c: C) manufactured input market
question.d: D) energy market

question.q: 5) Which market is an example of a resource market?
question.c: C) automobile market
question.d: D) haircut market

question.q: 6) The demand and supply model determines
question.c: C) supply prices.
question.d: D) demand prices.

question.c: C) fell; rose

question.q: 11) Refer to Table 3.1.1. Between 2011 and 2012, the price of coffee relative to the price of tea ________ while the price of coffee relative to the price of cola ________.
question.c: C) fell; rose
question.d: D) fell; fell

question.q: 12) A market where no single buyer or seller can influence the price is
question.c: C) a competitive market.
question.d: D) an output market.

question.q: 13) A relative price is
question.a: A) the ratio of one price to another.
question.c: C) a quantity of a "basket" of goods and services forgone.
question.d: D) determined by demand and supply.

question.q: 14) William Gregg owned a mill in South Carolina. In December 1862, he placed a notice in the Edgehill Advertister announcing his willingness to exchange cloth for food and other items. Here is an extract:
question.a: A) buy bacon and trade it for cloth because they could buy 8 yards of cloth for only $1.60, and use that cloth to obtain a bushel of salt
question.b: B) not buy bacon and trade it for cloth because they would have to buy 8 yards of cloth for $1.60 and then give Mr. Gregg an extra $0.40 to buy a bushel of salt
question.c: C) buy bacon and trade it for cloth and then trade the cloth for salt because salt is more important for life than either cloth or bacon
question.d: D) not buy bacon and trade it for cloth because the relative price of 1 bushel of salt is only 1/8 yard of cloth
question.e: E) buy bacon and trade it for cloth because cloth is more expensive than bacon

question.q: 15) The opportunity cost of good A in terms of good B is equal to the
question.a: A) money price of good A minus the money price of good B.
question.b: B) money price of good B minus the money price of good A.
question.c: C) ratio of the money price of good A to the money price of good B.
question.d: D) ratio of the money price of good B to the money price of good A.
question.e: E) money price of good A plus the money price of good B.

question.q: 16) Suppose the price of a football is $20.00 and the price of a basketball is $10.00. The ________ of a football is ________.
question.a: A) relative price; 2 basketballs per football
question.b: B) relative price; 1/2 basketball per football
question.c: C) opportunity cost; $15.00
question.d: D) opportunity cost; $10.00

question.q: 1) The law of demand states that, other things remaining the same,
question.a: A) the higher the price of a good, the smaller is the quantity demanded.
question.b: B) the higher the price of a good, the smaller is the quantity supplied.
question.c: C) price and quantity supplied are positively related.
question.d: D) as income increases, willingness to pay for the last unit increases.
question.e: E) the higher the price of a good, the greater is the quantity demanded.

question.q: 2) Which one of the following events shifts the demand curve for grape jelly to the right?
question.a: A) an increase in income if grape jelly is a normal good
question.b: B) a decrease in the price of strawberry preserves, a substitute for grape jelly
question.c: C) a decrease in the price of grape jelly
question.d: D) an increase in the price of peanut butter, a complement of grape jelly
question.e: E) a decrease in the population

question.q: 3) The demand curve slopes downward to the right because
question.a: A) an increase in income leads to increased consumption.
question.b: B) of the law of supply.
question.c: C) of the law of demand.
question.d: D) of comparative advantage.
question.e: E) as income rises, the quantity demanded increases.

question.q: 4) An increase in the price of ground beef
question.a: A) increases the demand for chicken, a substitute for ground beef.
question.b: B) increases the demand for hamburger buns, a complement of ground beef.
question.c: C) increases the quantity demanded of ground beef.
question.d: D) decreases the quantity demanded of ground beef.

question.q: 5) An increase in income
question.a: A) increases the demand for turnips if a turnip is an inferior good.
question.b: B) increases the demand for turnips if a turnip is a normal good.
question.c: C) increases the supply of turnips.
question.d: D) decreases the demand for turnips if turnips have a very low price.
question.e: E) decreases the supply of turnips.

question.q: 6) A turnip is an inferior good if
question.a: A) an increase in the price of a turnip decreases the quantity of turnips that consumers want to buy.
question.b: B) an increase in income decreases the demand for turnips.
question.c: C) an increase in income increases the demand for turnips.
question.d: D) turnips violate the law of demand.
question.e: E) turnips are a low quality good.

question.q: 7) If a turnip is an inferior good, then, ceteris paribus, an increase in the price of a turnip will
question.a: A) decrease the demand for turnips.
question.b: B) increase the demand for turnips.
question.c: C) decrease the supply of turnips.
question.d: D) increase the supply of turnips.

question.q: 8) Suppose income increases. Choose the correct statement.
question.a: A) The equilibrium price of turnips falls if a turnip is an inferior good.
question.b: B) The equilibrium price of turnips rises if a turnip is an inferior good.
question.c: C) The equilibrium quantity of turnips decreases if a turnip is an inferior good.
question.d: D) The supply of turnips decreases whether or not a turnip is an inferior good.

question.q: 9) Point A in Figure 3.2.1 indicates that
question.a: A) $1 is the least that consumers are willing to pay for the 4,000th apple.
question.b: B) consumers will not be in equilibrium if the price of an apple is $1.
question.c: C) consumers will only pay $1 for any apple.
question.d: D) if the price is $1, consumers will plan to buy 4,000 apples.
question.e: E) if the price is more than $1, consumers will buy 9,000 apples.

question.a: A) Producers would be unwilling to sell the 9,000th apple for less than $0.50.
question.b: B) The most that consumers would be willing to pay for the 9,000th apple is $0.50.
question.c: C) At a price of $0.50, consumers will be unwilling to buy any apples.
question.d: D) At a price of $0.50, there will be an apple shortage.
question.e: E) At point B, the market is in equilibrium.

question.q: 11) Given Figure 3.2.1, under what condition are consumers willing to buy more than 9,000 apples per week?
question.a: A) if the price is above $1
question.b: B) if the price is between $1 and $0.50
question.c: C) if the price is below $0.50

question.q: 17) A unit elastic demand
question.a: A) means that the ratio of a change in quantity demanded to a change in price is equal to 1.
question.b: B) means that the ratio of a percentage change in quantity demanded to a percentage change in price is equal to 1.
question.c: C) means that the ratio of a change in price to a change in quantity demanded is equal to 1.
question.d: D) is illustrated by a horizontal demand curve.
question.e: E) is illustrated by a vertical demand curve.

19) A fall in the price of a good from $11.50 to $8.50 results in an increase in the quantity demanded from 19,200 to 20,800 units. The price elasticity of demand is

question.d: D) is inelastic.
question.e: E) cannot be computed unless we know the original price and the new price.

This implies that the demand in Sackville is ________ and demand in Prince Albert is ________.
question.c: C) inelastic; elastic
question.d: D) elastic; inelastic

question.q: 23) Suppose the government of Nova Scotia wants to reduce the consumption of electricity by 5 percent. The price elasticity of demand for electricity is 0.40. You advise the Nova Scotia government to
question.a: A) raise the price of electricity by 12.5 percent.
question.b: B) raise the price of electricity by 2 percent.
question.c: C) lower the price of electricity by 12.5 percent.
question.d: D) stay away from the market for electricity and let the market mechanism fix the problem.
question.e: E) lower the price of electricity by 2 percent.

question.b: B) raise the price of a computer by 0.21 percent.
question.c: C) lower the price of a computer by 0.21 percent.
question.d: D) lower the price of a computer by 1.714 percent.
question.e: E) lower the price of a computer by 0.58 percent.

question.d: D) zero.

question.q: 26) At a price of $15, Jack's quantity demanded of good A is the same as when the price rises to $16. Jack's demand for good A is
question.c: C) perfectly elastic.
question.d: D) unit elastic.

question.q: 27) Which one of the following will yield a measured price elasticity of demand of 5.0? A 10 percent rise in price results in a
question.a: A) 10 percent decrease in quantity demanded.
question.b: B) 5 percent decrease in quantity demanded.
question.c: C) 2 percent decrease in quantity demanded.
question.d: D) 50 percent decrease in quantity demanded.
question.e: E) 0.5 percent decrease in quantity demanded.

question.e: E) demand is inelastic in this range.

question.d: D) Happy Cow brand milk at Ralph's Grocery Store in Regina

question.q: 32) For which one of the following is demand likely to be most inelastic?
question.c: C) potatoes
question.d: D) gasoline

question.c: C) longer the passage of time after a price increase.
question.d: D) fewer good substitutes that are available.
question.e: E) larger the fraction of income spent on the good.

question.q: 34) Demand will be more elastic the
question.c: C) longer the passage of time after a price increase.
question.d: D) fewer substitutes are available.
question.e: E) smaller the fraction of income spent on the good.

question.q: 35) Figure 4.1.1 illustrates a linear demand curve. Comparing the price elasticity in the $2 to $3 price range with the elasticity in the $8 to $9 range, we can conclude
question.a: A) that demand is more elastic in the $8 to $9 price range.
question.b: B) that demand is more elastic in the $2 to $3 price range.
question.c: C) that the price elasticity of demand is the same in both price ranges.
question.d: D) nothing without numerical information about quantities.
question.e: E) that the price elasticity of demand is zero in both price ranges because the demand curve is a straight-line demand curve.

question.c: C) total revenue remains unchanged.
question.d: D) total revenue initially increases then decreases.
question.e: E) total revenue initially decreases then increases.

question.c: C) total revenue remains unchanged.
question.d: D) the quantity demanded increases by more than 10 percent.
question.e: E) the percentage change in quantity demanded is more than the percentage change in price.

question.c: C) elastic.
question.d: D) perfectly elastic.

question.b: B) greater than zero but less than 1.
question.d: D) greater than 1.

question.b: B) the price of complements but not the price of substitutes.
question.c: C) income.
question.d: D) preferences.
question.e: E) the price of substitutes and complements.

question.a: A) the shorter the passage of time.

question.c: C) the harder it is to obtain good substitutes.
question.d: D) all of the above.

43) For which one of the following will demand be the most price elastic?
question.c: C) Toronto newspapers
question.d: D) The Toronto Star

question.a: A) The French wine supply will increase as price rises.
question.b: B) If the demand for French wine is elastic, wine producers will experience an increase in total revenue.
question.c: C) The initial change in the market will create a surplus of French wine.

question.b: B) decreases the quantity demanded by half.

question.d: D) decreases the quantity demanded by 2 percent.
question.e: E) increases the quantity demanded by 0.5 percent.

question.q: 47) The demand for a good will be more price inelastic,
question.a: A) the higher is its price.
question.b: B) the larger is the percentage of income spent on it.
question.c: C) the longer is the passage of time.
question.d: D) the smaller the supply of the good.
question.e: E) the fewer substitutes are available for the good.

question.q: 48) A union leader who claims that "higher wages increase living standards without causing unemployment" believes that the demand for labour is
question.c: C) perfectly elastic.
question.d: D) perfectly inelastic.

question.q: 49) Business people speak about price elasticity of demand without using the actual term. Which one of the following statements reflects elastic demand for a good?
question.a: A) "A price cut won't help me. It won't increase sales, and I'll just get less money for each unit."
question.b: B) "I don't think a price cut will make any difference to my bottom line. What I may gain from selling more I would lose on the lower price."
question.c: C) "My customers are real bargain hunters. Since I set my prices just a few cents below my competitors, customers have flocked to the store, and sales are booming."
question.d: D) "With the recent economic recovery, people have more income to spend and sales are booming, even at the previous prices."

question.q: 50) If a rise in price results in a decrease in total revenue, then the price elasticity of demand is
question.c: C) greater than zero but less than 1.
question.d: D) equal to 1.

question.q: 51) Suppose that Simon Fraser University decides to raise tuition fees to increase the total revenue it receives from students. This policy works only if the demand for a Simon Fraser University education is
question.c: C) elastic.
question.d: D) greater than the demand for a University of Western Ontario education.

question.q: 52) The demand for a good is perfectly elastic when the price elasticity of demand is
question.c: C) equal to 1.
question.d: D) between 1 and zero.

question.q: 53) When the price elasticity of demand is ________, demand for the good is perfectly inelastic.
question.c: C) equal to 1
question.d: D) between 1 and zero

question.q: 54) When the price elasticity of demand is ________, demand for the good is elastic.
question.c: C) equal to 1
question.d: D) between 1 and zero

question.q: 55) When the price elasticity of demand is ________, demand for the good is unit elastic.
question.c: C) equal to 1
question.d: D) between 1 and zero

question.c: C) equal to 1
question.d: D) between 1 and zero

question.q: 57) The price elasticity of demand for airplane travel one year in advance of the departure date is most likely to be
question.c: C) between zero and 1.
question.d: D) equal to 1.

question.q: 58) The price elasticity of demand for airplane travel one week in advance of the departure date is most likely to be
question.c: C) between zero and 1.
question.d: D) equal to 1.

question.q: 59) If a price decrease results in an increase in total revenue, then demand is
question.c: C) perfectly inelastic.
question.d: D) equal to supply.

question.q: 60) Suppose Swiss Chalet in Moncton knows that the demand for their half-chicken meals is elastic. If the manager wants to increase total revenue from half-chicken meal sales, he should
question.a: A) lower the price of a half-chicken meal.
question.b: B) not change the price of a half-chicken meal.
question.c: C) raise the price of a half-chicken meal.
question.d: D) decrease the supply of half-chicken meals.

question.q: 61) As a result of a poor growing season, the supply curve of apples shifted leftward, the equilibrium price of apples rose, and total revenue fell. This suggests that the price elasticity of demand for apples is
question.c: C) inelastic.
question.d: D) unit elastic.

question.q: 62) Suppose the Nunavut government decides to repair Iqaluit roads. One way to generate sufficient funds for this plan is to increase taxes on gasoline. The government will be able to raise total revenue from gasoline sales only if the demand for gasoline is
question.b: B) equal to the supply of gasoline.
question.c: C) unit elastic.
question.d: D) inelastic.

question.c: C) strawberry ice cream
question.d: D) a banana split made with strawberry and chocolate ice cream
question.e: E) a banana split with with Nestle strawberry and chocolate ice cream

question.c: C) unit elastic.
question.d: D) elastic.
question.e: E) elastic -- the same as your demand for all other goods.

question.q: 65) The longer the time that has elapsed since a price change the more time consumers will have to respond to price changes. As a result, demand becomes
question.c: C) more elastic.
question.d: D) perfectly inelastic.

question.a: A) The demand for gasoline will increase after consumers adjust their consumption behaviour to the new higher price.

question.c: C) Initially after the price change, the price elasticity of demand will be less elastic than it will be a few years after the price change.

question.e: E) Initially after the price change, the price elasticity of demand will be more elastic than it will be a few years after the price change.

question.q: 67) The demand for a good is price elastic if

question.b: B) a fall in price results in a decrease in total revenue.
question.c: C) a rise in price results in a decrease in total revenue.
question.d: D) the good is a necessity.
question.e: E) the demand for the good is very insensitive to changes in price.

question.a: A) a rise in price results in an increase in total revenue.
question.b: B) a rise in price results in a decrease in total revenue.
question.c: C) an increase in income results in a decrease in total revenue.
question.d: D) an increase in income results in an increase in total revenue.
question.e: E) the good is a luxury.

question.a: A) a 5 percent increase in total revenue.
question.b: B) a 5 percent decrease in total revenue.
question.c: C) no change in total revenue.
question.d: D) an increase in total revenue greater than 5 percent.
question.e: E) an increase in total revenue less than 5 percent.

question.e: E) its price falls and demand is elastic.

question.c: C) elastic.
question.d: D) inelastic.

question.a: A) if the price of A rises, we know the demand for A is elastic.
question.b: B) if the total revenue from sales of A rises, we know the demand for A is elastic.
question.c: C) if the total revenue from sales of A falls, we know the demand for A is elastic.
question.d: D) total revenue will increase because the price of A must rise.
question.e: E) total revenue must fall because the quantity bought and sold of A must fall.

question.c: C) is unit elastic.
question.d: D) has a price elasticity equal to 1/2.
question.e: E) has a price elasticity equal to 2.

question.a: A) total revenue does not change.
question.b: B) quantity demanded does not change.
question.c: C) quantity demanded falls to zero.
question.d: D) total revenue increases from zero.
question.e: E) None of the above occurs.

question.a: A) fall and total revenue increases.
question.b: B) fall and total revenue decreases.
question.c: C) rise and total revenue increases.
question.d: D) rise and total revenue decreases.
question.e: E) rise, but changes in total revenue will depend on elasticity of supply.

question.b: B) greater than zero but less than 1.
question.c: C) equal to 1.
question.d: D) greater than 1.
question.e: E) less than the elasticity of supply.

question.a: A) lower the equilibrium price but increase total consumer spending on juice.
question.b: B) decrease the equilibrium quantity and decrease total consumer spending on juice.
question.c: C) decrease both the equilibrium quantity and the price of juice.
question.d: D) raise the equilibrium price as well as total consumer spending for juice.
question.e: E) raise the equilibrium price but leave total consumer spending for juice constant.

question.a: A) Tina thinks the demand for CDs has price elasticity of demand zero and Brian thinks price elasticity of demand equals 1.
question.b: B) Tina thinks the demand for CDs has price elasticity of demand equal to 1 and Brian thinks price elasticity of demand equals zero.
question.c: C) Tina thinks the demand for CDs is price elastic and Brian thinks it is price inelastic.
question.d: D) Tina thinks the demand for CDs is price inelastic and Brian thinks it is price elastic.
question.e: E) Tina and Brian should stick to singing and forget about economics.

question.q: 79) Given the relationship shown in Figure 4.1.3 between total revenue from the sale of a good and the quantity of the good sold, then
question.a: A) this is an inferior good.
question.b: B) this is a normal good.
question.c: C) the price elasticity of demand is zero.
question.d: D) demand for this good is perfectly elastic.
question.e: E) the price elasticity of demand is 1.

question.b: B) greater than zero but less than 1.
question.c: C) equal to 1.
question.d: D) greater than 1.

question.c: C) a decrease of 40 percent.
question.d: D) an increase of 2 percent.

question.c: C) some extended period of time passes.
question.d: D) all of the above.

question.q: 83) Total revenue is more likely to rise when the price falls if

question.b: B) a low proportion of income is spent on the good.
question.c: C) some extended period of time passes.
question.d: D) all of the above.

question.c: C) upward sloping.
question.d: D) downward sloping.
question.e: E) initially upward sloping and then downward sloping.

question.c: C) perfectly elastic.
question.d: D) perfect inelastic.

question.q: 86) If the price elasticity of demand is zero, then demand is
question.c: C) perfectly inelastic.
question.d: D) perfectly elastic.

question.q: 87) Refer to Table 4.1.3. The price elasticity of demand for Jolt is
question.e: E) cannot be calculated because income is not constant.

question.a: A) more of their income on bison.

question.e: E) zero dollars on bison meat.

question.c: C) falls; rises

question.q: 90) Refer to Table 4.1.5. The demand for hotel rooms is ________ because ________.

question.e: E) inelastic; if the price is set low enough, total revenue will increase

question.c: C) 2.0; increase

question.q: 1) Consider the information in Table 4.2.1. Select the best statement.

question.a: A) price divided by the percentage change in income
question.b: B) price divided by the percentage change in quantity demanded
question.c: C) income divided by the percentage change in quantity demanded
question.d: D) quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in price
question.e: E) quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in income

question.q: 3) If the quantity of carrots demanded increases by a small percentage when income increases by a large amount, we know that the demand for carrots is
question.c: C) income inferior.
question.d: D) income elastic.

question.q: 4) If the quantity of carrots demanded increases by a large percentage when income increases by a small amount, we know that the demand for carrots is
question.c: C) income inferior.
question.d: D) income inelastic.

question.e: E) A percentage change in price will lead to a larger percentage change in quantity demanded.

question.c: C) an increase in income increases the quantity demanded at the current price.
question.d: D) an increase in income decreases the quantity demanded at the current price.

question.q: 9) Fred's income increases from $1,950 per week to $2,050 per week. As a result, he decides to increase the number of movies he attends each month by 10 percent. Fred's demand for movies is

question.c: C) many; little
question.d: D) many; lot
question.e: E) We can't determine the relative benefits from the imposition of trade barriers.

question.c: C) small; small
question.d: D) large; large

question.c: C) tariff maximization.

question.q: 28) Offshoring occurs when a firm in Canada
question.a: A) hires foreign labour and produces in other countries.

question.c: C) hires Canadian labour and produces in Canada.

question.c: C) hires Canadian labour and produces in Canada.
question.d: D) buys finished goods, components, or services from other firms in Canada.
question.e: E) Both B and D are correct.

question.q: 1) The change in total utility that results from a one-unit increase in the quantity of a good consumed is
question.c: C) average utility.

question.q: 2) Utility is
question.a: A) the value of a good.
question.b: B) the additional satisfaction received from consuming another unit of a good.
question.c: C) the benefit or satisfaction from consuming goods and services.
question.d: D) the practical usefulness of a good.
question.e: E) equal to the price of a good.

question.q: 3) Diminishing marginal utility means that
question.a: A) Ralph will enjoy his second hamburger less than the first one.

question.d: D) the utility from eating two hamburgers will be more than twice the utility from eating the first one.
question.e: E) hamburgers seem smaller as you eat more of them.

question.q: 4) As more of a good is consumed its
question.c: C) marginal utility remains unchanged.
question.d: D) total utility decreases.
question.e: E) total utility increases at an increasing rate.

question.q: 5) What is marginal utility?
question.a: A) The change in total utility divided by the price of a good.
question.b: B) The maximum amount of satisfaction from consuming a good.
question.c: C) The total satisfaction received from consuming as much of the good that is available for consumption.
question.d: D) The additional satisfaction received from consuming one more unit of a good.
question.e: E) The change in the price of a good divided by the change in total utility.

question.q: 6) John likes to eat apples, oranges, and pears. If John increases his consumption of oranges, ceteris paribus, marginal utility theory tell us that John's marginal utility of
question.c: C) pears decreases.
question.d: D) oranges remains constant.
question.e: E) oranges, apples, and pears all decrease.

question.q: 7) The fact that your fourth slice of pizza does not generate as much satisfaction as your third slice is an example of
question.c: C) diminishing marginal utility.
question.d: D) the paradox of value.

9) Refer to Table 8.1.1. The value of C is

question.d: D) decreasing when marginal utility is increasing.
question.e: E) increasing when marginal utility is positive.

question.a: A) total utility divided by price.
question.b: B) total utility divided by the total number of units consumed.
question.c: C) the slope of the total utility curve.
question.d: D) the inverse of total utility.
question.e: E) the area below the demand curve but above market price.

question.q: 12) Total utility equals
question.a: A) the sum of the marginal utilities of each unit consumed.
question.b: B) the area below the demand curve but above the market price.
question.c: C) the slope of the marginal utility curve.
question.d: D) the marginal utility of the last unit divided by price.
question.e: E) the marginal utility of the last unit consumed multiplied by the total number of units consumed.

question.b: B) decreases at an increasing rate.
question.c: C) decreases at a decreasing rate.
question.d: D) increases at an increasing rate.
question.e: E) increases at a decreasing rate.

question.q: 14) When total utility is increasing, marginal utility
question.b: B) must be between zero and one.
question.c: C) is either increasing or decreasing.
question.d: D) is either positive or negative.

question.c: C) 38 units
question.d: D) 11.5 units

question.q: 17) Table 8.1.2 gives total utilities for Jim and Sally. Which one of the following statements is true?
question.a: A) Jim has increasing marginal utility.

question.d: D) Jim and Sally receive the same marginal utility from the third unit consumed.
question.e: E) If Sally consumes 2 units, her total utility is 10 units.

question.q: 18) A budget line is drawn with
question.a: A) quantity of one good on the vertical axis and the quantity of the second good on the horizontal axis.
question.b: B) price of one good on the vertical axis and the price of the second good on the horizontal axis.
question.c: C) quantity of one good on the vertical axis and its price on the horizontal axis.
question.d: D) quantity of one good on the horizontal axis and its price on the vertical axis.
question.e: E) quantity of one good on the horizontal axis and its total utility on the vertical axis.

question.a: A) shows the limits to a household's consumption choices.
question.b: B) shows the households total utility.
question.c: C) is downward sloping because it illustrates decreasing marginal utility.
question.d: D) shows how a household’s consumption choices change as income changes.
question.e: E) Both A and D are correct.

question.a: A) have positive marginal utility and those that have negative marginal utility.
question.b: B) are available and those that are unavailable.
question.c: C) are desirable and those that are undesirable.
question.d: D) are affordable and those that are unaffordable.
question.e: E) are normal goods and those that are inferior goods.

question.q: 21) Sam buys gasoline and coffee each week. To draw his budget line for gasoline and coffee, Sam needs to know
question.a: A) if his income is expected to rise in the future.
question.b: B) if the price of gasoline is expected to rise in the future.
question.c: C) if the price of coffee is expected to fall in the future.
question.d: D) the goods that he considers to be substitutes for gasoline and for coffee.
question.e: E) how much income he has to spend and the prices of one litre of gasoline and one cup of coffee.

question.q: 1) Sarah can consume either pizzas or hamburgers. The price of a hamburger is $1 and the price of a pizza is $5. Let MUh be the marginal utility of hamburgers and MUp be the marginal utility of pizzas. In consumer equilibrium, what must the ratio MUh/MUp equal?
2) Refer to Table 8.2.1. Consider Sam's utility from sailing and skiing. If the price of sailing is $10 per hour and the price of skiing is $20 per hour, Sam will choose to spend
question.c: C) more time sailing than skiing.

question.e: E) the same amount of time sailing and skiing, since they give the same amount of utility.

question.b: B) 2 hours and ski for 4 hours.

question.q: 1) An indifference curve is
question.a: A) the boundary between what can be produced and what cannot be produced.
question.b: B) the boundary between what a consumer can afford and what he cannot afford.
question.c: C) a line that shows combinations of goods among which a consumer is indifferent.
question.d: D) the boundary between normal goods and inferior goods.
question.e: E) a line with a positive slope.

question.q: 2) A preference map is
question.a: A) a series of points that represent levels of equal satisfaction.
question.b: B) a series of demand curves.
question.c: C) a series of supply curves.
question.d: D) a map that shows contour lines.
question.e: E) a series of indifference curves.

question.q: 3) The marginal rate of substitution
question.a: A) is the amount of good Y substituted for good X as a consumer moves along his budget line.
question.b: B) is the rate at which a person gives up the good measured on the y-axis to get an additional unit of the good measured on the x-axis while remaining on the same indifference curve.
question.c: C) increases as a consumer consumes more of the good measured on the x-axis.
question.d: D) is greater than the magnitude of the slope of the budget line.
question.e: E) is equal to the slope of the budget line.

question.q: 4) Which one of the following statements is false?
question.a: A) If the indifference curve is steep, the marginal rate of substitution is high.
question.b: B) A low marginal rate of substitution implies a flat indifference curve.
question.c: C) A flat indifference curve implies a consumer must receive a large amount of good X to compensate for a small decrease in good Y.
question.d: D) A high marginal rate of substitution implies a consumer must receive a large amount of good X to compensate for a small decrease in good Y.
question.e: E) A high marginal rate of substitution implies a consumer must receive a small amount of good X to compensate for a large decrease in good Y.

question.q: 5) The magnitude of the slope of an indifference curve is
question.a: A) the marginal rate of substitution.
question.b: B) the marginal rate of transformation.
question.c: C) the marginal propensity to consume.
question.d: D) the marginal propensity to substitute.
question.e: E) the relative price of good Y.

question.q: 6) Which one of the graphs in Figure 9.2.1 shows perfect substitutes?
question.c: C) (c)
question.d: D) (d)

question.q: 7) Which of the graphs in Figure 9.2.1 shows perfect complements?
question.c: C) (c)
question.d: D) (d)

question.q: 8) A constant marginal rate of substitution between two goods implies
question.a: A) the goods are perfect complements.
question.b: B) the goods are imperfect substitutes.
question.c: C) the goods are both inferior.
question.d: D) one good is normal and one good is inferior.
question.e: E) the goods are perfect substitutes.

question.q: 9) What is a distinguishing characteristic of goods that are perfect complements?
question.c: C) L-shaped indifference curves
question.d: D) upward-sloping indifference curves
question.e: E) curved indifference curves, bowed away from the origin

question.q: 10) A consumer always has a cup of coffee with a tablespoon of sugar. What would the consumer's indifference curves for these two goods look like?
question.b: B) horizontal along the entire length
question.c: C) downward sloping with a constant slope
question.d: D) vertical along the entire length

question.q: 11) A consumer considers Coke and Pepsi to be perfect substitutes for each other. What would the consumer's indifference curves for these two goods look like?
question.b: B) horizontal along the entire length
question.c: C) vertical along the entire length
question.d: D) upward sloping
question.e: E) downward sloping with a constant slope

question.q: 12) Which one of the following statements is false?
question.a: A) Indifference curves are negatively sloped.
question.b: B) A preference map consists of a series of indifference curves.
question.c: C) Indifference curves are bowed out from the origin.
question.d: D) The marginal rate of substitution is the magnitude of the slope of an indifference curve.
question.e: E) The marginal rate of substitution increases as a consumer moves up along an indifference curve for ordinary goods.

question.q: 13) Figure 9.2.2 shows three indifference curves for Brenda. Which one of the following is not true?
question.a: A) Brenda would be equally happy consuming at either point B or point C.
question.b: B) Brenda prefers consuming at point B to consuming at point A.
question.c: C) Brenda prefers consuming at point D to consuming at either point B or point C.
question.d: D) The marginal rate of substitution is higher at point C than at point B.
question.e: E) Brenda prefers consuming at point D to consuming at point A.

question.q: 14) Good X is measured on the horizontal axis and good Y is measured on the vertical axis. The marginal rate of substitution is
question.a: A) the relative price of good X in terms of good Y.
question.b: B) the relative price of good Y in terms of good X.
question.c: C) the rate at which a consumer will give up good Y to obtain an additional unit of good X while remaining indifferent.
question.d: D) the rate at which a consumer will give up good X to obtain an additional unit of good Y while remaining indifferent.
question.e: E) equal to the magnitude of the slope of the budget line.

question.q: 15) Which one of the following statements is true about the indifference curves for two goods that are perfect substitutes?
question.a: A) The indifference curves are negatively-sloped straight lines.
question.b: B) The indifference curves are L-shaped.
question.c: C) The marginal rate of substitution is zero.
question.d: D) The indifference curves are positively-sloped straight lines.
question.e: E) The marginal rate of substitution is infinity.

question.q: 16) Which one of the following statements is true about the indifference curves for two goods that are close but not perfect substitutes?
question.a: A) The indifference curves are negatively-sloped straight lines.
question.b: B) The indifference curves are L-shaped.
question.c: C) The marginal rate of substitution is constant.
question.d: D) The marginal rate of substitution decreases as more of the good measured on the x-axis and less of the good measured on the y-axis are consumed.

question.q: 17) The shape of a person's indifference curves between two goods depends on
question.a: A) the prices of the two goods.
question.c: C) the degree of substitutability between the two goods.
question.d: D) the level of satisfaction for the person.

question.q: 18) If two goods are perfect substitutes, then their
question.a: A) indifference curves are positively-sloped straight lines.
question.b: B) indifference curves are negatively-sloped straight lines.
question.c: C) indifference curves are L-shaped.
question.d: D) marginal rate of substitution is zero.
question.e: E) marginal rate of substitution is infinity.

question.q: 19) Refer to Figure 9.2.3. Rashid buys only books and albums. The figure shows his preferences. When Rashid chooses the consumption point of 3 books and 2 albums, his marginal rate of substitution is ________.
question.c: C) 3/2 books per album
question.d: D) 2/3 books per album

question.q: 20) Refer to Figure 9.2.3. When Rashid chooses the consumption point of 2 books and 6 albums, his marginal rate of substitution is ________.
question.c: C) 3 books per album
question.d: D) 1 book per album

question.q: 21) Refer to Figure 9.2.4. Rashid buys only books and albums. The figure shows his preferences. Rashid's indifference curves ________ display diminishing marginal rate of substitution because ________.
question.a: A) do; Rashid is indifferent between consuming 6 albums and 2 books and consuming 2 albums and 3 books
question.b: B) do not; the magnitude of the slope of both indifference curves decreases as Rashid consumes more albums and fewer books
question.c: C) do not; Rashid is indifferent between consuming 6 albums and 2 books and consuming 2 albums and 3 books
question.d: D) do; the magnitude of the slope of both indifference curves decreases as Rashid consumes more albums and fewer books
question.e: E) do; the price of an album decreases as Rashid increases the quantity he buys

question.q: 22) Refer to Figure 9.2.5. The graphs show indifference curves for various goods. Graph ________ best describes the pair of goods baseballs and baseball bats. Graph ________ best describes the pair of goods desktop computers and laptop computers.
23) An indifference curve slopes downward because ________.
question.a: A) it shows that people are only happy when they increase consumption of all goods
question.b: B) it shows that when a person gives up some of good X they must increase their consumption of good Y to remain indifferent
question.c: C) it shows that when a person gives up some of good X they can afford to increase their consumption of good Y
question.d: D) it is a demand curve without prices
question.e: E) the quantity demanded increases as the price falls

question.q: 24) Which of the following statements is FALSE?
question.a: A) A consumer possesses a preference map.
question.b: B) An indifference curve is a line that shows combinations of goods among which a consumer is indifferent.
question.c: C) A consumer has only one indifference curve.
question.d: D) The marginal rate of substitution is the rate at which a consumer will give up good y to get an additional unit of good x and remain on the same indifference curve.
question.e: E) If the indifference curve is steep, the marginal rate of substitution is high.

question.q: 25) Which of the following results in a rightward shift of your indifference curves for gasoline and movie rentals?
question.a: A) an increase in the price of a litre of gasoline with no change in the price of a movie rental
question.b: B) an increase in the price of a movie rental with no change in the price of a litre of gasoline
question.c: C) an increase in income if gasoline and movie rentals are normal goods
question.d: D) a decrease in the price of a litre of gasoline or a decrease in the price of a movie rental

question.q: 26) If two consumption points are on different indifference curves, then one point is
question.a: A) a substitute for the other.
question.c: C) a complement of the other.
question.d: D) a normal good and the other point is an inferior good.
question.e: E) more expensive than the other.

question.q: 1) Leah consumes at a point on her budget line where her marginal rate of substitution is less than the magnitude of the slope of her budget line. As Leah moves towards her best affordable point, she will move to
question.c: C) a lower indifference curve.
question.d: D) a higher indifference curve.
question.e: E) a tangent point on the same indifference curve.

question.q: 2) Leah consumes at a point on her budget line where her marginal rate of substitution is less than the magnitude of the slope of her budget line. As Leah moves along her budget line toward her best affordable point, she will move
question.c: C) up and left.
question.d: D) up and right.

question.q: 3) A consumer's best affordable point occurs
question.c: C) on the budget line.
question.d: D) at a point that cannot be determined.
question.e: E) at a corner on the budget line, with only one good consumed.

question.q: 4) At the best affordable point, what is the relationship between the indifference curve and the budget line?
question.a: A) The budget line and the indifference curve are identical.
question.b: B) The slope of the indifference curve exceeds the slope of the budget line.
question.c: C) The slope of the budget line exceeds the slope of the indifference curve.
question.d: D) The slope of the indifference curve equals the slope of the budget line.

question.q: 5) Jay has an income of $10 to buy peanuts and popcorn. The price of peanuts is $1 a bag and the price of popcorn is $2 a bag. He chooses to consume 5 bags of peanuts and 2 bags of popcorn. What can we say about this consumption choice?
question.a: A) It is not the best affordable choice. He should consume more peanuts, more popcorn, or more of both.
question.b: B) It is the best affordable choice, and his marginal rate of substitution equals the slope of the budget line.
question.c: C) The consumption choice is on the budget line.
question.d: D) The consumption choice is outside the budget line.

question.q: 6) Which one of the following is true at the best affordable choice of a consumer?
question.a: A) Marginal rate of substitution exceeds the slope of the budget line.
question.b: B) Marginal rate of substitution is less than the relative price of the good measured on the x-axis.
question.c: C) All income is spent.
question.d: D) The consumption choice is outside the budget line.
question.e: E) Other consumption points along the consumer's budget line lie on higher indifference curves.

question.q: 7) At the best affordable point, which statement is true?
question.a: A) The slope of the indifference curve equals the slope of the budget line.
question.b: B) The marginal rate of substitution between two goods equals their absolute price.
question.c: C) The highest affordable indifference curve has the same intercept as the budget line.
question.d: D) Other points on the same indifference curve are affordable but not preferred.
question.e: E) Some income is not spent.

question.q: 8) Consider the budget line and indifference curve in Figure 9.3.1. If the price of good X is $1 a unit, then the price of good Y is
question.c: C) $1.25 a unit.
question.d: D) $2 a unit.

question.q: 9) Consider the budget line and indifference curve in Figure 9.3.1. At the best affordable point, the marginal rate of substitution is
10) Consider the budget line and indifference curve in Figure 9.3.1. If the price of good X is $2 a unit, what is the price of good Y?
question.c: C) $1.50 a unit
question.d: D) $2.67 a unit
question.e: E) impossible to calculate without additional information

question.q: 11) Which one of the following statements about Figure 9.3.2 is true?
question.a: A) Point S is preferred to point Q, but S is not affordable.
question.b: B) Point R is not affordable.
question.c: C) Point T is preferred to point Q, but T is not affordable.
question.d: D) Points Q and S cost the same, but Q is preferred to S.
question.e: E) Point R is the best affordable point.

question.q: 12) Peter's income increases and so does his consumption of both movies and pop, but his consumption of pop increases by less than his consumption of movies increases. Which one of the following statements is true for Peter?
question.a: A) A movie is an inferior good; pop is a normal good.
question.b: B) A movie is a normal good; pop is an inferior good.
question.c: C) A movie is an inferior good; pop is an inferior good.
question.d: D) Movies and pop are both normal goods.
question.e: E) A movie is a normal good; we cannot tell whether pop is a normal good or an inferior good.

question.q: 13) A consumer choosing between apples and oranges is at her best affordable point. Then the price of apples decreases. If both apples and oranges are normal goods, which one of the following statements is true about her new best affordable point?
question.a: A) She will consume more apples and more oranges.
question.b: B) She will consume more apples and fewer oranges.
question.c: C) She will consume fewer apples and more oranges.
question.d: D) She will consume fewer apples and fewer oranges.
question.e: E) She will consume more apples, and we cannot tell whether she will consume more or less oranges.

question.q: 14) Which statement is true for a normal good?
question.a: A) The income effect dominates the substitution effect.
question.b: B) The income effect reinforces the substitution effect.
question.c: C) As income increases, consumption decreases.
question.d: D) As income increases, consumption remains constant.
question.e: E) As price falls, we cannot tell whether consumption increases or decreases.

question.q: 15) Which statement is true for an inferior good?
question.a: A) The substitution effect is positive; as price rises, consumption increases.
question.b: B) The income effect is absent; as income increases, consumption remains constant.
question.c: C) The income effect works in the opposite direction to the substitution effect.
question.d: D) The good is of poor workmanship.
question.e: E) The income effect works in the same direction as the substitution effect.

question.q: 16) The effect of a change in income on buying plans is called the
question.c: C) normal effect.
question.d: D) inferior effect.

question.q: 17) What is the relationship between goods and the income effect?
question.a: A) An inferior good has a positive income effect.
question.b: B) A normal good has a positive income effect.
question.c: C) An inferior good has no income effect.
question.d: D) A normal good has no income effect.
question.e: E) A normal good has a negative income effect.

question.q: 18) What is a distinguishing characteristic of an inferior good?
question.c: C) a positive substitution effect
question.d: D) a negative income effect

question.q: 19) The substitution effect is the effect of
question.a: A) a change in income on the quantity bought.
question.b: B) a change in price on the quantity bought when the consumer moves to a higher indifference curve.
question.c: C) a change in income on the quantity bought when the consumer moves to a higher indifference curve.
question.d: D) a change in the best affordable point.
question.e: E) a change in price on the quantity bought when the consumer hypothetically remains on the same indifference curve.

question.q: 20) A change in the price of a good has
question.c: C) a substitution effect and an income effect.
question.d: D) an income effect that exceeds the substitution effect.
question.e: E) a substitution effect that exceeds the income effect.

question.q: 21) Suppose the price of potatoes falls and there is a decrease in the purchases of potatoes, what can we infer?
question.a: A) The income effect is negative and exceeds the substitution effect.
question.b: B) The income effect is negative and reinforces the substitution effect.
question.c: C) The income effect is positive and exceeds the substitution effect.
question.d: D) The income effect is positive and reinforces the substitution effect.
question.e: E) The income effect is negative and just about offsets the substitution effect.

question.q: 22) Which one of the following statements is always true of the substitution effect?
question.a: A) It leads to a positive income effect.
question.c: C) It decreases consumption.
question.d: D) It leads to a negative income effect.

question.q: 23) Which one of the following is always true of the price effect?
question.a: A) It leads to a positive income effect.
question.c: C) It decreases consumption.
question.d: D) It leads to a negative income effect.

question.q: 24) Which one of the following is always true of the income effect?
question.a: A) It leads to a positive income effect.
question.c: C) It decreases consumption.
question.d: D) It leads to a negative income effect.

question.q: 25) The price of a good increases relative to other goods. Which one of the following statements must be true? The resulting
question.c: C) substitution effect is negative.
question.d: D) substitution effect is positive.

question.q: 26) When the price of a good changes, the change in consumption that leaves the consumer indifferent between the two choices is called the
question.c: C) income effect.
question.d: D) price effect.

question.q: 27) If the price of a normal good rises, the income effect
question.a: A) will increase consumption of the good and the substitution effect will decrease consumption.
question.b: B) will decrease consumption of the good and the substitution effect will increase consumption.
question.c: C) and the substitution effect will both increase consumption of the good.
question.d: D) and the substitution effect will both decrease consumption of the good.
question.e: E) is always larger than the substitution effect.

question.q: 28) If the price of the good measured on the horizontal axis falls, the substitution effect is indicated by movement to a
question.c: C) steeper part of the same indifference curve.
question.d: D) flatter part of the same indifference curve.
question.e: E) flatter part of a higher indifference curve.

question.q: 29) Consider an initial budget line labelled RS in Figure 9.3.3. The budget line becomes RT with
question.a: A) a rise in the price of good X.
question.b: B) a fall in the price of good X.
question.c: C) a rise in the price of good Y.
question.d: D) a decrease in the preference for good X.
question.e: E) an increase in real income.

question.q: 30) Consider an initial budget line labelled RS in Figure 9.3.3. If the budget line becomes RT, the substitution effect is illustrated by the move from point
question.c: C) A to D.
question.d: D) B to D.

question.q: 31) Consider an initial budget line labelled RS in Figure 9.3.3. If the budget line becomes RT, the income effect is illustrated by the move from point
question.c: C) A to D.
question.d: D) B to C.

question.q: 32) Consider an initial budget line labelled RT in Figure 9.3.3. What would rotate the budget line to RS?
question.a: A) a rise in the price of good X
question.b: B) a fall in the price of good X
question.c: C) a rise in the price of good Y
question.d: D) a decrease in the preference for good X
question.e: E) an increase in real income

question.q: 33) Consider an initial budget line labelled RT in Figure 9.3.3. If the budget line becomes RS, the substitution effect is illustrated by the move from point
question.c: C) B to D.
question.d: D) B to A.

question.q: 34) Consider an initial budget line labelled RT in Figure 9.3.3. If the budget line becomes RS, the income effect is illustrated by the move from point
question.c: C) B to D.
question.d: D) C to B.

question.q: 35) If the price of an inferior good rises, the income effect
question.a: A) will have an uncertain effect on consumption of the good, and the substitution effect will decrease consumption.
question.b: B) will decrease consumption of the good, and the substitution effect will decrease consumption.
question.c: C) and the substitution effect will both increase consumption of the good.
question.d: D) and the substitution effect will both decrease consumption of the good.
question.e: E) will increase consumption of the good and the substitution effect will decrease consumption.

question.q: 36) Refer to Fact 9.3.1. Marc's initial marginal rate of substitution was
question.a: A) not calculable with the information given.
question.b: B) equal to 2 cans of root beer given up for each bag of chips gained.
question.c: C) equal to 1 can of root beer given up for each bag of chips gained.
question.d: D) equal to 10 cans of root beer given up for each bag of chips gained.
question.e: E) equal to 1/2 can of root beer given up for each bag of chips gained.

question.q: 37) Refer to Fact 9.3.1. When the price of a bag of chips falls, Marc
question.a: A) will consume more beer, more chips, and be better off.
question.b: B) will consume less beer, more chips, and be better off.
question.c: C) will consume less beer, more chips, and be worse off.
question.d: D) will consume less beer, less chips, and be worse off.
question.e: E) consume more beer, less chips, and be better off.

question.q: 38) When price rises, the substitution effect
question.b: B) increases consumption for normal goods only.
question.c: C) decreases consumption for normal goods only.
question.d: D) decreases consumption for inferior goods only.
question.e: E) does none of the above.

question.q: 39) Refer to Figure 9.3.4. Which graphs show the case where good Y is an inferior good?
question.c: C) (a) and (c)
question.d: D) (b) and (d)

question.q: 40) Refer to Figure 9.3.4. Which graphs show the case where good Y is a normal good?
question.c: C) (a) and (c)
question.d: D) (b) and (d)

question.q: 41) Karen consumes chocolate and candles. When Karen is at her best affordable point, she is ________.
question.a: A) on or inside her budget line, on her highest attainable indifference curve, and has a marginal rate of substitution between chocolate and candles that is equal to the relative price of chocolate and candles
question.b: B) on the indifference curve that is closest to the origin and minimizing the marginal rate of substitution
question.c: C) on the indifference curve that is farthest from the origin and maximizing the marginal rate of substitution
question.d: D) on her budget line, on her highest attainable indifference curve, and has a marginal rate of substitution between chocolate and candles that is equal to the relative price of chocolate and candles
question.e: E) on her budget line, on her highest attainable indifference curve, and maximizing the marginal rate of substitution

question.q: 42) The substitution effect is the effect of a change in ________ on ________. The income effect is the effect of a change in ________ on ________.
question.a: A) income; quantity bought of a substitute; income; quantity bought
question.b: B) income; consumption; price; quantity bought
question.c: C) price; quantity bought; income; quantity bought
question.d: D) the price of a substitute; quantity bought; income; the number of labour hours

question.a: A) is negative and the substitution effect is positive

question.q: 44) When Jim is at his best affordable point, the budget line
question.a: A) is steeper than the highest attainable indifference curve.
question.b: B) is flatter than the highest attainable indifference curve.
question.c: C) does not touch the highest attainable indifference curve.
question.d: D) is tangent to the highest attainable indifference curve.
question.e: E) intersects the highest attainable indifference curve.

question.q: 45) Albert is consuming at a point where his budget line is not as steep as indifference curve. To reach consumer equilibrium, Albert
question.a: A) consumes less of the good that is measured on the horizontal axis.
question.b: B) consumes none of the good that is measured on the horizontal axis.
question.c: C) must increase his income.
question.d: D) must shop at stores that have lower prices.
question.e: E) consumes more of the good that is measured on the horizontal axis.

question.q: 46) The substitution effect
question.a: A) always dominates the income effect.
question.b: B) is always dominated by the income effect.
question.c: C) results in an increase in the quantity of the good consumed when the price rises.
question.d: D) results in a decrease in the quantity of the good consumed when the price falls.
question.e: E) is greater than the price effect.

question.q: 1) A firm's goal is to
question.b: B) maximize cost while minimizing revenue.
question.c: C) maximize profit.
question.d: D) minimize costs.

question.c: C) supplied by the firm's owner.
question.d: D) bought in the market and supplied by the firm's owner.
question.e: E) bought in the market, owned by the firm, and supplied by the firm's owner.

question.a: A) is the firm's opportunity cost of using the capital it owns.
question.c: C) has two components: economic depreciation and foregone interest.
question.d: D) both A and C are correct.

question.c: C) It includes normal profit.
question.d: D) It is the amount paid for the use of land or buildings.

question.q: 6) The difference in the market value of a new car and the market value of the same car one year later is
question.c: C) economic deterioration.
question.d: D) physical deterioration.

question.q: 7) Economic depreciation is

question.c: C) the change in the market value of capital over a given period.
question.d: D) the deterioration of the physical appearance of a capital.

question.a: A) the cost of resources bought in the market.

question.a: A) cannot increase his economic profit by advertising because advertising increases his average total cost.
question.b: B) cannot increase his economic profit by advertising because advertising increases his total cost.
question.c: C) can increase his economic profit by advertising.
question.d: D) can increase his economic profit by advertising only if he raises the price of a picture frame.
question.e: E) can increase his economic profit by advertising only if he can lower his total variable cost.

question.q: 22) Firms in monopolistic competition constantly develop new products in an effort to
question.a: A) increase the demand for their product.
question.b: B) make the demand for their product unit elastic.
question.c: C) increase the marginal cost of their product.
question.d: D) decrease average total cost.

question.q: 23) Excess capacity and high advertising expenditures are encountered in
question.c: C) monopolistic competition.
question.d: D) perfect competition.

question.q: 24) Monopolistically competitive firms engaging in advertising will definitely achieve which of the following?
question.b: B) an increase in average total cost
question.c: C) an increase in total cost
question.d: D) Both B and C are correct.
question.e: E) A, B, and C are correct.

question.q: 1) The market structure in which natural or legal barriers prevent the entry of new firms and a small number of firms compete is
question.c: C) perfect competition.
question.d: D) oligopoly.

question.q: 2) Suppose that industry A consists of four firms who collectively control 96 percent of total sales in the market. We can conclude that industry A is
question.c: C) monopolistically competitive.
question.d: D) an oligopoly.

question.q: 3) Which one the following industries is the best example of an oligopoly?
question.c: C) the automobile industry
question.d: D) the clothing industry

question.q: 4) Which one of the following industries is the best example of an oligopoly?
question.c: C) the footwear industry
question.d: D) the cosmetics industry

question.q: 5) Which one of the following characteristics applies to oligopolistic markets?
question.a: A) There is a large number of firms.
question.b: B) The absence of barriers to entry of firms.
question.c: C) Firms are large relative to the size of the market.
question.d: D) All firms are price takers.
question.e: E) Firms produce only differentiated products.

question.q: 6) Which one of the following characteristics applies to oligopolistic markets?
question.a: A) There is free entry of rival firms.
question.b: B) Firms are so large relative to the market that they do not have to consider the behaviour of rival firms.
question.c: C) Firms are mutually independent because there are many firms in the industry.
question.d: D) Firms have to consider the behaviour of their rivals since their rivals are also large relative to the size of the market as a whole.
question.e: E) Economic profit of each firm equals zero.

question.q: 7) Why might only a few firms dominate an oligopolistic industry?
question.a: A) A natural or legal barrier to entry exists.
question.b: B) Perfectly elastic demand makes small-scale operation economically inefficient.
question.c: C) Decreasing returns to scale may make small-scale firms more advantageous.
question.d: D) Inelastic market demand leads to the domination of the industry by a few firms.
question.e: E) It is due to the outcome of the prisoners' dilemma.

question.q: 8) Firm X is competing in an oligopolistic industry. When firm X increases its price
question.a: A) then rival firm Y will always increase its price.
question.b: B) then rival firm Y will increase its market share if firm Y also increases its price.
question.c: C) then the behaviour of rival firm Y will have no impact on the market share of firm X.
question.d: D) the market as a whole will become less profitable.
question.e: E) the rival firm Y will increase its market share if firm Y keeps a constant price.

question.q: 9) Which is not a characteristic of oligopoly?
question.a: A) Each firm faces a downward-sloping demand curve.
question.c: C) The sales of one firm will not have a significant effect on other firms.
question.d: D) There is more than one firm in the industry.

question.q: 10) If the efficient scale of production only allows three firms to supply a market, the market is a
question.c: C) natural oligopolgy.
question.d: D) monopolistic competition.

question.q: 11) A cartel is a group of firms which agree to
question.b: B) raise the price of their products.
question.c: C) lower the price of their products.
question.d: D) increase the amount they produce.

question.q: 12) Because an oligopoly has a small number of firms
question.a: A) each firm can act like a monopoly.
question.b: B) the firms may legally form a cartel.
question.c: C) the HHI for the industry is small.
question.d: D) the four-firm concentration ratio for the industry is small.

question.q: 13) Complete the following sentence. A duopoly is
question.a: A) a market where three dominant firms collude to decide the profit-maximizing price.
question.b: B) a market where two firms compete for profit and market share.
question.c: C) the same as a monopoly.
question.d: D) not an oligopoly.
question.e: E) a market with two distinct products.

question.q: 14) A duopoly occurs when ________.
question.a: A) there are only two producers of a particular good competing in the same market
question.b: B) there are two producers of two goods competing in an oligopoly market
question.c: C) there are numerous producers of two goods competing in a competitive market
question.d: D) the one producer of two goods sells the goods in a monopoly market
question.e: E) a competitive market produces two goods

question.q: 15) Refer to Figure 15.1.1. In the scenario above, the market is:
question.b: B) A natural oligopoly with three firms
question.c: C) A natural monopoly
question.d: D) Monopolistically competitive

question.q: 16) A monopolistically competitive firm is like an oligopolistic firm insofar as
question.a: A) both face perfectly elastic demand.
question.b: B) both can earn an economic profit in the long run.
question.c: C) both have MR curves that lie beneath their demand curves.
question.d: D) neither is protected by high barriers to entry.

question.q: 17) An oligopoly is a market structure in which there
question.a: A) are a few buyers but many sellers.
question.b: B) are no barriers to entry.
question.c: C) are many independent sellers.
question.d: D) are a few goods sold by many sellers.
question.e: E) is a temptation to collude.

question.q: 18) The distinguishing features of oligopoly are ________ and ________ in the industry.
question.a: A) no barriers to entry; a small number of firms
question.b: B) barriers to entry; a large number of firms
question.c: C) no barriers to entry; a large number of firms
question.d: D) barriers to entry; one firm
question.e: E) barriers to entry; a small number of firms

question.q: 19) Oligopoly is similar to
question.a: A) perfect competition because both market types produce identical goods.
question.b: B) perfect competition because both firms in both market types make zero economic profit in the long run.
question.c: C) monopoly because both market types have barriers to entry.
question.d: D) monopoly because both market types have a single firm.
question.e: E) monopolistic competition because firms in both markets face a perfectly elastic demand.

question.q: 20) In an oligopoly market, the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index is usually
question.c: C) above 1,800.
question.d: D) equal to 10,000.

question.q: 1) All games share four common features. They are
question.a: A) costs, prices, profit, and strategies.
question.b: B) revenues, elasticity, profit, and payoffs.
question.c: C) rules, strategies, profit, and outcome.
question.d: D) patents, copyrights, barriers to entry, and rules.
question.e: E) rules, strategies, payoffs, and outcome.

question.q: 2) Prisoners' dilemma describes a case where
question.a: A) collusion of the participants leads to the best solution from their point of view.
question.b: B) rivalry among a large number of rivals leads to lower overall profit.
question.c: C) one prisoner has no chance to be acquitted since there is no other prisoner to support his testimony.
question.d: D) a prisoner has no incentive to confess to his crime, and stands a greater chance of not going to prison.
question.e: E) rivalry of the participants leads to the worst solution from their point of view.

question.q: 3) Refer to Table 15.2.1. This table includes the sentences that Bob and Joe will receive if convicted. They have been apprehended by the police under the suspicion of committing armed robbery. The two are immediately separated and questioned about the case. Which one of the following observations is correct?
question.a: A) Bob would be smart to confess no matter what Joe does.
question.b: B) Joe would be smart not to confess no matter what Bob does.
question.c: C) Both Bob and Joe would be better off not confessing if they both do not confess.
question.d: D) Both Bob and Joe would be better off "coming clean" and confessing to their crime.
question.e: E) Both Bob and Joe have a dominant strategy of not confessing.

question.q: 4) Refer to Table 15.2.1. This table includes the sentences that Bob and Joe will receive if convicted. They have been apprehended by the police under the suspicion of committing armed robbery. The two are immediately separated and questioned about the case. Which one of the following observations is correct?
question.a: A) If Joe confesses, Bob would be better off not confessing.
question.b: B) If Bob confesses, Joe would be better off confessing.
question.c: C) The outcome of the game, assuming Joe and Bob cannot collude, is they will both go free.
question.d: D) If Joe does not confess, Bob would be better off confessing.
question.e: E) The outcome of the game, assuming Joe and Bob cannot collude, is they will both confess.

question.q: 5) Which one of the following is not a feature common to all games?
question.c: C) strategies
question.d: D) payoffs

question.q: 6) In the prisoners' dilemma with players Art and Bob, each prisoner would be best off if
question.c: C) Art denies and Bob confesses.
question.d: D) Bob denies and Art confesses.
question.e: E) none of the above is done.

question.q: 7) In the prisoners' dilemma, with players Art and Bob, the dominant strategy equilibrium is that
question.c: C) Art denies and Bob confesses.
question.d: D) indeterminate.
question.e: E) Bob denies and Art confesses.

question.q: 8) A dominant strategy equilibrium occurs when
question.a: A) there is a clear strategy for each player independent of the other player's actions.
question.b: B) each player takes the best possible action given the other player's action.
question.c: C) each player complies with the collusive agreement.
question.d: D) you cooperate until the other player cheats, and then you cheat forever.

question.q: 9) A Nash equilibrium occurs when
question.a: A) there is a clear strategy for each player independent of the other player's actions.
question.b: B) each player takes the best possible action given the other player's action.
question.c: C) each player complies with the collusive agreement.
question.d: D) you cooperate until the other player cheats, and then you cheat forever.

question.q: 10) For a cartel to succeed,
question.a: A) it does not need the cooperation of a majority of firms in the industry.
question.b: B) there must be free entry of rival firms.
question.c: C) consumers must have alternative products available to satisfy the same need.
question.d: D) no major producer can remain outside the agreement of the cartel.
question.e: E) the industry must have an elastic demand.

question.q: 11) Once a cartel determines the profit-maximizing price,
question.a: A) all members of the cartel have a strong incentive to abide by the agreed-upon price.
question.b: B) each member will face the temptation to cheat on the cartel price to increase its sales and profit.
question.c: C) changes in the output of any member firms will have no impact on the market price.
question.d: D) entry into the industry of rival firms will have no impact on the profit of the cartel.
question.e: E) entry into the industry of rival firms will raise cartel profit as long as the new firms join the cartel.

question.a: A) each individual member has the incentive to restrict its own output to maximize profit.
question.b: B) the marginal cost is equal to the cartel price at the profit-maximizing output level.
question.c: C) each firm has the incentive to lower its price to sell more than the allotted amount.
question.d: D) each firm has the incentive to cheat by raising its price to maximize profit.
question.e: E) price is less than marginal cost for each member of the cartel.

question.q: 13) If there is a successful collusive agreement in a duopoly to maximize profit,
question.a: A) the market price will equal the marginal cost of production.
question.b: B) the market price will equal the average total cost of production.
question.c: C) the price will be the same as the price in a perfectly competitive market.
question.d: D) the price will be the monopoly price.
question.e: E) the market marginal revenue will be the same as the demand curve.

question.a: A) each of the duopolists has no incentive to cheat on the agreement.
question.b: B) each duopolist has the incentive to cheat on the duopoly agreement by lowering the price.
question.c: C) each duopolist has the incentive to cheat on the agreement by increasing the price to make monopoly profit.
question.d: D) there is no concern over the entrance of potential rivals, since they cannot decrease the duopolists' profit.
question.e: E) the dominant strategy is to collude.

question.a: A) each firm will produce the same amount.
question.b: B) each firm will produce its maximum output possible.
question.c: C) industry marginal revenue will equal industry marginal cost at the level of total output.
question.d: D) industry demand will equal industry marginal cost at the level of total output.

question.q: 16) The firms Trick and Gear form a cartel to collude to maximize profit. If this game is nonrepeated, the Nash equilibrium is
question.a: A) both firms cheat on the agreement.
question.b: B) both firms comply with the agreement.
question.c: C) Trick cheats, while Gear complies with the agreement.
question.d: D) Gear cheats, while Trick complies with the agreement.

20) Consider a cartel consisting of several firms that is maximizing total profit. If one firm cheats on the cartel agreement by cutting its price and increasing its output, the best response of the other firms is to

question.c: C) price exceeds marginal cost.

question.e: E) no solution can be found.

question.c: C) tit-for-tat strategy.

question.e: E) only when there is no Nash equilibrium.

question.d: D) dominant firm strategy.

question.d: D) cheats in the current period if the other player has always cheated, but cooperates forever if the other player has ever cooperated.

question.d: D) monkey-see, monkey-do strategy.
