If Andrew and Betty are the only two consumers in the economy, which point would be on the economy's marginal social benefit curve?
question.c: C) price of $10, quantity of 4
question.d: D) price of $30, quantity of 0

question.q: 6) For a private good, the economy's marginal social benefit curve is the ________ sum of the individual marginal benefit curves and for a public good, the economy's marginal social benefit curve is the ________ sum of the individual marginal benefit curves.
question.c: C) horizontal; vertical
question.d: D) horizontal; horizontal
question.e: E) horizontal and vertical; vertical and horizontal

question.q: 7) Suppose in a country there are only two persons. Person A is willing to pay $50 to have one unit of a public good produced; person B is willing to pay $60 to have one unit of a public good produced and $50 to have two units produced. A point on the country's marginal social benefit curve for this public good is a price of ________ and quantity demanded of ________.
question.c: C) $110; 2 units
question.d: D) $110; 1 unit

question.q: 8) If the marginal social cost of producing a public good is greater than the marginal social benefit, then
question.a: A) more than the efficient quantity of the public good is being produced.
question.b: B) less than the efficient quantity of the public good is being produced.
question.c: C) the efficient quantity of the public good is being produced.
question.d: D) the public good is being produced by a private firm.
question.e: E) the public good must be a common resource.

question.q: 9) Free riding can occur if a good is
question.c: C) a private good.
question.d: D) nonexcludable and rival.

question.q: 10) Private provision of public goods
question.a: A) fails because the private firm will always go broke.
question.b: B) succeeds because public provision is often more costly.
question.c: C) succeeds if consumers expect to obtain a benefit from the consumption of the public good.
question.d: D) fails because of the free-rider problem.
question.e: E) fails because private firms generally charge higher prices than public firms, and therefore lose customers.

question.q: 11) Public goods are provided by government because
question.a: A) governments are more efficient than private firms at producing public goods.
question.b: B) free-rider problems result in underproduction by private markets.
question.c: C) people value national defence very highly.
question.d: D) private firms will make an economic profit.
question.e: E) private firms do not take into account the impact of external costs.

question.q: 12) The quantity of a public good produced by private provision
question.a: A) is less than the efficient quantity.
question.b: B) is equal to the efficient quantity.
question.c: C) is greater than the efficient quantity.
question.d: D) maximizes total public benefit.

question.q: 13) Governments provide public goods such as national defence because
question.a: A) governments are more efficient than private firms at producing public goods.
question.b: B) of the free-rider problem which results in underproduction by private firms.
question.c: C) people do not value national defence very highly.
question.d: D) of the potential that private firms will make excess profit.

question.q: 14) The efficient scale of provision of a public good occurs where
question.a: A) total benefit is at a maximum.
question.b: B) total benefit is at a minimum.
question.c: C) marginal social benefit is at a maximum.
question.d: D) marginal social benefit minus marginal social cost equals zero.
question.e: E) marginal social cost is at a minimum.

question.q: 15) Public choice theory predicts that government
question.a: A) acts to promote the redistribution of wealth and income.
question.b: B) acts to maximize the amount of campaign contributions.
question.c: C) acts to eliminate waste and promote an efficient allocation of resources.
question.d: D) makes choices that result in efficient provision of public goods.
question.e: E) makes choices that result in inefficient overprovision of public goods.

question.q: 16) Public choice theory predicts that
question.a: A) voters are fully informed about the effects of policies.
question.c: C) governments make choices that achieve an efficient provision of public goods.
question.d: D) votes are based on reality, not perceptions.
question.e: E) votes are based on lobbyists' viewpoints.

question.q: 17) According to public choice theory government failure occurs because
question.a: A) government officials do not listen to the pleading of special interest groups.
question.c: C) government officials act in their own self-interest.
question.d: D) voters are fully informed about the effects of policies.
question.e: E) government cannot calculate the levels of externalities because there is no market for them.

question.q: 18) To attract a majority of voters, a political party will
question.a: A) aim its message at the most enthusiastic groups.
question.b: B) aim its message at a small but loyal following.
question.c: C) present a political package aimed at making the wealthier voters better off.
question.d: D) present a political package aimed at making a majority of voters better off.
question.e: E) respond strongest to the most vigorous lobbyists.

question.q: 19) The idea that the platforms of the political parties will tend to become similar over time is
question.a: A) not a reflection of reality.
question.b: B) true in theory but not true in actuality.
question.c: C) called the principle of minimum differentiation.
question.d: D) called the principle of minimal political confrontation.
question.e: E) the result of intense lobbying pressure.

question.q: 20) Minimum differentiation among the political parties suggests that
question.a: A) the parties will have few ideas in common on their platforms.
question.b: B) the parties will offer few ideas on minimizing the size and scope of government.
question.c: C) the platforms of the parties will tend to become similar as they try to appeal to a majority of voters.
question.d: D) the platforms of the parties will tend to become dissimilar as they try to appeal to a loyal majority of voters.
question.e: E) the platforms of the parties will tend to have few, if any, new ideas.

question.q: 21) Rational ignorance suggests that
question.b: B) all voters will be ignorant on issues that are not of special interest to them.
question.c: C) all voters will pursue information about each issue before voting.
question.d: D) low voter turnout is due to a lack of understanding of the importance of the political platforms.
question.e: E) it is easier to aim at the median voter because it is a less costly strategy for the politicians.

question.q: 22) Rational ignorance suggests that a voter should stop acquiring more information about an issue when
question.a: A) the marginal benefit from acquiring the information equals zero.
question.b: B) the total cost of acquiring the information is minimized.
question.c: C) the total benefit from acquiring the information is maximized.
question.d: D) the marginal cost of acquiring the information is equal to the marginal benefit derived from the information.
question.e: E) the marginal cost of acquiring the information is greater than zero.

question.q: 23) Rational ignorance suggests that voters will
question.a: A) understand defence technology before voting for defence policy.
question.b: B) understand the auditing procedures of the Canada Revenue Agency before voting for tax reform.
question.c: C) understand the chemistry of the atmosphere before voting for a clean-air act.
question.d: D) vote without complete information on many issues.
question.e: E) vote based on their complete trust in politicians and bureaucrats.

question.q: 24) Public choice theory assumes those involved in the political process are motivated by
question.b: B) the desire to achieve efficiency.
question.c: C) dishonesty.
question.d: D) public spirit.
question.e: E) the desire for maximum profit.

question.q: 25) If all voters are well informed about national defence, the quantity of national defence provided by the government will be
question.a: A) greater than the efficient quantity.
question.b: B) less than the efficient quantity.
question.c: C) the least costly quantity.
question.d: D) the efficient quantity.
question.e: E) the quantity that maximizes the budget of the Department of National Defence.

question.q: 26) If voters are rationally ignorant, the quantity of national defence provided by the government will be
question.a: A) greater than the efficient quantity.
question.b: B) less than the efficient quantity.
question.c: C) the least costly quantity.
question.d: D) the quantity that maximizes the budget of the Department of National Defence.
question.e: E) both A and D are correct.

question.q: 27) Competition between two political parties will cause those parties to propose policies
question.c: C) of rational ignorance.
question.d: D) that reduce the well-being of middle-income families and increasing the well-being of the rich and the poor.
question.e: E) that equate total costs and total benefits.

question.q: 28) The budget of a government department is likely to increase beyond the efficient quantity if
question.b: B) there is rational voter ignorance combined with special interest lobbying.
question.c: C) the political equilibrium can be described in terms of social interest theory.
question.d: D) bureaucrats are rationally ignorant.

question.q: 29) The budget of a government department is likely to be efficient if
question.b: B) there is rational voter ignorance combined with special interest lobbying.
question.c: C) the political equilibrium can be described in terms of public choice theory.
question.d: D) bureaucrats are rationally ignorant.

question.q: 30) According to public choice theory, a voter will tend to be well informed if the issue in question
question.a: A) is complicated and difficult to understand.
question.c: C) is of special interest to a small group to which the voter does not belong.
question.d: D) has a large direct effect on the voter.
question.e: E) is important even if it does not directly affect the voter.

question.q: 31) Competitors who make themselves identical to appeal to the maximum number of voters illustrate the
question.c: C) principle of rational ignorance.
question.d: D) principle of nonrivalry.

question.q: 32) All of the following statements regarding rational ignorance are true except
question.a: A) it results when the cost of information exceeds the expected benefit of acquiring the information.
question.b: B) it allows special interest groups to exert political influence.
question.c: C) combined with special interest groups, it yields inefficiency in the provision of public goods.
question.d: D) it leads to an efficient outcome.

question.q: 33) In Table 17.2.1, which one of the proposals will have the greatest support?
question.c: C) Proposal B
question.d: D) Proposal C

question.q: 34) In Table 17.2.1, which one of the proposals will have the least support?
question.c: C) Proposal B
question.d: D) Proposal C

question.q: 35) In Table 17.2.1, which of the proposals would be supported by political parties according to the principle of minimum differentiation?
question.c: C) Proposal B
question.d: D) Proposal C

question.q: 36) Growing voter income can lead to the growth of the government sector because
question.a: A) public goods are income elastic.
question.b: B) public goods are income inelastic.
question.c: C) richer voters are more likely to be rationally ignorant.
question.d: D) richer voters do not care about overprovision of government goods.

question.q: 37) According to public choice theory, a voter will favour a candidate whose political program is
question.a: A) perceived by the voter to be in his self-interest.
question.b: B) best for the majority of the people.
question.c: C) closest to efficiency.
question.d: D) favoured by the median voter.

question.q: 38) Rational ignorance
question.a: A) results when the cost of acquiring information exceeds the benefit of acquiring the information.
question.b: B) allows special interest groups to exert political influence.
question.c: C) combined with special-interest groups can yield inefficient provision of public goods.
question.d: D) results in all of the above.
question.e: E) results in none of the above.

question.q: 39) Refer to Figure 17.2.2. The graph shows the marginal social benefit and marginal social cost of a garbage disposal system in a city of 1 million people. If voters are well informed about the costs and benefits of the garbage disposal system, the political equilibrium of garbage is
question.c: C) 2.5 million tonnes a day.
question.d: D) 4.0 million tonnes a day.

question.q: 40) Refer to Figure 17.2.3. The graph provides information about a waste disposal system in a city of 1 million people. If the city installs the efficient capacity, then each person pays ________ in taxes.
question.d: D) zero

question.q: 41) Your city council is contemplating upgrading its traffic control system and the council believes that the bigger the computer it installs, the better job it can do. Elected officials want to install the scale of the system that will win the most votes. The city bureaucrats want to maximize the budget. Suppose that you are an economist and your job is to calculate the scale of the system that uses resources efficiently. Public choice theory predicts that the quantity chosen will result in ________. As an informed voter, you can attempt to influence the choice of the correct system by encouraging other voters to ________.
question.a: A) overprovision that maximizes the budget of the bureaucrats; vote only for officials that will provide the smaller efficient quantity
question.b: B) overprovision that maximizes the budget of the bureaucrats; increase their income elasticity of demand for the new traffic control system
question.c: C) the efficient quantity; decrease their income elasticity of demand for the new traffic control system
question.d: D) the efficient quantity; increase their income elasticity of demand for the new traffic control system
question.e: E) overprovision that minimizes the income elasticity of demand of bureaucrats; decrease their elasticity of demand for the new traffic control system

question.q: 42) According to ________ theory, governments make choices that result in an ________ provision of public goods. This outcome occurs in ________.
question.a: A) public choice; efficient; political markets in which voters are rationally ignorant
question.b: B) social interest; efficient; a perfect political system in which voters are fully informed about the effects of policies
question.c: C) social interest; efficient; political markets in which voters are rationally ignorant
question.d: D) public choice; inefficient; a perfect political system in which voters are full informed about the effects of policies
question.e: E) social interest; inefficient; political markets in which voters are rationally ignorant

question.q: 1) Which of the following achieves the efficient use of a common resource?
question.a: A) property rights, production quotas, and individual transferable quotas
question.b: B) property rights, individual transferable quotas, and subsidies
question.c: C) property rights, production quotas, and subsidies
question.d: D) individual transferable quotas and copyrights
question.e: E) production quotas, individual transferable quotas, and copyrights

question.q: 2) One way to alleviate the tragedy of the commons is to
question.a: A) eliminate production quotas for using the common resource.
question.b: B) make the resource private property.
question.c: C) allow all individuals to use the common resource free of charge.
question.d: D) distribute common resources among those individuals who really need the resource free of charge.
question.e: E) set a price of $1 per unit of the common resource because it is an affordable price.

question.q: 3) An individual transferable quota is a production limit that
question.a: A) has a price equal to marginal cost.
question.b: B) is assigned to every producer in the industry at a predetermined price.
question.c: C) is assigned to an individual who must transfer the quota to anyone the government assigns.
question.d: D) is assigned to an individual who is free to transfer the quota to someone else.
question.e: E) has a price equal to marginal benefit.

question.q: 4) The "tragedy of the commons" refers to
question.a: A) the inability of lower income groups to achieve a higher level of education.
question.b: B) the absence of incentives to prevent the overuse of a common resource that arises when its users have no incentive to conserve it and use it sustainably.
question.c: C) the acceptance of deplorable working conditions by those who lack the human capital to obtain a better job.
question.d: D) the tendency for bureaucrats to maximize their budget.
question.e: E) farmers who allow their livestock to overgraze their fields.

question.q: 5) The absence of incentives to prevent the overuse of a common resource that arises when its users have no incentive to conserve it and use it sustainably is referred to as
question.c: C) the tragedy of the commons.
question.d: D) rational ignorance.

question.q: 6) Sustainable production is
question.a: A) the rate of production that can be maintained indefinitely.
question.b: B) the production output with the lowest average total cost.
question.c: C) the production output where MC=ATC.
question.d: D) the rate of production that maximizes marginal private benefit.
question.e: E) the rate of production where MB=MC.

question.q: 7) Common resources are overused because
question.a: A) the marginal private benefit of operating a boat is the quantity of fish a boat can catch.
question.b: B) the social benefits outweigh the private benefits.
question.c: C) the marginal private benefit will always exceed the marginal social cost.
question.d: D) external costs are not considered.
question.e: E) social costs are controlled by production quotas.

question.q: 8) In the equilibrium for a common resource with no government regulation,
question.a: A) marginal social benefit is greater than marginal social cost.
question.b: B) marginal social benefit equals marginal social cost.
question.c: C) marginal social benefit is less than marginal cost.
question.d: D) marginal social benefit is greater than marginal cost.
question.e: E) marginal social benefit equals marginal cost.

question.q: 9) The tragedy of the commons is the absence of incentives to
question.a: A) reduce marginal cost of common resources.
question.b: B) prevent underuse of common resources.
question.c: C) prevent overuse of common resources.
question.d: D) discover new common resources.
question.e: E) export wool in sixteenth-century England.

question.q: 10) When a production quota is used to remedy the problem of the commons, then
question.a: A) the production quota is set so that use of the resource is where marginal private benefit equals marginal cost.
question.b: B) the production quota is set so that use of the resource is where marginal private benefit equals marginal social benefit.
question.c: C) the market equilibrium, but not the efficient outcome, is achieved.
question.d: D) all users of the resource have an incentive to cheat on the production quota.
question.e: E) the production quota is set so that marginal social benefit is maximized.

question.q: 11) Setting a production quota does not always achieve the efficient use of a common resource because ________.
question.a: A) marginal cost differs for each producer and it is in everyone's self-interest to cheat and produce more than the assigned quota
question.b: B) the marginal private benefit from a production quota is zero
question.c: C) marginal cost differs for each producer and the marginal social benefit from a production quota is zero
question.d: D) a production quota does not totally eliminate the problem of free-ridership of a common resource

question.q: 12) All of the following statements are true except ________.
question.a: A) the market price of an ITQ equals the marginal social benefit minus the marginal cost
question.b: B) when an ITQ system is used in a fishing market, boat owners with a low marginal cost are willing and able to pay more for a quota than are boat owners with a higher marginal cost
question.c: C) individual differences in marginal cost do not prevent an ITQ system from delivering the efficient outcome
question.d: D) an ITQ is a production limit that is assigned to an individual who is free to transfer the quota to someone else
question.e: E) Canada does not use ITQs

question.q: 13) Which of the following applies to the tragedy of the commons?
question.c: C) II and III
question.d: D) I, II and III

question.q: 14) In which of the following cases can the tragedy of the commons occur?
question.c: C) II and III only
question.d: D) I and IV only

question.q: 15) For a common resource, the marginal private cost curve slopes ________ and the marginal social cost curve slopes ________.
question.c: C) downward; upward
question.d: D) downward; downward
question.e: E) upward or downward; in the same direction as the marginal private cost curve

question.q: 16) The efficient use of a common resource requires that the ________ equals the ________.
question.a: A) marginal private benefit; marginal social cost
question.b: B) marginal social benefit; marginal social cost
question.c: C) marginal private benefit; marginal social benefit
question.d: D) marginal social cost; marginal private cost

question.q: 17) If property rights are assigned to a common resource, then the
question.a: A) government needs to set an ITQ to achieve efficiency.
question.b: B) government needs to set a production quota to achieve efficiency.
question.c: C) more than the efficient quantity is produced.
question.d: D) marginal social benefit increases.
question.e: E) marginal private cost becomes equal to the marginal social cost.

question.q: 18) Figure 17.3.1 shows the marginal private cost curve, marginal social cost curve, and marginal social benefit curve for cod, a common resource. The equilibrium quantity in an unregulated market is
question.c: C) 3,000 kilograms a week.
question.d: D) 5,000 kilograms a week.

question.q: 19) Figure 17.3.1 shows the marginal private cost curve, marginal social cost curve, and marginal social benefit curve for cod, a common resource. The efficient quantity is
question.c: C) 3,000 kilograms a week.
question.d: D) 5,000 kilograms a week.

question.q: 20) Figure 17.3.1 shows the marginal private cost curve, marginal social cost curve, and marginal social benefit curve for cod, a common resource. A quota that results in the common resource being used efficiently is set at
question.c: C) 3,000 kilograms a week.
question.d: D) 5,000 kilograms a week.

question.q: 21) Figure 17.3.2 shows the marginal private cost curve, marginal social cost curve, and marginal social benefit curve for raising goats on a common pasture. The equilibrium in an unregulated market is
question.c: C) 50 goats.
question.d: D) 55 goats.

question.q: 22) Figure 17.3.2 shows the marginal private cost curve, marginal social cost curve, and marginal social benefit curve for raising goats on a common pasture. The efficient quantity is
question.c: C) 50 goats.
question.d: D) 55 goats.

question.q: 23) Figure 17.3.2 shows the marginal private cost curve, marginal social cost curve, and marginal social benefit curve for raising goats on a common pasture. A quota that results in the common resource being used efficiently is set at
question.c: C) 50 goats.
question.d: D) 55 goats.

question.q: 24) Figure 17.3.2 shows the marginal private cost curve, marginal social cost curve, and marginal social benefit curve for raising goats on a common pasture. If property rights to the pasture are granted to a farmer so that the farmer owns the pasture, the farmer raises
question.c: C) 50 goats.
question.d: D) 55 goats.

question.q: 1) The four factors of production are
question.a: A) productive factors, neutral factors, entrepreneurial factors, and nonproductive factors.
question.b: B) men, women, animals, and children.
question.c: C) labour, capital, entrepreneurship, and land.
question.d: D) machines, factories, buildings, and farms.
question.e: E) labour, money, profits, and land.

question.q: 2) Profit is the factor price for
question.c: C) entrepreneurship.
question.d: D) labour.

question.q: 3) Coal is an example of
question.c: C) capital.
question.d: D) a common resource.

question.q: 4) Water from the Mackenzie River is an example of
question.b: B) a natural resource that can be used repeatedly.
question.c: C) capital.
question.d: D) a static resource.

question.q: 5) Natural resources that are depleted as they are used
question.b: B) are called nonrenewable natural resources.
question.c: C) should be used for only highly valued purposes.
question.d: D) should be conserved for future generations.
question.e: E) are called renewable natural resources.

question.q: 6) An example of a nonrenewable natural resource is
question.c: C) rain.
question.d: D) sunshine.

question.q: 7) Choose the statement that is incorrect.
question.a: A) Capital consists of the tools, instruments, machines, buildings, and other constructions that have been produced in the past and that businesses now use to produce goods and services.
question.b: B) A market for capital services is a rental market.
question.c: C) The services of the capital that a firm owns and operates have an implicit price that arises from depreciation and interest costs.
question.d: D) Capital is a factor of production.
question.e: E) Most capital services are traded in a market.

question.q: 8) Choose the statement that is incorrect.
question.a: A) Entrepreneurship is a factor of production.
question.b: B) Entrepreneurs receive the profit or bear the loss that results from their business decisions.
question.c: C) Entrepreneurship consists of all the gifts of nature.
question.d: D) Entrepreneurial services are traded in markets.
question.e: E) Both C and D are incorrect.

question.q: 9) Choose the statement that is correct.
question.a: A) Labour services are the physical and mental work effort that people supply to produce goods and services.
question.b: B) A labour market is a collection of people and firms who trade labour services.
question.c: C) The price of labour services is the wage rate.
question.d: D) Most labour services are traded on a contract, called a job.

question.q: 1) Firms hire labour
question.a: A) to minimize the average cost of the employment of labour.
question.c: C) to maximize profit.
question.d: D) because capital is more expensive.

question.q: 2) To maximize profit, a firm hires labour until
question.a: A) there is no more labour available at the market wage rate.
question.b: B) they can sell that labour for no more than what they paid for it.
question.c: C) the wage rate paid to the labour equals the marginal cost of production.
question.d: D) the additional benefit of hiring the labour is equal to the additional revenue the labour generates.
question.e: E) the value of marginal product equals the wage rate.

question.q: 3) To maximize profit, the firm must equate the
question.a: A) wage rate to the price of the good.
question.b: B) wage rate to the marginal product of labour.
question.c: C) value of marginal product to the factor price.
question.d: D) marginal factor cost to the price of the output.
question.e: E) marginal cost of the factor to the marginal product of the factor.

question.q: 4) The value of marginal product of labour is the revenue
question.a: A) generated by selling an additional unit of output.
question.b: B) needed to hire an additional unit of labour.
question.c: C) generated by the employment of an additional unit of labour.
question.d: D) needed to cover the cost of producing an additional unit of output.
question.e: E) generated to cover the cost of hiring an extra unit of labour.

question.q: 5) If marginal product of a restaurant employee is 10 customers per hour, and the price of a meal is $15, the restaurant employee's value of marginal product is

6) Suppose a gift shop in Corner Brook Newfoundland hires workers to personalize ornaments for Christmas. The store sells the personalized ornaments for $6 each. The value of marginal product of this store's fourth worker is $60. The marginal product of the fourth worker is
question.c: C) 60 ornaments.
question.d: D) 360 ornaments.

question.q: 7) If the marginal product of a baker is 10 loaves of bread, and the price of a loaf of bread is $2, the baker's value of marginal product is

8) The Brown's Egg store in Lethbridge Alberta hires workers to paint eggs. The price of an egg is $2.50. The value of marginal product of this store's fifth worker is $25. The marginal product of the fifth worker is
question.c: C) 2 eggs.
question.d: D) 10 eggs.

question.q: 9) Refer to Table 18.2.1. If the firm can sell all the output it wants for the price of $5 a unit, what is the value of marginal product of the 6th worker?
10) Refer to Table 18.2.1. If the firm can sell all the output it wants for the price of $4 a unit, what is the profit-maximizing number of workers if the wage rate is $12?
11) Refer to Table 18.2.1. If the firm can sell all the output it wants for the price of $5 a unit, what is the profit-maximizing number of workers if the wage rate is $30?
12) Refer to Table 18.2.1. If the firm can sell all the output it wants for the price of $10 a unit, what is the profit-maximizing number of workers if the wage rate is $30?
13) If the price of the firm's output decreases, the value of marginal product curve
question.c: C) becomes more inelastic.
question.d: D) shifts to the left.

question.q: 14) Mr. Shaw has a small factory in Estevan Saskatchewan. He will continue hiring labour as long as the value of marginal product of labour ________ the wage rate.
question.c: C) is less than or equal to
question.d: D) determines

question.q: 15) A profit-maximizing firm will continue to hire labour until the
question.a: A) wage rate equals the last worker's marginal product.
question.b: B) last worker's value of marginal product is maximized.
question.c: C) last worker's value of marginal product is negative.
question.d: D) wage rate equals the last worker's value of marginal product.
question.e: E) last worker's value of marginal product equals zero.

question.q: 16) A shift in a firm's demand curve for labour occurs when there is a change in the
question.c: C) price of the output.
question.d: D) working-age population.

question.q: 17) A shift in a firm's demand curve for labour occurs for all of the following reasons except a change in
question.a: A) the prices of other factors of production.
question.c: C) the price of the firm's output.
question.d: D) wage rate.

question.q: 18) Suppose a profit-maximizing firm hires labour in a competitive labour market. If the value of marginal product of labour is greater than the wage rate, the firm should
question.c: C) increase the quantity of labour it hires.
question.d: D) decrease the quantity of labour it hires.
question.e: E) shift to a more labour-intensive production process.

question.q: 19) When the price of a firm's output increases
question.a: A) the supply of labour increases.
question.b: B) the firm hires less labour.

question.b: B) increases aggregate expenditure and produces a rightward shift of the aggregate demand curve.
question.c: C) increases aggregate expenditure and produces a leftward shift of the aggregate demand curve.
question.d: D) has no effect on aggregate expenditure.
question.e: E) increases aggregate expenditure, but has no effect on the aggregate demand curve.

question.q: 3) A rise in the price level
question.a: A) decreases aggregate expenditure and produces a movement along the aggregate demand curve.
question.b: B) decreases aggregate expenditure and produces a rightward shift of the aggregate demand curve.
question.c: C) decreases aggregate expenditure and produces a leftward shift of the aggregate demand curve.
question.d: D) has no effect on aggregate expenditure.
question.e: E) increases aggregate expenditure, but has no effect on the aggregate demand curve.

question.q: 4) The aggregate expenditure curve and the aggregate demand curve are
question.b: B) the same curve, just with different names.
question.c: C) linked because if the price level rises, the aggregate expenditure curve shifts downward, and the aggregate demand curve shifts leftward.
question.d: D) linked because if the price level rises, the aggregate expenditure curve shifts downward, and there is a movement up along the aggregate demand curve.
question.e: E) linked because if the price level rises, the aggregate expenditure curve shifts downward, and there is a movement down along the aggregate demand curve.

question.q: 5) A shift in the aggregate expenditure curve as a result of a rise in the price level,
question.a: A) shifts the aggregate demand curve leftward.
question.b: B) has no effect on the aggregate demand curve.
question.c: C) shifts the aggregate demand curve rightward.
question.d: D) creates a movement down along the aggregate demand curve.
question.e: E) creates a movement up along the aggregate demand curve.

question.q: 6) Suppose that investment increases by $10 billion. If the multiplier is 2, the AD curve
question.a: A) shifts rightward by the horizontal distance $20 billion.
question.b: B) shifts rightward by a horizontal distance greater than $20 billion.
question.c: C) shifts rightward by a horizontal distance less than $20 billion.
question.d: D) is not affected.
question.e: E) shifts upward by a vertical distance equal to $20 billion.

question.q: 7) Suppose that investment decreases by $15 billion. If the multiplier is 2.5, the aggregate demand curve
question.a: A) shifts leftward by a horizontal distance of $37.5 billion.
question.b: B) shifts leftward by a horizontal distance greater than $37.5 billion.
question.c: C) shifts leftward by a horizontal distance less than $37.5 billion.
question.d: D) shifts upward by a vertical distance of $37.5 billion.

question.q: 8) Suppose the multiplier is 2 and the short-run aggregate supply curve is positively sloped. Investment increases by $10 billion. In the short run, equilibrium real GDP
question.b: B) increases by more than $20 billion.
question.c: C) decreases by less than $20 billion.
question.d: D) does not change.
question.e: E) increases by less than $20 billion.

question.q: 9) Suppose the multiplier is 2.5 and investment increases by $20 billion. Starting at potential GDP, in the long run, equilibrium real GDP
question.b: B) increases by more than $50 billion.
question.c: C) decreases by less than $50 billion.
question.d: D) does not change.
question.e: E) increases by less than $50 billion.

question.q: 10) Suppose that investment decreases by $15 billion. If the multiplier is 2, and the short-run aggregate supply curve is positively sloped. In the short run, equilibrium real GDP
question.b: B) decreases by more than $30 billion.
question.c: C) decreases by less than $30 billion.
question.d: D) increases by less than $30 billion.

question.q: 11) Suppose that investment increases by $10 billion. Which one of the following would reduce the effect of this increase in autonomous expenditure on equilibrium real GDP in the short run?
question.a: A) an increase in the marginal propensity to consume.
question.b: B) a decrease in the marginal propensity to import
question.c: C) a decrease in the marginal tax rate
question.d: D) a steeper short-run aggregate supply curve
question.e: E) a flatter short-run aggregate supply curve

question.q: 12) Everything else remaining the same, if aggregate demand changes, the amount by which the AD curve shifts depends on
question.a: A) the change in aggregate supply.
question.b: B) the change in autonomous expenditure and the multiplier.
question.c: C) changes in induced expenditure.
question.d: D) the change in the price level.

question.q: 13) Suppose there is an increase in exports. Assuming the price level is held constant, which one of the following best describes the sequence of changes in the economy?
question.a: A) Autonomous expenditure increases, induced expenditure increases, real GDP increases, and the price level rises.
question.b: B) Induced expenditure increases, autonomous expenditure increases, real GDP increases, and consumption increases.
question.c: C) Induced expenditure increases, real GDP increases, autonomous expenditure increases, and the price level increases, lowering autonomous expenditure and real GDP increases by a smaller amount.
question.d: D) Induced expenditure increases, real GDP increases, autonomous expenditure increases, real GDP increases more, autonomous expenditure increases again, etc.
question.e: E) Autonomous expenditure increases, real GDP increases, induced expenditure increases, real GDP increases more, induced expenditure increases again, and the process continues until equilibrium expenditure is reached.

question.q: 14) In the long run, the multiplier
question.a: A) has a larger effect on real GDP than it has in the short run, because the multiplier effect has a longer time period to exert its impact on the economy.
question.b: B) has a larger effect on real GDP than it has in the short run, because there are more induced expenditures in the long run.
question.c: C) has a larger effect on real GDP than it has in the short run because of changes in the price level.
question.d: D) has a smaller effect on real GDP than it has in the short run because of changes in the price level.
question.e: E) can have a smaller or larger effect on real GDP than it has in the short run.

question.q: 15) The difference in the influence of a multiplier between the short run and the long run, is that
question.a: A) the multiplier effect is larger in the long run.
question.b: B) the multiplier effect is zero in the long run.
question.c: C) the multiplier effect is zero in the short run.
question.d: D) there is no multiplier effect in the short run.
question.e: E) the multiplier effect depends on potential GDP in the long run.

question.q: 16) A rise in the price level ________.
question.a: A) shifts the AD curve rightward and brings a movement up along the AE curve
question.b: B) shifts the AE curve upward and brings a movement down along the AD curve
question.c: C) shifts the AE curve downward and brings a movement up along the AD curve
question.d: D) shifts the AD curve leftward and brings a movement down along the AE curve
question.e: E) shifts the AE curve downward and shifts the AD curve rightward

question.q: 17) An increase in investment shifts the AE curve upward by an amount equal to the ________, and shifts the AD curve rightward by an amount equal to the ________.
question.a: A) change in investment; change in investment times the multiplier
question.b: B) change in investment times the multiplier; change in investment times the multiplier
question.c: C) change in investment times the multiplier; change in investment
question.d: D) change in investment; change in investment
question.e: E) change in investment divided by the multiplier; change in investment

question.q: 18) The larger the multiplier, the ________ the AE curve and the ________ the AD curve from a given increase in investment.
question.a: A) steeper; greater the rightward shift of
question.b: B) steeper; greater the movement upward along
question.c: C) flatter; greater the rightward shift of
question.d: D) flatter; greater the movement upward along
question.e: E) steeper; greater the movement downward along

question.q: 19) Which of the following events shifts the aggregate expenditure curve and also shifts the aggregate demand curve?
question.c: C) II and III
question.d: D) I, II, and III

question.q: 18) You are given the following information about the Canadian economy. Autonomous consumption expenditure is $50 billion, investment is $200 billion, and government expenditure is $250 billion. The marginal propensity to consume is 0.7 and net taxes are $250 billion. 21) In an economy, autonomous spending is $20 trillion and the slope of the AE curve is 0.8.

question.q: 1) Which of the following would cause the aggregate demand curve to keep shifting rightward year after year?
question.b: B) a one-time increase in government expenditures on goods and services
question.c: C) inflation
question.d: D) excess wage demands
question.e: E) a persistent increase in the quantity of money

question.q: 2) At full employment an increase in the quantity of money (ceteris paribus) can create a
question.a: A) demand-pull inflation, as can an increase in government expenditure.
question.b: B) demand-pull inflation, but an increase in government expenditure cannot.
question.c: C) cost-push inflation, as can an increase in government expenditure.
question.d: D) cost-push inflation, but an increase in government expenditure cannot.
question.e: E) demand-pull and a cost-push inflation, as can an increase in government expenditure.

question.q: 3) Demand-pull inflation occurs when
question.c: C) input costs rise.
question.d: D) people incorrectly forecast inflation.
question.e: E) unemployment is above the natural rate.

question.q: 4) Inflation resulting from an increase in aggregate demand is called
question.c: C) anticipated inflation.
question.d: D) unanticipated inflation.

question.q: 5) Which one of the following can create a demand-pull inflation?
question.a: A) a sharp increase in the price of oil
question.b: B) higher wages negotiated by unions
question.c: C) a cut in the interest rate
question.d: D) a decrease in investment as a result of a decrease in expected future profits
question.e: E) a decrease in government expenditure on goods and services

question.q: 6) Stagflation occurs when the economy experiences both
question.a: A) rising inflation and increasing real GDP.
question.b: B) falling inflation and decreasing real GDP.
question.c: C) rising inflation and decreasing real GDP.
question.d: D) falling inflation and increasing real GDP.
question.e: E) low exports and low imports.

question.q: 7) Suppose the economy is in long-run equilibrium when the price of oil rises. Which one of the following is not a short-run effect of this situation?
question.a: A) an increase in real GDP above long-run real GDP
question.b: B) an increase in the price level
question.c: C) a decrease in real GDP
question.d: D) an increase in unemployment
question.e: E) a decrease in consumer spending

question.q: 8) Suppose OPEC unexpectedly collapses, which leads to a fall in the price of oil. As a result, the price level
question.a: A) rises, and real GDP increases.
question.b: B) rises, and real GDP decreases.
question.c: C) falls, and real GDP increases.
question.d: D) falls, and real GDP decreases.
question.e: E) rises, and real GDP remains the same.

question.q: 9) An increase in the price level due to an increase in the price of oil
question.a: A) creates stagflation in the short-run and will trigger a cost-push inflation.
question.b: B) creates stagflation in the short-run and may trigger off a cost-push inflation.
question.c: C) increases output above potential GDP.
question.d: D) leads to an increase in the money wage rate.
question.e: E) leads to a decrease in the money wage rate.

question.q: 10) Cost-push inflation can result from an initial
question.a: A) decrease in personal income taxes.
question.b: B) increase in personal income taxes.
question.c: C) increase in government expenditure.
question.d: D) increase in the money wage rate.

question.q: 11) Stagflation can result from
question.a: A) a leftward shift of the demand curve.
question.b: B) a rightward shift of the demand curve.
question.c: C) a leftward shift of the short-run aggregate supply curve.
question.d: D) a rightward shift of the short-run aggregate supply curve.
question.e: E) a rightward shift of the long-run aggregate supply curve.

question.q: 12) A cost-price inflation spiral results if the policy response to stagflation is to keep
question.c: C) increasing aggregate demand.
question.d: D) increasing short-run aggregate supply.

question.q: 13) Refer to Figure 28.1.1. The figure illustrates an economy initially in equilibrium at the intersection of the SAS0 curve and the AD0 curve. Which of the following shifts the short-run aggregate supply curve from SAS0 to SAS1?
question.a: A) an increase in the price of oil
question.b: B) an increase in the price level
question.c: C) an increase in the marginal product of labour
question.d: D) an increase in the demand for money
question.e: E) a decrease in the money wage rate

question.q: 14) Refer to Figure 28.1.2. The economy is in long-run equilibrium. If the short-run aggregate supply curve shifts leftward from SAS0 to SAS1, ceteris paribus, then people expected
question.b: B) the price level to rise to 110.
question.c: C) the real wage rate to fall by 10 percent.
question.d: D) a real GDP decrease of $50 billion.

question.q: 15) Refer to Figure 28.1.2. The economy is in long-run equilibrium. If the short-run aggregate supply curve shifts leftward from SAS0 to SAS1, ceteris paribus, then the actual inflation rate
question.a: A) is greater than the expected inflation rate.
question.b: B) is less than the expected inflation rate.
question.c: C) is the same as the expected inflation rate.
question.d: D) cannot be determined without more information.
question.e: E) depends on what happens to wage settlements.

question.q: 16) Refer to Figure 28.1.2. The vertical distance between SAS0 and SAS1 represents the
question.b: B) expected increase in real GDP.
question.c: C) actual decrease in real GDP.
question.d: D) expected inflation rate.
question.e: E) expected decrease in the real wage rate.

question.q: 17) Refer to Figure 28.1.2. If the short-run aggregate supply curve does not shift, and remains at SAS0, then the expected inflation rate is
question.c: C) 15 percent.
question.d: D) 5 percent.

question.q: 18) Refer to Figure 28.1.2. If SAS shifts from SAS0 to SAS1, then
question.a: A) inflation is expected to be 10 percent.
question.c: C) a recession will occur.
question.d: D) unemployment will fall.

question.q: 19) Refer to Figure 28.1.2. Consider the market for labour as the short-run aggregate supply curve shifts leftward from SAS0 to SAS1. This shift could have been the result of an agreement between workers and employers for a
question.a: A) 10 percent decrease in the money wage rate.
question.b: B) 10 percent increase in the money wage rate.
question.c: C) 15 percent decrease in the money wage rate.
question.d: D) 15 percent increase in the money wage rate.
question.e: E) 10 percent increase in the real wage rate.

question.q: 20) Refer to Figure 28.1.2. Complete the following sentence. The figure illustrates
question.c: C) a cost-push inflation spiral.
question.d: D) a one time rise in the price level.
question.e: E) A and C are both correct.

question.q: 21) A forecast based on all the relevant information is
question.c: C) a rational expectation.
question.d: D) always a correct expectation.

If the aggregate demand curve is expected to shift to AD1 but remains at AD0, the new equilibrium real GDP is ________ and the new equilibrium price level is ________.
question.c: C) $500 billion; 100
question.d: D) $620 billion; 125

question.q: 24) Refer to Figure 28.1.3. Assume that the figure illustrates an economy initially in equilibrium at the intersection of the SAS0 curve and the AD0 curve. If the aggregate demand curve is expected to remain at AD0 but shifts to AD1, the new equilibrium real GDP is ________ and the new equilibrium price level is ________.
question.c: C) $500 billion; 100
question.d: D) $620 billion; 125

question.e: E) We cannot tell without more information on wage negotiations.

question.q: 26) A correctly anticipated increase in the quantity of money, in an economy with an unchanging long-run aggregate supply, will result in
question.a: A) a rise in the price level and an increase in real GDP.
question.b: B) a rise in the price level and a decrease in real GDP.
question.c: C) a proportional rise in the price level and no change in real GDP.
question.d: D) no change in the price level and an increase in real GDP.
question.e: E) no change in the price level and no change in real GDP.

question.q: 27) Suppose the quantity of money is expected to remain unchanged but it actually increases. The price level
question.a: A) rises and real GDP increases.
question.b: B) rises and real GDP decreases.
question.c: C) falls and real GDP increases.
question.d: D) falls and real GDP decreases.
question.e: E) rises and real GDP stays the same.

question.q: 28) An economy is in long-run equilibrium when aggregate supply unexpectedly decreases. Then real GDP (ceteris paribus) will be
question.c: C) equal to potential GDP.
question.d: D) either above, below, or equal to potential GDP depending on the position of the aggregate demand curve.
question.e: E) either above or equal to potential GDP depending on the position of the aggregate demand curve.

question.q: 29) A correctly anticipated increase in the quantity of money
question.a: A) increases the price level with no change in real GDP.
question.b: B) does not change the price level or real GDP.
question.c: C) does not change the price level but increases real GDP.
question.d: D) increases the price level and increases real GDP.
question.e: E) does not change the price level but decreases real GDP.

question.q: 30) A forecast that is based on all the relevant information available is
question.a: A) usually no better than a random guess given that the future bears many uncertainties.
question.c: C) called a rational expectation.
question.d: D) useful only in the prediction of cost-push inflation.
question.e: E) useful only in the prediction of demand-pull inflation.

question.q: 31) Refer to Figure 28.1.5. Which one of the graphs in the figure represents an economy experiencing stagflation?
question.c: C) (c)
question.d: D) (d)

question.c: C) (c)
question.d: D) (d)

question.q: 33) The economy starts out at a full-employment equilibrium. Some events then occur that generate a demand-pull inflation.
question.c: C) the quantity of money
question.d: D) government expenditure

question.c: C) C; B, H, G, I

question.q: 35) Refer to Figure 28.1.6. Starting at point A, the initial effect of a cost-push inflation is a move to point ________. As a cost-push inflation spiral proceeds, it follows the path ________.
question.a: A) C; B, H, G, I
question.c: C) B; E, G, I
question.d: D) E; I

question.q: 36) The economy starts out at a full-employment equilibrium. Some events then occur that generate a cost-push inflation.
question.b: B) an increase in the quantity of money
question.c: C) a decrease in government expenditure
question.d: D) an increase in the money wage rate or an increase in the money prices of raw materials

question.c: C) III only

question.q: 38) Stagflation is the result of
question.a: A) a decrease in aggregate demand.
question.b: B) a decrease in short-run aggregate supply.
question.c: C) an increase in aggregate demand.
question.d: D) an increase in short-run aggregate supply.
question.e: E) a decrease in short-run aggregate supply combined with a simultaneous increase in aggregate supply.

question.q: 39) When the price level is rising and simultaneously real GDP is decreasing
question.a: A) the natural unemployment rate is rising.
question.b: B) the natural unemployment rate is falling.
question.c: C) stagflation is occurring.
question.d: D) the economy is experiencing an expansionary gap.
question.e: E) Both A and C are correct.

question.q: 40) Suppose aggregate demand increases by more than expected. Which of the following describes what occurs?
question.a: A) Real GDP is greater than potential GDP.
question.c: C) Unemployment falls.
question.d: D) The natural unemployment rate does not change.

question.q: 1) Along the short-run Phillips curve, everything remaining the same, the higher the
question.a: A) unemployment rate, the lower the inflation rate.
question.b: B) price level, the lower the inflation rate.
question.c: C) money wage rate, the lower is the unemployment rate.
question.d: D) quantity of money, the lower the unemployment rate.
question.e: E) growth rate of the quantity of money, the higher the inflation rate.

question.q: 2) The short-run Phillips curve shows the relationship between ________ holding constant the expected inflation rate and the natural unemployment rate.
question.a: A) the inflation rate and the economic growth rate
question.b: B) unemployment and the economic growth rate
question.c: C) the inflation rate and the unemployment rate
question.d: D) growth and potential GDP.
question.e: E) the inflation rate and the growth of the money wage rate.

question.q: 3) If the unemployment rate rises and the inflation rate falls, while the natural unemployment rate and the expected inflation rate remain constant, then we are studying a movement along the
question.c: C) Friedman curve.
question.d: D) short-run Phillips curve.

question.q: 4) For a given expected inflation rate, the higher the unemployment rate, the lower is the actual inflation rate. This relationship is the ________ Phillips curve. When the expected inflation rate changes, this is shown as a movement along the ________ Phillips curve.
question.c: C) long-run; natural
question.d: D) natural; short-run

question.q: 5) If the natural unemployment rate rises
question.a: A) the long-run Phillips curve shifts rightward and the short-run Phillips curve does not change.
question.b: B) the long-run Phillips curve shifts leftward and the short-run Phillips curve does not change.
question.c: C) the short-run Phillips curve shifts rightward and the long-run Phillips curve does not change.
question.d: D) the short-run and long-run Phillips curves both shift leftward.
question.e: E) the short-run and long-run Phillips curves both shift rightward.

question.q: 6) If the natural unemployment rate falls
question.a: A) the long-run Phillips curve shifts rightward and the short-run Phillips curve does not change.
question.b: B) the long-run Phillips curve shifts leftward and the short-run Phillips curve does not change.
question.c: C) the short-run Phillips curve shifts rightward.
question.d: D) the short-run and long-run Phillips curves both shift leftward.
question.e: E) the short-run and long-run Phillips curves both shift rightward.

question.q: 7) The short-run Phillips curve shows the relationship between
question.a: A) the price level and real GDP in the short run.
question.b: B) the price level and unemployment in the short run.
question.c: C) unemployment and real GDP in the short run.
question.d: D) inflation and unemployment, when inflation expectations can change.
question.e: E) inflation and unemployment, when the expected inflation rate and the natural unemployment rate remain constant.

question.q: 8) Along the short-run Phillips curve, if the actual unemployment rate falls below the natural unemployment rate, the
question.a: A) actual inflation rate will be equal to the expected inflation rate.
question.b: B) actual inflation rate will be greater than the expected inflation rate.
question.c: C) actual inflation rate will be less than the expected inflation rate.
question.d: D) actual inflation rate may be greater than, equal to, or less than the expected inflation rate
question.e: E) expected inflation rate will fall to zero.

question.q: 9) A movement down along the short-run Phillips curve results from an unanticipated
question.c: C) decrease in short-run aggregate supply.
question.d: D) increase in short-run aggregate supply.
question.e: E) increase in the natural unemployment rate.

question.q: 10) An increase in the expected rate of inflation shifts the
question.c: C) long-run Phillips curve rightward.
question.d: D) long-run Phillips curve leftward.
question.e: E) B and C are correct.

question.d: D) 7 percent

question.d: D) 7 percent

question.c: C) 6 percent
question.d: D) 7 percent

question.d: D) 3 percent
question.e: E) cannot be determined without more information

question.q: 19) Refer to Figure 28.2.2. The figure illustrates an economy's Phillips curves. If the current inflation rate is 4 percent, what is the natural unemployment rate?
question.c: C) 4 percent
question.d: D) 3 percent
question.e: E) cannot be determined without more information

question.q: 20) Refer to Figure 28.2.2. The figure illustrates an economy's Phillips curves. If the expected inflation rate changes to 3 percent, the
question.a: A) short run Phillips curve will shift upward and the long run Phillips curve will not change.
question.b: B) short run Phillips curve will shift downward and the long run Phillips curve will not change.
question.c: C) short run Phillips curve will shift upward and the long run Phillips curve will shift leftward.
question.d: D) short run Phillips curve will shift upward and the long run Phillips curve will shift rightward.
question.e: E) short run Phillips curve will shift downward and the long run Phillips curve will shift rightward.

question.q: 21) If the inflation rate is lower than the expected inflation rate,
question.a: A) unemployment is above the natural rate.
question.b: B) the natural unemployment rate will increase.
question.c: C) the expected inflation rate will increase.
question.d: D) unemployment is below the natural rate.
question.e: E) the economy is not operating on the short-run Phillips curve.

question.q: 22) If there is a fully anticipated increase in the inflation rate
question.a: A) unemployment will be below the natural rate.
question.b: B) unemployment will be above the natural rate.
question.c: C) the natural unemployment rate will increase.
question.d: D) the economy is not operating on the LRPC curve.
question.e: E) the economy is operating on the LRPC curve.

question.q: 23) If the natural unemployment rate increases, the long-run Phillips curve ________, the short-run Phillips curve ________, and the expected inflation rate ________.
question.a: A) does not shift; does not shift; does not change
question.b: B) shifts rightward; shifts rightward; does not change
question.c: C) does not shift; shifts rightward; rises
question.d: D) shifts rightward; curve does not shift; falls
question.e: E) shifts rightward; shifts rightward; falls

question.q: 24) The Canadian short-run Phillips curve ________ when the expected inflation rate rises and ________ when the expected inflation rate falls.
question.a: A) shifts downward; shifts upward; shifts rightward; shifts leftward
question.b: B) does not shift; does not shift; shifts rightward; shifts leftward
question.c: C) shifts upward; shifts downward; does not shift; does not shift
question.d: D) shifts upward; shifts downward; shifts rightward; shifts leftward
question.e: E) shifts upward; does not shift; shifts rightward; does not shift

question.q: 25) The Canadian long-run Phillips curve ________ when the expected inflation rate rises and ________ when the expected inflation rate falls.
question.a: A) does not shift; does not shift; does not shift; does not shift
question.b: B) does not shift; does not shift; shifts rightward; shifts leftward
question.c: C) shifts upward; shifts downward; shifts rightward; shifts leftward
question.d: D) shifts rightward; shifts leftward; does not shift; does not shift
question.e: E) shifts rightward; shifts leftward; shifts rightward; shifts leftward

question.q: 26) Refer to Table 28.2.2. The economy's natural unemployment rate is 4 percent. Table 28.2.2 gives some points on the economy's short-run Phillips curve. When the unemployment rate is 4 percent ________.
question.a: A) actual inflation is greater than expected inflation
question.b: B) actual inflation is less than expected inflation
question.c: C) and the inflation rate is 6 percent a year, the short-run and long-run Phillips curves intersect
question.d: D) and the expected inflation rate is 8 percent a year, the short-run Phillips curve shifts downward

question.q: 27) Refer to Table 28.2.2. The economy's natural unemployment rate is 4 percent. Table 28.2.2 gives some points on the economy's short-run Phillips curve. If the expected inflation rate rises to 8 percent a year, ________.
question.a: A) the long-run Phillips curve shifts leftward
question.b: B) the short-run Phillips curve shifts upward
question.c: C) the short-run Phillips curve shifts downward
question.d: D) Both A and B are correct.
question.e: E) Both A and C are correct.

question.q: 28) Consider the short-run Phillips curve in Canada since the 1960s.
question.a: A) Canada's inflation/unemployment tradeoff is best shown as a series of shifting short-run Phillips curves that sometimes shift upward and sometimes shift downward.
question.b: B) Canada's inflation/unemployment tradeoff is undefined.
question.c: C) Canada's short-run Phillips curve is consistently shifting upward.
question.d: D) Canada's short-run Phillips curve is consistently shifting downward.
question.e: E) Canada's short-run Phillips curve is consistently shifting rightward.

question.q: 1) According to ________, the business cycle is the result of aggregate demand growing at a fluctuating rate.
question.a: A) the Keynesian cycle theory only
question.b: B) only the Keynesian and monetarist cycle theories
question.c: C) the Keynesian, monetarist, and real business cycle theories
question.d: D) the Keynesian, monetarist, and new classical cycle theories

question.q: 2) Which of the following are business cycle theories that regard fluctuations in aggregate demand as the factor that creates business cycles?
question.c: C) I and III
question.d: D) I, II and III

question.q: 3) Which of the following is not a mainstream theory of the business cycle?
question.c: C) New Keynesian cycle theory
question.d: D) Real business cycle theory

question.q: 4) In the Keynesian business cycle theory, business cycles begin with a change in
question.c: C) business confidence.
question.d: D) monetary policy.

question.q: 5) ________ states that the main source of economic fluctuations is fluctuations in business confidence.
question.c: C) Keynesian cycle theory
question.d: D) Monetarist cycle theory

question.q: 6) Refer to Figure 28.3.1. Suppose the economy moves from point A to point C. According to the monetarist theory of the business cycle, what could have caused this movement?
question.a: A) an increase in the money wage rate
question.b: B) an increase in the growth rate of the quantity of money
question.c: C) a decrease in the growth rate of the quantity of money
question.d: D) an increase in uncertainty

question.q: 7) Refer to Figure 28.3.1. Suppose the economy moves from point D to point B. According to the monetarist theory of the business cycle, what could have caused this movement?
question.a: A) a decrease in the money wage rate
question.b: B) an increase in uncertainty about future sales and profits
question.c: C) an increase in the growth rate of the quantity of money
question.d: D) an increase in the money wage rate

question.q: 8) Both new Keynesian and new classical cycle theories claim that
question.a: A) animal spirits can trigger a business cycle.
question.b: B) shifts in the SAS curve are the main impulse for a business cycle.
question.c: C) unexpected changes in aggregate demand trigger a business cycle.
question.d: D) expected changes in the quantity of money can trigger a business cycle.
question.e: E) a change in the price of oil is the major cause of a business cycle.

question.q: 9) The key difference between new classical cycle theory and new Keynesian cycle theory is that the new classical cycle theory believes that ________ while the new Keynesian cycle theory believes that ________.
question.a: A) expected changes in aggregate demand change real GDP; expected changes in aggregate demand do not change real GDP
question.b: B) only unexpected changes in aggregate demand change real GDP; only expected changes in aggregate demand change real GDP
question.c: C) only unexpected changes in aggregate demand change real GDP; both expected and unexpected changes in aggregate demand change real GDP
question.d: D) the short-run aggregate supply curve is horizontal; the short-run aggregate supply curve is vertical.
question.e: E) expected and unexpected changes in aggregate demand change real GDP; only changes in labour productivity change aggregate demand

question.q: 10) The ________ cycle theory states that only unexpected fluctuations in aggregate demand bring fluctuations in real GDP around potential GDP.
question.c: C) Keynesian
question.d: D) monetarist

question.q: 11) In new classical cycle theory, ________ bring fluctuations in real GDP around potential GDP.
question.a: A) unexpected changes in aggregate demand
question.b: B) expected changes in aggregate demand
question.c: C) fluctuations in money growth with rigid wages
question.d: D) fluctuations in investment coupled with rigid wages
question.e: E) expected changes in labour productivity

question.q: 12) The new classical theory argues that the primary factor leading to business cycles is
question.a: A) expected fluctuations in aggregate demand.
question.b: B) expected fluctuations in short-run aggregate supply.
question.c: C) unexpected fluctuations in aggregate demand.
question.d: D) unexpected fluctuations in short-run aggregate supply.
question.e: E) unexpected fluctuations in long-run aggregate supply.

question.q: 13) New Keynesian economists believe that ________ is influenced by ________.
question.a: A) yesterday's money wage rate; today's rational expectations of the money wage
question.b: B) today's money wage rate; yesterday's rational expectations of the price level
question.c: C) yesterday's rational expectations of the price level; today's money wage rate
question.d: D) today's money wage rate; today's rational expectations of the price level
question.e: E) today's money wage rate; animal spirits

question.q: 14) Which business cycle theory emphasizes that, because of previously negotiated wage agreements, both expected and unexpected fluctuations in aggregate demand can change real GDP?
question.a: A) the new classical cycle theory
question.b: B) the new Keynesian cycle theory
question.c: C) Monetarist cycle theory
question.d: D) Keynesian cycle theory

question.q: 15) The factor leading to business cycles in the ________ cycle theory is unexpected fluctuations in aggregate demand while in the ________ cycle theory both unexpected and expected fluctuations in aggregate demand are factors that lead to business cycles.
question.c: C) new Keynesian; Keynesian
question.d: D) monetarist; new Keynesian

question.q: 16) According to ________ theory, a decrease in productivity growth shifts the ________.
question.a: A) real business cycle; AD curve rightward
question.b: B) Keynesian cycle; SAS curve leftward
question.c: C) real business cycle; demand for loanable funds curve leftward
question.d: D) Keynesian cycle; SAS curve rightward
question.e: E) real business cycle; AD curve leftward

question.q: 17) The key ripple effect in real business cycle theory is the ________ decision and it depends on the ________.
question.c: C) what-to-save; nominal interest rate
question.d: D) where-to-work; real wage rate
question.e: E) when-to-work; rigidity of the money wage rate

question.q: 18) According to the real business cycle theory, what effects follow from a change in productivity?
question.c: C) I and III
question.d: D) II and III

question.q: 19) "Intertemporal substitution" in real business cycle theory refers to the change in the ________ as a result of the change in the real interest rate.
question.c: C) supply of labour
question.d: D) consumer demand for goods

question.q: 20) In real business cycle theory, a decrease in productivity leads to all of the following events EXCEPT
question.a: A) a decrease in the demand for labour.
question.b: B) a decrease in the demand for loanable funds.
question.c: C) a rise in the real wage rate.
question.d: D) a fall in the real interest rate.
question.e: E) a decrease in the supply of labour.

question.q: 21) In real business cycle theory, the supply of labour
question.a: A) increases if the nominal interest rate rises.
question.b: B) is independent of the real interest rate.
question.c: C) decreases if the real interest rate rises.
question.d: D) decreases if the real interest rate falls.
question.e: E) decreases if the real wage rate decreases.

question.q: 22) Suppose that a severe shock that decreases the demand for loanable funds hits Canada. Which of the following can we expect to occur according to real business cycle theory?
question.a: A) The real interest rate will fall.
question.b: B) People will work fewer hours.
question.c: C) The real wage rate will fall.
question.d: D) The demand for loanable funds will decrease.
question.e: E) All of the above are true.

question.q: 23) According to real business cycle theory, an increase in productivity ________ the demand for loanable funds, ________ the demand for labour, and ________ the supply of labour. The real interest rate will ________.
question.a: A) increase; increases; does not change; fall
question.b: B) increase; increases; does not change; rise
question.c: C) decrease; decreases; decreases; fall
question.d: D) increases; increases; increases; rise

question.q: 24) According to the real business cycle theory, during a recession the demand for labour ________ and the supply of labour ________.
question.c: C) does not change; decreases
question.d: D) decreases; decreases

question.q: 25) According to real business cycle theory, workers' decisions to work now versus later depend on
question.a: A) the real wage rate today but not the real wage rate in the future.
question.c: C) the real interest rate.
question.d: D) labour productivity.

question.q: 26) Suppose that in response to a decrease in real interest rates, a person decides to reduce his supply of labour today and increase it in the future. This behaviour is most consistent with the
question.c: C) new Keynesian cycle theory.
question.d: D) real business cycle theory.

question.q: 27) According to real business cycle theory, if the Bank of Canada increases the quantity of money when real GDP decreases, real GDP
question.a: A) will increase but only temporarily.
question.c: C) and the price level will both be unaffected.
question.d: D) will be unaffected, but the price level will rise.
question.e: E) will decrease due to the inefficiencies introduced into production as a result.

question.q: 28) Suppose that the business cycle in Canada is best described by RBC theory.
question.c: C) higher; larger; large
question.d: D) lower; larger; large

question.q: 29) According to mainstream business cycle theory, ________ grows at a steady rate and ________ grows at a fluctuating rate.
question.a: A) aggregate demand; long-run aggregate supply
question.c: C) potential GDP; short-run aggregate supply
question.d: D) short-run aggregate supply; long-run aggregate supply
question.e: E) short-run aggregate supply; aggregate demand

question.q: 30) In real business cycle theory, ________ are the main source of economic fluctuations.
question.a: A) unexpected changes in government expenditure
question.c: C) random fluctuations in productivity
question.d: D) unexpected changes in the full-employment quantity of labour
question.e: E) changes in the quantity of money

question.q: 31) In real business cycle theory, the supply of labour
question.a: A) increases if the real interest rate falls.
question.b: B) increases if the real interest rate rises.
question.c: C) increases if the demand for labour decreases.
question.d: D) is not influenced by changes in the real interest rate.
question.e: E) increases if the demand for loanable funds decreases.

question.q: 32) According to real business cycle theory, a fall in the real interest rate ________ the supply of labour and ________ employment.
question.c: C) decreases; increases
question.d: D) increases; decreases
question.e: E) does not change; does not change

question.q: 33) Real business cycle theorists believe that the intertemporal substitution effect ________. Many other economists believe that the intertemporal substitution effect ________.
question.c: C) occurs in the money market; occurs in the labour market
question.d: D) occurs in the labour market; occurs in the money market

question.q: 1) If revenues exceed outlays, the government's budget balance is ________, and the government has a budget ________.
question.c: C) positive; deficit
question.d: D) negative; surplus

question.q: 2) If outlays exceed revenues, the government's budget balance is ________, and the government has a budget ________.
question.c: C) positive; deficit
question.d: D) negative; surplus

question.q: 3) Government debt is
question.a: A) equal to revenues minus outlays.
question.c: C) a phenomena that occurs only during times of war.
question.d: D) the total amount of government borrowing.
question.e: E) the result of a rising price level.
