question.a: A) total revenues have no strong trends.
question.b: B) revenues include corporate income taxes, personal income taxes; indirect taxes and investment income.
question.c: C) the main source of fluctuations in revenues is corporate income taxes.
question.d: D) indirect taxes decreased during the 1990s due to the introduction of the GST.
question.e: E) total revenues increased through the 1960s and 1980s.

question.q: 5) All of the following statements are true except
question.a: A) the three components of government outlays are transfer payments, expenditures on goods and services, and debt interest.
question.b: B) debt interest has been steadily increasing since 1960.
question.c: C) expenditures on goods and services have a downward trend.
question.d: D) outlays increased steadily from 1971 through 1985.
question.e: E) transfer payments decreased sharply during the 1990s.

question.q: 6) Choose the correct statement
question.a: A) The federal government debt was 5 percent of GDP in 1970.
question.b: B) The debt-to-GDP ratio increased slightly during the 2008-2009 recession.
question.c: C) The debt-to-GDP ratio increased from 1974 through 1997, and then began to decrease.
question.d: D) The government debt increases when the government has a budget deficit.

question.q: 7) During the 1980s and 1990s in Canada,
question.a: A) investment income as a percentage of GDP increased.
question.b: B) indirect taxes as a percentage of GDP increased steadily.
question.c: C) personal income taxes as a percentage of GDP decreased.
question.d: D) total revenues as a percentage of GDP increased by over 5 percent.

question.q: 8) The main components of government revenues are
question.a: A) transfer payments, investment income, and indirect taxes.
question.b: B) personal income taxes, corporate income taxes, indirect taxes, and investment income.
question.c: C) debt interest, expenditures on goods and services, and income taxes.
question.d: D) corporate income taxes, indirect taxes, and transfer payments.
question.e: E) debt interest, corporate income taxes, and income taxes.

question.q: 9) The category of federal government revenues that fluctuates the most is
question.c: C) personal income taxes.
question.d: D) debt interest.

question.q: 10) Suppose the government starts with a debt of $0. Then in year 1, there is a deficit of $100 billion, in year 2 there is a deficit of $60 billion, in year 3 there is a surplus of $40 billion, and in year 4 there is a deficit of $20 billion. What is government debt at the end of year 4?
question.c: C) $180 billion.
question.d: D) Somewhat greater than $220 billion, depending on the interest rate.
question.e: E) Somewhat greater than $140 billion, depending on the interest rate.

question.q: 11) Which of the following would not increase an existing budget deficit?
question.a: A) an increase in interest on the government debt
question.b: B) an increase in government expenditures on goods and services
question.c: C) an increase in government transfer payments
question.d: D) an increase in indirect taxes
question.e: E) a decrease in investment income

question.q: 12) Fiscal policy is
question.a: A) the use of the federal budget to achieve macroeconomic objectives.
question.b: B) any policy by the Bank of Canada.
question.c: C) budgeting policy by aggregate households.
question.d: D) any attempt by the federal government or Bank of Canada to control inflation.
question.e: E) effective only when the federal government has a budget surplus.

question.q: 13) Which of the following is not a source of government revenues?
question.c: C) corporate income taxes
question.d: D) indirect taxes

question.q: 14) Which of the following is a government outlay?
question.c: C) debt interest
question.d: D) indirect taxes

question.q: 15) As a percentage of provincial GDP, provincial government outlays are highest in
question.c: C) the Yukon Territory.
question.d: D) Nunavut.

question.q: 16) What are the main categories of the federal government outlays?
question.a: A) transfer payments, expenditures on goods and services, and debt interest
question.b: B) indirect taxes, farmers' subsidies, and debt interest
question.c: C) personal income taxes, expenditures on goods and services, and debt interest
question.d: D) investment income, debt interest and transfer payments

question.q: 17) Outlays as a percentage of provincial GDP are the highest in ________, whereas the largest transfers from the federal government are made to ________.
question.a: A) Ontario; Northern Canada and the Atlantic provinces
question.b: B) British Columbia; Northern Canada and the Atlantic provinces
question.c: C) Alberta; Northern Canada and the Atlantic provinces
question.d: D) Northern Canada; Northern Canada and the Atlantic provinces
question.e: E) Northern Canada and the Atlantic provinces; Quebec

question.q: 18) The government of Ricardia's budget lists the following projected revenues and outlays: $25 million in personal income taxes, $15 million in corporate income taxes, $5 million in indirect taxes, $2 million in investment income, $30 million in transfer payments, $12 million in government expenditure, and $8 million in debt interest. Ricardia has a government budget
question.c: C) surplus of $13 million.
question.d: D) deficit of $13 million.

question.q: 19) The largest source of revenues for the federal government is
question.b: B) expenditures on goods and services.
question.c: C) personal income taxes.
question.d: D) corporate income taxes.
question.e: E) indirect taxes such as the GST.

question.q: 20) Prior to World War II, the purpose of the federal budget was to ________.
question.b: B) achieve macroeconomic objectives such as full employment and price level stability
question.c: C) finance the business of government
question.d: D) provide incentives to encourage investment
question.e: E) oversee revenue equalization among the provinces

question.q: 21) Canada's government debt
question.a: A) is smaller than the value of the public capital stock so Canada's debt has not financed public consumption expenditure.
question.b: B) is larger than the value of the public capital stock so some of Canada's debt has financed public consumption expenditure.
question.c: C) equals the value of the public capital stock.
question.d: D) has risen every year since 1975.
question.e: E) is smaller than the value of the public capital stock so some of Canada's debt has financed public consumption expenditure.

question.q: 22) The Federal Budget of 2011-12 projected ________.
question.c: C) a government budget deficit
question.d: D) a decreasing government debt
question.e: E) Both A and D are correct.

question.q: 1) An increase in income taxes
question.a: A) does not affect potential GDP because potential GDP depends on technology only.
question.b: B) does not affect potential GDP as long as the economy's endowments of resources and the state of technology remain unchanged.
question.c: C) increases potential GDP because workers have to work longer hours to maintain the same standard of living before the tax increase.
question.d: D) decreases potential GDP because workers' incentives to work are weakened.
question.e: E) decreases potential GDP because real GDP decreases when households have less disposable income to spend.

question.q: 2) A tax cut on capital income
question.a: A) does not affect potential GDP because the interest rate affects aggregate expenditure only.
question.b: B) does not affect potential GDP because it has no impact on the supply of labour.
question.c: C) increases potential GDP because workers have greater incentives to work.
question.d: D) increases potential GDP because the supply of loanable funds increases.
question.e: E) increases potential GDP because households have more disposable income to spend.

question.q: 3) Consider all the effects of fiscal policy. A cut in the income tax
question.a: A) shifts the AD curve rightward but does not shift either the LAS or SAS curve.
question.b: B) shifts the AD, SAS, and LAS curves rightward.
question.c: C) shifts the SAS curve rightward but does not shift either the AD or LAS curve.
question.d: D) shifts both the SAS and LAS curves rightward but does not shift the AD curve.
question.e: E) shifts the LAS curve rightward but does not shift either the AD or SAS curve.

question.q: 4) Consider all the effects on fiscal policy. A cut in the tax on capital income
question.a: A) shifts the AD curve rightward.
question.b: B) shifts the SAS curve rightward.
question.c: C) shifts the LAS curve rightward.
question.d: D) all of the above.

question.q: 5) Consider all the effects of fiscal policy. An income tax cut
question.a: A) increases both real GDP and the price level.
question.b: B) increases real GDP but decreases the price level.
question.c: C) increases real GDP but leaves the price level unchanged.
question.d: D) increases real GDP and the price level may rise or fall.
question.e: E) does not change real GDP or the price level.

question.q: 6) An income tax cut that provides a greater incentive to work than an alternative tax cut will result in comparatively
question.a: A) higher long-run real GDP and a higher price level.
question.b: B) higher long-run real GDP and a lower price level.
question.c: C) the same level of long-run real GDP and price level.
question.d: D) the same level of long-run real GDP and a higher price level.
question.e: E) the same level of long-run real GDP and a lower price level.

question.q: 7) If the nominal interest rate is 11%, the inflation rate is 4% and the tax rate is 25%, what is the real after-tax interest rate?
8) The Laffer Curve has been criticized by mainstream economists because
question.a: A) there is no theoretical possibility of higher tax rates leading to lower tax revenues.
question.b: B) higher tax rates do not create negative incentive effects.
question.c: C) tax cuts are just spent, not saved as predicted by the theory.
question.d: D) savers look only at real interest rates, not nominal interest rates.
question.e: E) empirically, tax cuts have not led to higher tax revenues.

question.q: 9) An income tax ________ potential GDP by shifting the labour ________ curve ________.
question.c: C) increases; supply; rightward
question.d: D) decreases; supply; leftward
question.e: E) increases; supply curve and labour demand curve; rightward

question.q: 10) If we compare Canada to France and the United Kingdom, Canada's tax wedge is ________ the French tax wedge and ________ the U.K. tax wedge.
question.c: C) smaller than; smaller than
question.d: D) larger than; larger than

question.q: 11) The difference between the before-tax and after-tax rates is the
question.c: C) tax wedge.
question.d: D) taxation penalty.

question.q: 12) If we compare the United States to France, we see that potential GDP per person in France is ________ than that in the United States because the French tax wedge is ________ than the U.S. tax wedge.
question.c: C) less; larger
question.d: D) less; smaller

question.q: 13) Suppose the tax rate on interest income is 50 percent, the real interest rate is 3 percent, and the inflation rate is 4 percent. The real after-tax interest rate is
question.c: C) 3.0 percent.
question.d: D) 4.0 percent.

question.q: 14) Suppose the tax rate on interest income is 25 percent, the real interest rate is 4 percent, and the inflation rate is 4 percent. The real after-tax interest rate is
question.c: C) 4.0 percent.
question.d: D) 2.0 percent.

question.q: 15) The Laffer curve is the relationship between
question.a: A) government expenditure and potential GDP.
question.b: B) the tax rate and potential GDP.
question.c: C) tax revenue and potential GDP.
question.d: D) the tax rate and the amount of tax revenue.

question.q: 16) According to the Laffer curve, raising the tax rate
question.a: A) always increases the amount of tax revenue.
question.b: B) always decreases the amount of tax revenue.
question.c: C) does not change the amount of tax revenue.
question.d: D) might increase, decrease, or not change the amount of tax revenue.
question.e: E) has no effect on the amount of tax revenue.

question.q: 17) The Laffer curve shows that increasing ________ increases ________ when ________ low.
question.a: A) tax revenue; potential GDP; tax revenue is
question.b: B) the tax rate; tax revenue; the tax rate is
question.c: C) potential GDP; tax revenue; tax revenue is
question.d: D) government outlays; the budget deficit; government expenditure is
question.e: E) investment; potential GDP; the interest rate is

question.q: 18) An increase in the tax on capital income ________ the supply of loanable funds and ________ investment.
question.c: C) decreases; increases
question.d: D) decreases; decreases
question.e: E) decreases the demand for loanable funds; decreases or increases

question.q: 19) Suppose that in China, investment is $400 billion, saving is $400 billion, tax revenues are $500 billion, exports are $300 billion, and imports are $200 billion. The government budget ________ the supply of loanable funds, which ________ the real interest rate and ________ investment.
question.c: C) surplus increases; lowers; increases
question.d: D) deficit decreases; raises; decreases

question.q: 20) Suppose that in China, investment is $400 billion, saving is $400 billion, tax revenues are $500 billion, exports are $300 billion, and imports are $200 billion. ________ in government expenditure or ________ in taxes will further increase China's budget ________, increase investment and speed economic growth.
question.a: A) A decrease; an increase; surplus
question.b: B) An increase; a decreases; deficit
question.c: C) An increase; an increase; surplus
question.d: D) A decrease; a decrease; deficit
question.e: E) A decrease; an increase; deficit

question.q: 21) The government is proposing to increase the tax rate on labour income and asks you to report on the supply-side effects of such an action. According to the research of Edward C. Prescott, cross-country evidence for Canada, the United States, the United Kingdom, and France shows all of the following except ________.

question.b: B) from left to right along the revenues curve.
question.c: C) from right to left along the outlays curve.
question.d: D) from left to right along the outlays curve.

question.b: B) a movement from left to right along the outlays curve.

question.c: C) shift upwards in the revenues curve.
question.d: D) shift upwards in the the outlays curve.

question.b: B) is triggered by the state of the economy.
question.c: C) involves only a change in government outlays and no change in revenues.
question.d: D) involves only a change in personal income tax rates.
question.e: E) occurs during recessions but not during expansions.

question.d: D) increases long-run aggregate supply.

question.c: C) changes in government expenditure do not directly affect consumption.
question.d: D) tax rates are the same regardless of income levels.

question.q: 33) An advantage of automatic stabilizers over discretionary fiscal policy is that
question.a: A) automatic stabilizers are not subject to all the same time lags that discretionary fiscal policy is.
question.b: B) automatic stabilizers can be easily fine-tuned to move the economy to full employment.
question.c: C) only Parliament is involved in implementing automatic stabilizers instead of both Parliament and the Bank of Canada.
question.d: D) automatic stabilizers require only a simple majority of Parliament to pass whereas discretionary fiscal policy requires a two-thirds majority to pass.
question.e: E) automatic stabilizers work in recessions and expansions but discretionary fiscal policy works only in a recession.

question.c: C) $60 billion.
question.d: D) $50 billion

question.c: C) surplus of $4 trillion; deficit of $1 trillion
question.d: D) surplus of $3 trillion; surplus of $2 trillion
question.e: E) deficit of $4 trillion; surplus of $1 trillion

question.b: B) Eliminating an inflationary gap is very simple - calculate the size of the gap and the size of the multiplier, then change government expenditure for an immediate decrease in real GDP.
question.c: C) When an economy is in an above full-employment equilibrium, an equal decrease in government expenditure and autonomous taxes cannot return the economy to full employment.
question.d: D) When an economy is in an above full-employment equilibrium, an increase in taxes will decrease aggregate demand, but because the autonomous tax multiplier is smaller than the government expenditure multiplier, the economy will not return to potential GDP.

question.q: 38) The economy is in a recession and the recessionary gap is large. Discretionary fiscal policy that might occur is ________. Automatic fiscal policy that might occur is ________. question.a: A) an increase in transfer payments and a fall in taxes; an increase in government expenditure and a cut in taxes; increase in transfer payments and taxes
question.b: B) a decrease in transfer payments and an increase in taxes; a decrease in government expenditure and an increase in taxes; decrease in transfer payments and taxes
question.c: C) an increase in government expenditure and a cut in taxes; an increase in transfer payments and a fall in taxes; increase in government expenditure and taxes
question.d: D) a decrease in government expenditure and an increase in taxes; a decrease in transfer payments and an increase in taxes; decrease in government expenditure and taxes

question.q: 39) If real GDP is less than potential GDP, which of the following fiscal policies would increase real GDP?
question.b: B) an increase in government expenditures
question.c: C) a fall in the interest rate
question.d: D) Both A and B are correct
question.e: E) Both B and C are correct.

question.q: 40) The use of fiscal policy is limited because
question.c: C) of impact lag.
question.d: D) all of the above

question.b: B) Tax cuts strengthen the incentive to work and to invest.

question.e: E) Both A and B are correct.

question.c: C) a structural surplus and a cyclical deficit

question.q: 1) Core inflation is the percentage change in
question.a: A) the Consumer Price Index including the eight most volatile prices.
question.b: B) an inflation rate that ranges between 1 percent and 3 percent annually.
question.c: C) the Consumer Price Index excluding the eight most volatile prices.
question.d: D) the average of the 8 most volatile prices in the Consumer Price Index.
question.e: E) the target midpoint inflation rate of 2 percent per year.

question.q: 2) How is responsibility for monetary policy set forth in Canada?
question.a: A) The Canadian Government administers monetary policy through the office of the Minister of Finance.
question.b: B) The Bank of Canada administers monetary policy as directed by the Minister of Finance.
question.c: C) The Bank of Canada Act places responsibility for the conduct of monetary policy on the Bank's Governing Council.
question.d: D) The Prime Minister bears ultimate responsibility for monetary policy.

question.q: 3) Which of the following benefits flow from the application of an inflation-control target?
question.a: A) If actual inflation exceeds the target range, the Bank of Canada can induce a recession to correct the matter.
question.b: B) The monetary authorities can change the target range whenever they feel it is appropriate.
question.c: C) People can make decisions with an understanding that inflation rates will remain relatively low.
question.d: D) Financial market traders have a clearer understanding of the Bank of Canada's intentions.

question.q: 4) Which of the following issues is a concern that critics express about the use of an inflation-control target?
question.a: A) The policy control rests in the hands of civil servants rather than in the hands of elected officials.
question.b: B) The policy control rests in the hands of elected officials rather than in the hands of civil servants.
question.c: C) It encourages a focus on real GDP growth at the expense of employment and of inflation.
question.d: D) It encourages a focus on inflation at the expense of employment and real GDP growth.
question.e: E) Monetary policy tends to be sensitive to the state of employment while focusing on inflation control targets.

question.q: 5) Who are the members of the Bank of Canada's Governing Council?
question.a: A) The Ministers of Finance from each province as well as the Federal Minister of Finance.
question.b: B) The Prime Minister, the Minister of Finance, and the Bank's Governor.
question.c: C) The Minister of Finance, the Governor, and four Deputy Governors.
question.d: D) The Bank's Governor, Senior Deputy Governor, and four Deputy governors who are appointed by the Prime Minister to represent the public interest.
question.e: E) The Bank's Governor, Senior Deputy Governor, and four Deputy Governors.

question.q: 6) How is consultation between the Bank of Canada and the Government of Canada on monetary policy arranged?
question.a: A) Consultations are arranged at the discretion of the Minister of Finance.
question.b: B) No consultation is required or needed.
question.c: C) The Bank of Canada Act requires regular consultations between the Governor and the Minister of Finance.
question.d: D) Consultations are arranged at the discretion of the Governor of the Bank of Canada.
question.e: E) Consultations are arranged through the Parliamentary Committee on Finance.

question.q: 7) Why does the Bank of Canada pay close attention to the core inflation rate in addition to the overall CPI inflation rate?
question.a: A) The core rate is more volatile and therefore a better predictor of trend inflation.
question.b: B) The core rate includes taxes, while the overall CPI rate does not.
question.c: C) The core rate has a lower average value and therefore makes the Bank look better.
question.d: D) The core rate is less volatile and a better predictor of future CPI inflation.
question.e: E) The core rate excludes eight volatile prices and is therefore more likely to stay within the target band.

question.q: 8) One criticism of the Bank of Canada's focus on an inflation control target is that
question.a: A) if inflation falls below the target range a recession will result.
question.b: B) if inflation edges above the target range, the Bank decreases aggregate demand and could create a recession.
question.c: C) the Bank pays too much attention to unemployment and real GDP growth and not enough to inflation control.
question.d: D) it makes setting expectations of inflation difficult.
question.e: E) the Bank rarely achieves its target.

question.q: 9) The objective of the Bank of Canada's monetary policy is
question.a: A) to keep the unemployment rate below 5 percent, the inflation rate between 1 and 3 percent a year, and long-term real GDP growth above 4 percent a year.
question.b: B) to control the quantity of money and interest rates to avoid inflation and when possible prevent excessive swings in real GDP growth and unemployment.
question.c: C) to keep the unemployment rate below 5 percent, the inflation rate between 1 and 3 percent a year, and long-term interest rates below 4 percent a year.
question.d: D) to keep the labour force participation rate above 80 percent, the inflation rate below 2 percent a year, and the exchange rate fluctuating by less than 3 percent a year.
question.e: E) to keep the overnight loans rate below 2 percent a year and the unemployment rate at its natural rate.

question.q: 10) The two parts of the inflation-control target are that the inflation-control target range will be ________ percent a year, and policy will aim at keeping the trend of inflation at ________ percent a year.
11) Choose the statement that is incorrect.
question.a: A) The actual path of the CPI was on trend from 1995 through 1998.
question.b: B) Between 1999 and 2001, the CPI moved below the 2 percent trend line.
question.c: C) The actual path of the CPI was below trend from 2001 through 2007.
question.d: D) The Bank of Canada and the Government of Canada agree that the inflation-control target range will be 1 percent to 3 percent.
question.e: E) All of the above statements are incorrect.

question.q: 12) The current Governor of the Bank of Canada is
question.c: C) David Dodge.
question.d: D) Paul Martin.

question.q: 1) As the sole issuer of Canadian money, the Bank of Canada can set any one of three variables:
question.a: A) the monetary base, the exchange rate, and the short-term interest rate.
question.b: B) the money base, the interest rate, and the unemployment rate.
question.c: C) the rate of inflation, the interest rate, and the unemployment rate.
question.d: D) the exchange rate, the interest rate, and the inflation rate.
question.e: E) the inflation rate, the unemployment rate, and the real economic growth rate.

question.q: 2) What is the overnight loans rate?
question.a: A) The percentage change in the volume of loans that take place overnight.
question.b: B) The interest rate that the Bank of Canada charges chartered banks.
question.c: C) The interest rate on loans that the big banks make to each other.
question.d: D) The volume of loans that take place during the night.
question.e: E) The interest rate that the Bank of Canada pays when it buys securities from chartered banks.

question.q: 3) How can the Bank of Canada use the bank rate to regulate the overnight loans rate?
question.a: A) The overnight loans rate is set at a quarter percentage point above the bank rate, which in turn is set by the Bank of Canada.
question.b: B) The bank rate is set at the settlement balances rate plus 0.25 percentage points.
question.c: C) The bank rate is set at 0.25 percentage points below the settlement balances rate, which is used to determine the overnight loans rate.
question.d: D) The overnight loans rate is set at 25 basis points above the bank rate.
question.e: E) The bank rate is set at the target overnight rate plus 0.25 percentage points.

question.q: 4) 25 basis points is
question.a: A) a quarter of a percentage point.
question.b: B) a quarter of the Bank of Canada's target inflation rate.
question.c: C) the spread between the savings rate and the lending rate.
question.d: D) the spread between the bank rate and the settlement balances rate.
question.e: E) the gap by which real GDP exceeds potential GDP.

question.q: 5) The operating band is
question.a: A) the interest rate that is established through an open market operation.
question.b: B) the target overnight interest rate plus or minus 25 basis points.
question.c: C) the target inflation rate plus or minus a quarter of a percentage point.
question.d: D) a half percentage point range in the target inflation rate.
question.e: E) the range between the lending rate and the borrowing rate.

question.q: 6) The settlement balances rate is the
question.a: A) proportion of outstanding loans from chartered banks that are resolved.
question.b: B) interest rate that the Bank of Canada charges the big banks on loans.
question.c: C) interest rate paid to chartered banks on their reserves held at the Bank of Canada.
question.d: D) ratio of the value securities sold by the Bank of Canada to securities outstanding.
question.e: E) proportion of overnight inter-bank loans that are resolved.

question.q: 7) The policy tools used by the Bank of Canada include
question.a: A) prime rate and bank rate.
question.b: B) the operating band and open market operations.
question.c: C) open market operations and prime rate.
question.d: D) prime rate and the exchange rate.
question.e: E) the exchange rate and open market operations.

question.q: 8) How does the Bank of Canada set the bank rate?
question.a: A) The Bank of Canada does not determine the bank rate.
question.b: B) The bank rate is set at a quarter percentage point above the prime lending rate.
question.c: C) The bank rate is set at a quarter percentage point above the target overnight loans rate.
question.d: D) The bank rate is set at a quarter percentage point below the overnight loans rate.
question.e: E) The bank rate is set at 25 basis points above the operating band.

question.q: 9) An open market operation
question.a: A) refers to the Bank of Canada's sales and purchases of corporate stock.
question.b: B) can change bank deposits but cannot alter the quantity of money.
question.c: C) is the purchase or sale of government of Canada securities by the Bank of Canada from or to a chartered bank or the public.
question.d: D) refers to loans made by the Bank of Canada to chartered banks.
question.e: E) refers to the purchase or sale of Canadian currency in exchange for foreign currency.

question.q: 10) The bank rate is the interest rate
question.a: A) banks charge their very best loan customers.
question.b: B) banks pay on term deposits.
question.c: C) the Bank of Canada pays on reserves held by banks.
question.d: D) the Bank of Canada charges when it lends reserves to the big banks.
question.e: E) received for holding Government of Canada Treasury Bills.

question.q: 11) The overnight loans rate is the interest rate
question.a: A) banks charge their best loan customers.
question.b: B) banks pay on term deposits.
question.c: C) the Bank of Canada pays on reserves held by banks.
question.d: D) the Bank of Canada charges when it lends reserves to banks.
question.e: E) on overnight loans that the big banks make to each other.

question.q: 12) The Bank of Canada can lower the overnight loans rate by
question.c: C) raising the settlement balances rate.
question.d: D) lowering the settlement balances rate.

question.q: 13) The sale of government bonds by the Bank of Canada
question.c: C) increases the quantity of money.
question.d: D) increases the banks' loans to the public.

question.q: 14) The purchase of government bonds by the Bank of Canada
question.c: C) decreases the price of bonds.
question.d: D) fights inflation.

question.q: 15) If the Bank of Canada aims to lower the overnight rate, it will
question.a: A) lower the bank rate and settlement balances rate, as well as buy government securities.
question.b: B) lower the bank rate, increase the settlement balances rate, as well as buy government securities.
question.c: C) lower the bank rate and settlement balances rate, as well as sell government securities.
question.d: D) raise the bank rate and settlement balances rate, as well as buy government securities.
question.e: E) raise the bank rate and settlement balances rate, as well as sell government securities.

question.q: 16) In an open market operation aimed at increasing expenditure, the Bank of Canada
question.a: A) sells government bonds, decreasing bank reserves, decreasing lending, decreasing the overnight rate.
question.b: B) sells government bonds, decreasing bank reserves, decreasing lending, increasing the overnight rate.

question.d: D) all of the above

question.q: 34) Canada produces both lumber and wine. Canada exports lumber and imports wine. The rest of the world imports Canadian lumber and exports wine to Canada. If Canada did not trade with the rest of the world, then the equilibrium price of lumber would be ________ in Canada than the rest of the world, and the equilibrium price of wine would be ________ in Canada than the rest of the world.
question.c: C) higher; higher
question.d: D) lower; lower
question.e: E) sometimes higher and sometimes lower; always higher

question.q: 35) Canada produces both lumber and wine. Canada exports lumber and imports wine. The rest of the world imports Canadian lumber and exports wine to Canada. Canada has a comparative advantage in producing ________. The rest of the world has a comparative advantage in producing ________.
question.c: C) wine; wine
question.d: D) lumber; lumber
question.e: E) both lumber and wine; neither lumber nor wine

question.q: 36) Suppose that the world price of oats is 30 cents a kilogram. Canada does not trade internationally, and the equilibrium price of oats in Canada is 40 cents a kilogram. Canada then begins to trade internationally. The price of oats in Canada ________. Canadian consumers buy ________ oats. Canadian firms produce ________ oats. Canada ________ oats.
question.c: C) falls; more; less; imports
question.d: D) rises; more; less; exports

question.q: 37) In one year, Brazil exported more than 1.8 billion kilograms of coffee to the rest of the world. We can conclude that
question.a: A) Brazil has comparative advantage in coffee production.
question.b: B) Brazil has an absolute advantage in coffee production.
question.c: C) the rest of the world has a comparative advantage in coffee production.
question.d: D) the rest of the world has an absolute advantage in coffee production.
question.e: E) Brazil's government has placed a tariff on coffee.

question.q: 38) Choose the correct statement.
question.a: A) Exports include goods and services.
question.b: B) Imports include goods but not services.
question.c: C) Imports include services but not goods.
question.d: D) Exports include goods but not services.
question.e: E) Exports include services but not goods.

question.q: 39) In one year, Brazil exported more than 1.8 billion kilograms of coffee to the rest of the world. We can conclude that
question.a: A) Brazil's coffee producers lose from this trade.
question.b: B) coffee consumers in the rest of the world lose from this trade.
question.c: C) Brazil's coffee consumers lose from this trade.
question.d: D) coffee producers in the rest of the world gain from this trade.
question.e: E) Brazil's government loses from this trade.

question.q: 40) In a market that moves from a situation of no trade to a situation where a good is exported, the price of the good ________ and the quantity produced by the domestic industry ________.
question.c: C) does not change; increases
question.d: D) does not change; decreases

question.q: 41) In a market that moves from a situation of no trade to a situation where a good is imported, the price of the good ________ and the quantity produced by the domestic industry ________.
question.c: C) does not change; increases
question.d: D) does not change; decreases

question.q: 1) A tariff is a tax that is imposed by the ________ country when an ________ good crosses its international boundary.
question.c: C) exporting; exported
question.d: D) importing; imported
question.e: E) importing or exporting; imported or exported

question.q: 2) A tax that is imposed by the importing country when an imported good crosses its international boundary is called
question.c: C) a voluntary export restraint.
question.d: D) a tariff.

question.q: 3) Tariffs and import quotas differ in that
question.a: A) one is a form of trade restriction, while the other is not.
question.b: B) one is a tax, while the other is a limit.
question.c: C) one is imposed by the government, while the other is imposed by the private sector.
question.d: D) one is legal, while the other is not.
question.e: E) one increases imports, while the other decreases imports.

question.q: 4) Tariffs and import quotas both result in
question.a: A) lower levels of domestic production.
question.b: B) the domestic government gaining revenue.
question.c: C) lower levels of imports.
question.d: D) higher levels of domestic consumption.

question.q: 5) If Canada imposes a tariff on imported cars,
question.a: A) Canada's demand curve for cars shifts rightward.
question.b: B) Canada's demand curve for cars shifts leftward.
question.c: C) Canada's supply curve of cars shifts rightward.
question.d: D) Canada's supply curve of cars shifts leftward.
question.e: E) the price in Canada rises but neither Canada's demand curve nor Canada's supply curve shifts.

question.q: 6) Which of the following statements concerning tariffs is NOT true?
question.a: A) A tariff increases domestic production.
question.b: B) A tariff creates revenue for the government.
question.c: C) A tariff decreases international trade.
question.d: D) A tariff leaves the price of imports unchanged.
question.e: E) A tariff decreases domestic consumption.

question.q: 7) If a country imposes a tariff on an imported good, the tariff ________ the price in the importing country and ________ the quantity of imports.
question.c: C) lowers; does not change
question.d: D) lowers; increases

question.q: 8) A tariff imposed by Canada on Japanese cars ________ the price of cars in Canada and ________ the quantity of Japanese cars imported into Canada.
question.c: C) lowers; increases
question.d: D) lowers; decreases

question.q: 9) If Canada imposes a tariff of $1 per imported shirt, the tariff
question.a: A) raises the price of a shirt paid by Canadian consumers.
question.c: C) decreases imports of shirts into Canada.
question.d: D) creates a social loss.

question.q: 10) If Canada imposes a tariff on imported steel, the tariff
question.a: A) raises the Canadian price of imported steel.
question.b: B) decreases the Canadian production of steel.
question.c: C) increases the total Canadian consumption of steel.
question.d: D) decreases employment in the Canadian steel industry.

question.q: 11) Suppose the country of Mooland imposes tariffs on imported beef from the country of Aqualand. As a result of the tariffs, the
question.a: A) price of beef in Mooland falls.
question.b: B) quantity of beef exported by Mooland increases.
question.c: C) quantity of beef imported by Mooland decreases.
question.d: D) quantity of beef imported by Mooland increases.
question.e: E) price of beef in Mooland does not change.

question.q: 12) Reducing a tariff ________ the domestic production of the good and ________ the total domestic consumption of the good.
question.c: C) decreases; increases
question.d: D) decreases; decreases

question.q: 13) Increasing a tariff ________ the domestic quantity consumed of the good and ________ the domestic production of the good.
question.c: C) decreases; increases
question.d: D) decreases; decreases

question.q: 14) Tariffs
question.b: B) generate revenue for the government.
question.c: C) encourage domestic consumers to buy more imports.
question.d: D) encourage domestic producers to produce less.

question.q: 15) Canada imports cars from Japan. If Canada imposes a tariff on cars imported from Japan, Canadian
question.a: A) consumers will lose and Japanese producers will gain.
question.b: B) tariff revenue will equal the loss of Canadian consumers.
question.c: C) consumers will lose and Canadian producers will gain.
question.d: D) car manufacturers will gain revenue equal to the revenue lost by Japanese car manufacturers.
question.e: E) producers will lose and Japanese consumers will gain.

question.q: 16) A Canadian tariff imposed on items that can be produced more cheaply abroad
question.a: A) benefits Canadians by making these goods cheaper.
question.b: B) makes the goods more expensive in foreign markets.
question.c: C) creates a social loss.
question.d: D) equalizes the cost of production between Canada and foreign producers.

question.q: 17) The winners from a tariff on imports are
question.c: C) consumers only.
question.d: D) consumers, producers, and government.

question.q: 18) A tariff is imposed on a good. This ________ the quantity supplied, ________ the quantity demanded, and ________ the price in the home country.
question.b: B) increases; does not change; does not change
question.c: C) increases; increases; raises
question.d: D) increases; decreases; lowers

question.q: 19) Refer to Figure 31.2.1, with the tariff Canadians buy ________ million shirts per year.
20) Refer to Figure 31.2.1, with the tariff Canada imports ________ million shirts per year.
21) Refer to Figure 31.2.1, the tariff ________ Canada's imports of shirts by ________ million shirts per year.
question.c: C) increases; 8
question.d: D) increases; 4

question.q: 22) Refer to Figure 31.2.1, the tariff ________ the domestic production of shirts in Canada by ________ per year.
question.c: C) increases; 4 million
question.d: D) decreases; 8 million

question.q: 23) Refer to Figure 31.2.1, the Canadian government's revenue from the tariff is ________.
question.c: C) $128 million
question.d: D) $48 million

question.q: 24) Of the following, in which decade were Canada's tariffs at their lowest level?
25) An import quota is
question.a: A) a tariff that is a fixed percentage of the price of a good.
question.b: B) a tariff that is a fixed dollar amount per unit of a good.
question.c: C) an agreed upon price for a good to be imported at a specified future date.
question.d: D) a restriction that specifies the maximum amount of a good that may be imported.
question.e: E) the same as an export subsidy.

question.q: 26) ________ specifies the maximum amount of a good that may be imported in a given period of time.
question.c: C) A trade restriction
question.d: D) An import quota

question.q: 27) Import quotas
question.a: A) are the same as tariffs.
question.b: B) are not used by Canada.
question.c: C) set the minimum percentage of the value of a product that must consist of imported components.
question.d: D) benefit society.
question.e: E) set the maximum number of units of a good that can be imported in a given time period.

question.q: 28) An import quota is a
question.a: A) tariff imposed on goods that are dumped in the country.
question.b: B) law that prevents ecologically damaging goods from being imported into a country.
question.c: C) market-imposed balancing factor that keeps prices of imports and exports in equilibrium.
question.d: D) government-imposed restriction on the quantity of a specific good that can be imported.
question.e: E) tax in an international market.

question.q: 29) An import quota directly restricts ________ and is designed to protect domestic ________.
question.c: C) imports; consumers only
question.d: D) imports; producers only

question.q: 30) Import quotas ________ the price of imported goods and ________ the quantity consumed in the country imposing the quota.
question.c: C) lower; increase
question.d: D) lower; decrease

question.q: 31) If a government imposes a quota on imports of a popular doll, the price of the doll in the country ________ and the quantity purchased in the country ________.
question.c: C) falls; increases
question.d: D) falls; decreases

question.q: 32) A key difference between tariffs and import quotas is that
question.a: A) consumers are hurt with import quotas but not with tariffs.
question.b: B) consumers are hurt with tariffs but not with import quotas.
question.c: C) the government receives revenue with a tariff, but the importer makes a profit with an import quota.
question.d: D) the government receives revenue with an import quota, but the importer makes a profit with a tariff.
question.e: E) domestic producers gain with a tariff and lose with an import quota.

question.q: 33) A difference between a quota and a tariff is that
question.a: A) a tariff generates a higher price than does an import quota.
question.b: B) a tariff generates a greater reduction in exports than does an import quota.
question.c: C) an import quota increases profits of domestic producers more than a tariff.
question.d: D) the government collects revenue from a tariff but does not collect revenue from an import quota.
question.e: E) an import quota creates a social loss and a tariff does not.

question.q: 34) A tariff ________ the domestic price of the good and an import quota ________ the domestic price of the good.
question.c: C) raises; lowers
question.d: D) raises; raises
question.e: E) does not change; does not change

question.q: 35) Table 31.2.1 shows the Canadian supply of and demand for widgets. Widgets are available on the world market for $7. If the Canadian government imposes a tariff of $1, the domestic selling price will be ________ and quantity bought will be ________.
question.c: C) $8; 16 million
question.d: D) $8; 24 million

question.q: 36) Table 31.2.1 shows the Canadian supply of and demand for widgets. Widgets are available on the world market for $7. If the Canadian government imposes a tariff of $1, how many widgets will Canada import?
question.c: C) 16 million
question.d: D) 28 million

question.q: 37) Table 31.2.1 shows the Canadian supply of and demand for widgets. Widgets are available on the world market for $7. Canadian widget producers convince the government to protect the domestic industry from cheap imports. If the Canadian government sets an import quota of 8 million widgets, the resulting price of a widget in Canada will be ________, and domestic production will be ________.
question.c: C) $8; 32 million
question.d: D) $9; 28 million

question.q: 38) A tariff on watches which are imported by Atlantis ________ the price of watches in Atlantis and ________.
question.a: A) lowers; imports of watches increase
question.b: B) raises; watch production in Atlantis increases
question.c: C) raises; watch production in Atlantis decreases
question.d: D) lowers; watch production in Atlantis increases
question.e: E) lowers; watch production in Atlantis decreases

question.q: 39) When an import quota is imposed, the gap between the domestic price and the price received in the exporting country is captured by
question.a: A) consumers in the importing country.
question.b: B) the domestic producers of the good.
question.c: C) the government of the importing country.
question.d: D) foreign exporters.
question.e: E) the importers of the good.

question.q: 40) When a tariff is imposed, the gap between the domestic price and the price received in the exporting country is captured by
question.a: A) consumers in the importing country.
question.b: B) the domestic producers of the good.
question.c: C) the government of the importing country.
question.d: D) foreign exporters.
question.e: E) the domestic importers of the good.

question.q: 41) Canada imposes a tariff on $1 per imported shirt, the higher tariff
question.a: A) raises the price of a shirt to Canadian consumers.
question.c: C) decreases imports of shirts into Canada.
question.d: D) creates a social loss.

question.q: 42) If Canada imposes a tariff on imported steel, the tariff
question.a: A) raises the Canadian price of imported steel.
question.b: B) decreases Canadian production of steel.
question.c: C) increases the total Canadian consumption of steel.
question.d: D) decreases employment in the Canadian steel industry.
question.e: E) both B and D are correct.

question.q: 43) Lowering the tariff on good X
question.a: A) increases domestic employment in industry X.
question.b: B) increases domestic imports of good X.
question.c: C) increases the domestic price of good X.
question.d: D) has no effect unless the nation's trading partners also lower their tariffs on good X.

question.q: 44) When the Canadian government imposes a tariff ________.
question.a: A) Canadian consumers gain and Canadian producers lose, and the gain exceeds the loss
question.b: B) the tariff revenue earned by the government is a social loss
question.c: C) a social loss occurs because increased domestic production could have been obtained at a lower cost as an import
question.d: D) Canadian producers lose
question.e: E) A and B are both correct

question.q: 45) Among the following, the domestic government gains the most revenue when it
question.c: C) encourages freer trade.
question.d: D) imposes a tariff.
question.e: E) increases the demand for a domestically-produced good.

question.q: 46) If a quota is set at the same quantity of imports that results from a tariff in Country A,
question.a: A) the quantity consumed in Country A is less under the quota than under the tariff.
question.b: B) the quantity consumed in Country A is the same under the quota and under the tariff.
question.c: C) the quantity consumed in Country A is more under the quota than under the tariff.
question.d: D) the government tariff revenue is greater than the importers' profit from the import quota.
question.e: E) the government tariff revenue is less than the importers' profit from the import quota.

question.q: 1) Economists usually agree with which of the following arguments that favour protectionism?
question.a: A) the competition with cheap foreign labour defence
question.c: C) the dumping defence
question.d: D) the infant-industry defence
question.e: E) None of the above. Economists generally agree that arguments in favor of protection are flawed.

question.q: 2) Which of the following are valid reasons advanced by almost all economists? Protection
question.b: B) prevents rich countries from exploiting developing countries.
question.c: C) is a good way for governments in developed nations to raise revenue.
question.d: D) penalizes lax environmental standards.
question.e: E) Economists would not support any of the above reasons.

question.q: 3) Which of the following are reasons economists consider valid for trade protection?
question.c: C) I, II, and III
question.d: D) I and III

question.q: 4) The idea of dynamic comparative advantage is the basis for which of the following arguments for protection from foreign competition?
question.a: A) the cheap foreign labour argument
question.c: C) the dumping argument
question.d: D) the saves jobs argument
question.e: E) the prevents rich countries from exploiting developing countries argument

question.q: 5) The most efficient way to encourage the growth of an infant-industry is through
question.c: C) a subsidy.
question.d: D) an import quota.

question.q: 6) The proposition that protection is necessary to allow an infant industry to grow into a mature industry so that it can compete in world markets is the ________.
question.c: C) new industry proposition
question.d: D) growth proposition

question.q: 7) Dumping occurs when a foreign firm ________.
question.b: B) disposes of waste material internationally
question.c: C) sells inferior output to foreigners
question.d: D) sells its exports at a lower price than its cost of production
question.e: E) sells its output at a lower price in a foreign country than in the country where it produces the good

question.q: 8) ________ occurs when a foreign firm sells its exports at a lower price than its cost of production.
question.c: C) A tariff
question.d: D) An infant industry

question.q: 9) Suppose that the country of Pacifica sold its cars in Atlantica for less than it costs to produce the cars. Pacifica could be accused of
question.b: B) increasing its gains from trade.
question.c: C) dumping.
question.d: D) engaging in learning-by-doing.

question.q: 10) When a firms "dumps" some of its output in another country, it
question.a: A) creates an environmental hazard in the receiving country.
question.b: B) sells its output abroad at a price lower than it costs to produce the output.
question.c: C) increases the total level of employment in the importing country.
question.d: D) is specializing according to comparative advantage.
question.e: E) creates for itself an absolute advantage.

question.q: 11) In poorer countries, free trade ________ the demand for labour in these countries and ________ the wages paid in these countries.
question.c: C) increases; lowers
question.d: D) increases; raises
question.e: E) increases the supply and decreases; lowers

question.q: 12) Which of the following statements is true?
question.a: A) International trade raises wages in developing countries.
question.b: B) International trade with rich industrial countries forces people in the developing countries to work for lower wages.
question.c: C) International trade leads to job losses in both import competing industries and exporting industries.
question.d: D) Unlike other types of international trade, offshoring does not bring any gains from trade.

question.q: 13) The argument that protection ________.
question.a: A) penalizes poor environmental standards is true
question.b: B) allows us to compete with cheap foreign wages is true
question.c: C) is necessary for infant industries is true
question.d: D) saves jobs is flawed
question.e: E) prevents rich countries from exploiting poor countries is true.

question.q: 14) Which of the following is an explanation for the existence of trade restrictions?
question.a: A) tariffs generate revenue for the government
question.c: C) inefficient quotas
question.d: D) both A and B

question.q: 15) In industrial countries, there is more reliance on ________, as opposed to ________ for government revenue.
question.c: C) tariffs; import quotas
question.d: D) import quotas; tax collection

question.q: 16) In developing countries, there is more reliance on ________ as opposed to ________ for government revenue.
question.c: C) tax collection; tariffs
question.d: D) tariffs; import quotas

question.q: 17) Of the groups listed below, which is most likely to lobby for protection?
question.a: A) workers in the import industry
question.b: B) workers in the export industry
question.c: C) consumers in the import industry
question.d: D) producers in the export industry

question.q: 18) Rent seeking is one reason why countries choose to
question.a: A) export and import the same goods.
question.c: C) follow the theory of comparative advantage.
question.d: D) hire foreign labour.

question.q: 19) When considering rent seeking, which of the following is TRUE?
question.a: A) The anti-free trade group generally will lobby more than the pro-free trade group.
question.b: B) The pro-free trade group generally will lobby more than the anti-free trade group.
question.c: C) Usually only the anti-free trade group is concerned about what is best for society at large.
question.d: D) Only the pro-free trade group is concerned about the government's revenue from tariffs.

question.q: 20) One reason that international trade is restricted is that
question.a: A) the individual gain to parties who benefit from the protection will be much larger than the individual loss to parties who lose.
question.b: B) the government completely pays the losers from international trade for their losses.
question.c: C) protectionism benefits consumers.
question.d: D) the government cannot measure the cost of protectionism.
question.e: E) tariff revenue raises more income than income taxes in industrial countries.

question.q: 21) Usually the removal of trade barriers affecting a particular good benefits ________ people domestically, each of whom gains a ________.
question.c: C) many; little
question.d: D) many; lot
question.e: E) We can't determine the relative benefits from the removal of trade barriers.

question.q: 22) Usually the imposition of trade barriers affecting a particular good benefits ________ people domestically, each of whom gains a ________.
question.c: C) many; little
question.d: D) many; lot
question.e: E) We can't determine the relative benefits from the imposition of trade barriers.

question.q: 23) The gains from free trade are enjoyed by a ________ number of people and the costs of free trade are imposed on a ________ number of people.
question.c: C) small; small
question.d: D) large; large
question.e: E) We can't determine the relative number of people who benefit and lose from free trade.

question.q: 24) The effects of offshoring from opening up call centres in India are similar to the effects from
question.c: C) import quota.
question.d: D) voluntary export restraints.

question.q: 25) Two reasons that explain why international trade in 2010 remains restricted is that restricted international trade ________.
question.a: A) benefits domestic producers of import-competing goods and services and generates tariff revenue in developing countries
question.b: B) prevents developed countries from exploiting third world countries and saves jobs in those countries
question.c: C) brings diversity and stability to the whole economy and saves jobs in developing countries
question.d: D) saves jobs and penalizes developing countries that have lax environmental standards
question.e: E) brings diversity to the whole economy and penalizes countries that have lax environmental standards

question.q: 26) Offshore outsourcing occurs when a firm in Canada ________.
question.a: A) hires foreign labour and produces in other countries
question.b: B) buys finished goods, components, or services from other firms in other countries
question.c: C) buys finished goods, components, or services from other firms in Canada
question.d: D) hires Canadian labour and produces in Canada
question.e: E) hires foreign workers who work in Canada

question.q: 27) When a firm implements offshore outsourcing, consumers in Canada ________, workers in Canada in the industry that is being outsourced ________ and workers in the foreign country in the industry that is being outsourced ________.
question.c: C) lose; gain; lose
question.d: D) gain; lose; gain

question.q: 28) The infant industry argument is based on the idea of
question.c: C) tariff maximization.
question.d: D) learning-by-doing.

question.q: 29) Offshoring occurs when a firm in Canada
question.a: A) hires foreign labour and produces in other countries.
question.b: B) buys finished goods, components, or services from other firms in other countries.
question.c: C) hires Canadian labour and produces in Canada.
question.d: D) buys finished goods, components, or services from other firms in Canada.
question.e: E) Both A and B are correct.
